content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												Review from Whiskey Reviews[wskosc.blogspot.co.uk]Sid Meier's name has become a stamp of instant approval over the years, ever since Pirates! we've accepted it as a seal of quality on Civilization games. Beyond Earth was hugely disappointing, so can the follow-up mend Sid's damaged appeal or is it time to hit end turn? Follow the link to find out.Lets be upfront; Starships is a huge disappointment. Like a good PC gamer the first thing you'll want to do is hit the options button and change resolution and bindings and the like; good luck getting any of that. The game is simply full screen or windowed, though you can resize the window it has the feel of playing a tablet game on your PC - and I've looked favourably upon many a tablet/phone port in the past but Starships stinks of lazy.It's not a bad looking game, resembling Civ 5 on medium settings but tough♥♥♥♥♥♥if your PC can't handle it because there's no graphical quality options to tinker with.While we're being upfront, there's no multiplayer either. If you're mainly a Civ multiplayer person then you'll probably want to skip right to the score and replace whatever number I pick with a big fat zero.The most thrilling Starships ever gets.That feeling doesn't subside with the actual gameplay either, you have one fleet of starships that you can upgrade and move around a randomly generated map. You can build more ships but they always go into this one fleet and no matter how much you upgrade them they're always one of a couple of classes and strategy is rather basic.Like Civilization combat takes place on a hexagonal grid, this time littered with asteroid fields of varying density that you can hide behind and which will lower the power of or block your shots entirely. Unlike Civilization 5 weapons have gigantic ranges of half a dozen tiles or more and more than one unit can occupy the same tile, eliminating what few tactical advantages the hex grid system had.There's no point building a flimsy cruiser loaded down with torpedoes because the enemy can just shoot its long range lasers past your friendly units and take it down, for example.Your two main tactics come in the form of asteroids and stealth.Asteroids as previously mentioned will lower a shots power or block it entirely. It's not always a perfect solution but you can hide weaker ships behind partial asteroid fields and launch fast but flimsy fighters or torpedoes from safety.Stealth meanwhile is a game breaking ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t button. Hitting the stealth button puts a ring around your ship, enemy ships have to get into this ring to detect your ship and fire upon it. It doesn't take many upgrades to bring this down to a one-hex or even half-hex size, making your ships almost entirely undetectable since the AI seems to forget sensors exist.Coupled with long range lasers, or even powerful short-range plasma weapons and you have a recipe for domination no matter what the odds. Throw in a wonder that allows you to enter stealth at no cost, activating it for free when you move which allows you to remain invisible and fire at the same time and you've got an instant win that'll allow as little as two or three moderately equipped ships to rampage across the galaxy freeing planets from your enemies influence often with no opposition as the AI attempts to preserve resources by not facing you for fear of being dominated.Remember that options screen from earlier?Some flavour is added to the combat via each encounter's random modifier, for example you might not be allowed to move directly right (referred to as "east" in game) or asteroid fields might disappear as the battle goes on, or shields might not work as well. They're minor, sometimes annoying and calling them flavour might have been a bit too generous because after four or five matches you'll stop reading them and just hit next.Second on the flavour menu is battle cards, again random effects that buff your fleet for varying effects; perhaps adding an extra shield level or allowing you to move two spaces further or even repairing your ships or damaging the enemies. They're useful in the right situation but I've gone whole campaigns without even using one, mainly because my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t stealth fleet was untouchable. Ooh! Choices! Those are the default selections by the way.The metagame is likewise light on stategy and content; you have crew morale/fatigue and that limits how many times you can move your fleet each turn. The idea being to jump between planets and secure influence to bring them into your empire in order to gain their resources and benefits.You do this by taking part in randomly selected missions for rewards. Having them randomly selected is nice but the serious lack of them, I think there's only about 7 or 8 in total, makes for a lot of repetition even in a medium sized galaxy let alone over multiple games. The missions generally come in three flavours; blow something up, run away, or play king of the hill with an AI too stupid to capture more than one of the points.One mission type I particularly hate, to the point that I let AIs actually take that planet and start a war to get it back later is the maze type. You either get limited sensor range or a limited number of turns and have to navigate a dense asteroid field set up like a maze, sometimes with enemies chasing you too. It's boring and stupid and if I wanted mazes I'd be playing a better game like Rogue, or Shining Force.Gameplay: Still not that good.Resources come in four flavours and have a single use each:Energy allows you to upgrade your ships or add new ones to the fleet.Metals allow you to buy planetary upgrades and build wonders.Food allows you to build cities, improving the resource generation of planets.Research allows you to research things (duh).Credits, lastly, are for buying the other resources via a Sins Of A Solar Empire style market.While I can't complain about the simplicity of the resource system, it does turn into a checklist of things to do every turn, since there's not much point holding onto anything because the diplomacy system might as well not exist so you may as well just dump everything into upgrading your own empire as soon as possible.The only resource you'll really put any thought into is energy, because it's used for repairing damaged ships you'll want to hold a little back each turn in case of a disastrous defeat or, more likely, a ding in the paintwork.Research is similarly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.Wonders make a return too, not every planet has one but many do and they're expensive to build but confer a powerful and ride ranging set of bonuses upon your fleet, and only your fleet.Bonuses range from the almost useless Torpedo Boosters (extra torpedo move speed) to the must-have Cloaking (free and automatic stealth) or Fleet Tradition (fatigue doesn't lower your crew's performance), making your third battle per turn just as easy to win as the first.The problem with wonders is that they're also a victory condition, having seven of them is an instant win so if you're late grabbing territory the AI can score an easy victory over you but this also backfires spectacularly as you can just let them build the wonders then go in and start stealing them out from under their noses. Of course, it wouldn't be Starships if they didn't manage to ♥♥♥♥ up the implementation somehow. Wonders aren't the only victory condition, but you'd be forgiven for thinking they are because it's so easy to accidentally win a wonder victory. For example, if you're going for a domination victory (holding 51% of all the planets) you'll have to grab enemy territory and their wonders along with it which leads to accidentally hoarding seven of the bloody things and winning via the condition you didn't want.Too long for Steam: Read the rest at http://wskosc.blogspot.co.uk

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												I think people were expecting a lot more from this game than what this game really is. It's just a little twiddle exploring one of Sid Meier's ideas. I can beat an "epic" difficult campaign in a matter of hours - my 26 hours as of this review has already put me through multiple campaigns. And in XCOM or Civilizations, I'd normally be maybe halfway through. And it's a spinoff of the Civilization Beyond Earth games - which are okay in their own right but thankfully the real Civilization games are still being actively developed.- Graphics? What graphics. They get the job done, though, and the engine's fairly optimized (Not completely stable, but optimized) so even paper PCs will run it well. And there's no finnagling with the UI, for the most part.- The ships are interesting at first until you understand just how simple they are. It's easy to learn, easy to pick up, and easy to exploit - perhaps too easy.- Combat is really simple - if you don't splurge on turn-based strategy games it might even be interesting, intriguing. There are a few options available to you - long-range laser sniper, hive mind swarmer with fighters, or close range facepuncher with plasma cannons. But compared to a game like XCOM, which has many small intricacies and almost nothing is certain (everything is certain in Starships, believe me, the only random action in a fight is whatever the AI does), Starships really does fade in comparison. You always know what's going to happen, and it happens the same way every time. It really hurts the replayability when you know the same thing that happened last campaign will probably happen again, even on the harder difficulties.- I consider the difference between tactics and strategy as follows: Tactics is being able to whoop someone's♥♥♥♥♥ whereas strategy is putting yourself in a great position to whoop someone's♥♥♥♥♥ That being said I think while the strategy level is just as simple as setting up your ships, the actions you take in the galaxy have a direct and tangible effect on the battlefields. For instance, you can't really be a great carrier swarmer without having Tight Squeeze, Hyperlaunch and Dual Command wonders built and AI modules researched to make the fighters worth something instead of just bait. You can't cover your ships in plasma cannons, engines and shields without having the planets to produce your energy, or which specialize in building said equipment for cheap. So the benefits to good strategy are there. But, like almost everything else, it's just really simple.It's difficult for me to recommend this game, it really is, because of what people will want and how simple this game is. I'm half-convinced that the main target platform for this game is the mobile platform - this would probably be a great mobile game, and it's just so underwhelming for a PC. But for what it is, it's a nice little gem to me, worth a few dozen hours. In the end I won't try to dissuade you from buying it, particularly if it's on sale. Even though feedback is bad, I want a bigger, badder, more complex version of this game that we can really sink our teeth into. Something that can stand proudly by Civ and XCOM. Even if it does have to sprout off Beyond Earth.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												I rarely write reviews so that should tell you a bit about the emotion I have for it. This is one of the most INCOMPLETE games I've ever played. There are some pieces of genius within this system, but they are hidden by a completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fleet management system, a stripped down research and upgrade system, a planetary management system that is just "for show" and a tech tree/wonder system that could be entirely missing and have the same impact on the game as this one. Don't even get me started on the victory system. While this isn't as bad as the abomination that was the spreadsheet simulator MOO3 - this is close enough to bring it up within this context.Clearly there was a lot of thought going into the creation of this game, but it just never comes together in any cohesive way. If you thought that Beyond Earth needed work or never delivered on its promise, stay far far far away from this demoware/proof of concept masquerading as a game. I'm surprised Sid Meier let his name be associated with it.

Posted: May 18, 2015
												I've been playing Sid Meier's games for a long long time. They ARE basically what I look for in a PC game and have brought me years of enjoyment. Now we have Sid Meier's Starships, which I'd been waiting for excitedly after the surprisingly great jump to space in Beyond Earth. Unfortunately this game is absolutely horrible. The game lacks that compelling desire its predecessors have to play and defeat it in all ways possible, or even explore the game or the world(s) within, because the interface is awful and the "story" throws you into space to do unexplained busy work. I can't begin to explain how this shook the foundations of what I believe to be the fundamental truths of the video game industry. This is coming from a fan who continued to play your games after my brother fell dead at his computer, due to a medical complication, and it just so happened he was playing Alpha Centauri when he passed. I never brought myself to play Alpha Centauri again, but I'd be real sad if he had died playing this pour excuse for a game. I hope you think real hard before putting your name on any product again. I think your time may have passed.Sincerely,Formerly one of your biggest fans,Steven R. Carr

content:
Posted: January 8
TLDR:Fast-paced, single-player, turn-based game.  More like "Galactic Civilizations" lite, than "Alpha Centauri" or any of the Civs.  Graphics and music are ok, gameplay is fun enough, but the user interface sometimes leaves you swearing at the monitor in an alien language.  I like the game, but was surprised it was a Firaxis title (lacked their typical depth and polish).Pros:+ Unique features add a nice twist+ Decent AI in the game's begining+ Some story and mission variety+ Immersive graphics and music+ Dynamic strategic/tactical mapsMids:* No tutorial (but not hard to learn)* In-game help (encyclopedia) is eh* Limited to 1 fleet (max 8 ships)* Not really a 4x - lacks real control* iOS port; VERY limited settingsCons:- Interface limited and frustrating- Some weird graphic glitches- Diplomacy is a joke - war/peace- Almost no data, lists, or charts- Big mid-game "steamroll" effectConclusion:Can't say I don't like the game, as I have enjoyed playing it.  I am however glad that I didn't pay much for it (I'd easily recommend it if you're able to grab it on sale for $7.50 or less).Kinda surprised this was a Firaxis game.  It's fun and all (graphics and music help to make you feel the way you'd expect to when playing a space game), but there is SOOOO much more that could have been there but isn't (list of planets and cities, charts showing ships, ability to make more than one fleet, less kludgy interface, etc.).Consider this a mildly enthusiastic thumbs up (would probably be  "Thumbs Sideways" if Steam allowed for the option).

number of helpful: 26 of 37 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												TLDR: A neat little game with some cool ideas, but mobile-game production values and a lack of long-term depth don't justify the $15 asking price. Worth picking up on sale or if you're desperate for some bite-sized light strategy, though.Store page description aside, Sid Meier's Starships is a turn-based strategy game wherein you try to conquer the galaxy. There are multiple ways to do this, but they all essentially boil down to building an unstoppable battle fleet and destroying your enemies.The game is divided into two layers. On the greater strategic layer, you see the galaxy itself, taking your fleet from planet to planet and performing missions to convince the inhabitants to join your empire. The tactical layer puts you on a hex-based battlescape and maneuvering your individual ships to do whatever needs to be done (and almost always involves the destruction of enemy ships). Complete a mission to gain influence with the planet's population. Gather enough influence and the planet will join your empire wholesale. Of course, your rivals will be doing the same thing in their section of space.The first half of Starships is basically a race for territory and resources, like in any classic 4X. Players will try to expand their empires, pulling in neutral planets and building infrastructure to fuel further conquest. Eventually, borders will start pressing up against each other, the galaxy will run out of neutral planets, and from there, it's a matter of the major players fighting it out to settle who will become space overlord of humanity. This is where things start to fall apart, as massive power swings can come out of nowhere and end a game without warning.There are four victory conditions. Capturing all other players' homeworlds obviously wins you the game, as does maxing out three fields of technology, controlling seven wonders, or governing over half of the galaxy's total population. The big swings come out of the way homeworld battles work. When a player captures another player's homeworld, the losing player's empire is immediately turned over to the conqueror in its entirety. A player with 15% of the galaxy's population can shoot up to 40% or more in a single battle, or zoom past the seven-wonder victory threshold before anyone knows what's going on.The actual starship combat is simple and easy to learn. Lasers have long effective ranges, while plasma cannons boast superior firepower once you can bring them to bear. Firing one means not being able to fire the other that turn. Torpedoes have a delay before they can be detonated, but are effective at area denial. Cloaking technology can make ships untargetable if there's no sensor-equipped enemy nearby to reveal them. Strike craft are weak, but they're fast and they can be replaced and repaired for free. Attacking a ship from the sides or rear generally provides hefty increases in damage done, and doing more damage increases the chance of scoring a critical hit and damaging the effectiveness of a ship's systems. Controlling various wonders, as usual, allows a player to break some of these rules.The economy side of the game exists purely to support the combat side of the game. You will not be building fantastic monuments and converting heathens to your banner using the power of your culture. You will not unlock the mysteries of the universe that bring your people to a new stage of enlightenment. You will research bigger guns, heavier armor, and more efficient engines for the ships. You will build ships, or you will build factories that build ships, or you will build factories that build factories that build ships. All roads lead to ship. The ship is love, the ship is life.Speaking of the ships, customization here is kind of weak. Rather than picking and choosing modules that change the way the ships function, you simply pick a category, choose a rating from 0-8, spend the requisite amount of ship-specific currency, and move on to the next. There's a certain amount of technique involved in weighing tradeoffs between speed and armor, or pure firepower versus stealth capabilities, or fighters versus torpedoes, but if you're looking for omnidirectional shields, stealth torpedoes, point defense cannons or any kind of customization that's any more complex than making one number larger than the others, you'll have to hope that there's a wonder that'll serve your purposes.Sid Meier's Starships was released simultaneously on PC and iOS, and it really shows. The UI is clearly designed for a mobile crowd, and it values clean visuals and uncluttered space above all else (including, at times, functionality). The ingame options menu is a joke, consisting of volume sliders and the options to turn tutorials and fullscreen mode on or off. There are no resolution or detail settings, which might be for the best because there's not a whole lot of detail to be had in the first place.Installing modules on a ship changes the model itself, but those changes don't exactly carry into the battles themselves. A battleship bristling with weaponry won't show off all of its guns firing with separate particle and lighting effects, just a slightly-larger salvo of lasers inexplicably curving in space as they approach their target. The backdrops and leader portraits have a painted look that washes them clean of finer details. All leader audio has been lifted from Civilization: Beyond Earth, and the only other voicework ingame consists of short combat barks along the lines of "critical damage" or "nice shot." Completing the game, regardless of method, affinity, or faction, yields the same unskippable victory cutscene (yes, a PC-centric developer released a game with unskippable cutscenes). If another player wins, their victory is announced with a quiet pop-up before the game unceremoniously dumps you back to the title screen--a title screen that lacks a proper exit button.Sid Meier's Starships boasts connectivity with Civilization: Beyond Earth, but you have to sign up for a My2K account to take advantage of that connectivity, and I'm not interested in juggling yet another set of login data. I doubt that it's a game-changer for either game, but I could be wrong. Either way, it's the cherry on top of the Bad Mobile Port sundae. As a proof-of-concept, Starships is great, boasting several ideas that I hope can be refined and make their way into future games (flanking-based damage, one randomly-determined wonder per city-equivalent, mission-based diplomacy), but it's all buried under a huge pile of the stereotypical money grab (content gated behind company-specific login, subpar production values, halfhearted PC port, gameplay that bottoms out within three hours). It really feels like an iOS game that got ported to the PC as an afterthought, and for $15, you might as well catch a good movie instead. Starships is a decent guilty pleasure, but I'd only recommend it if you can catch it on sale.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												If you're looking for an epic 4x space strategy game like Endless Space, Galactic Civilizations 1-3, or something else, this is not that game. If you are looking for a game with spreadsheets and lists, this is not that game. If you're looking for a game where you command hundreds of ships divided into multiple fleets, this is not that game. If however you're looking for a lite 4x space strategy game that includes tactical combat and can be played start to finish in a few hours, then this might be worth consideration.The unique element of this game is how it's focused around your single fleet of ships. In the beginning of the game, the fleet is not very strong. However given enough resources it can grow in size (up to 8 ships) and strength to become a formidable force in the galaxy. You'll be faced with the decision of choosing between engines, shields, armor, and different weapons. Do you continue to upgrade your existing ships or buy more ships to add to the fleet? Do you choose speed over armor? Do you build out your ships for specific roles? What tech do you research to compliment your upgrade strategy? Then there are wonders which further enhance your fleet and can provide huge advantages. You'll also find battle cards which provide bonuses during missions.Another fun element of the game are the missions. When you visit other planets you'll be faced with missions that range from escorting transport ships while protecting them from pirates, escaping with sympathizers aboard your flagship, defeating waves of attacking ships, and so on. Successfully completing missions will provide influence or other rewards.As for the complaints about this being a tablet or mobile game, it is true that the options screen is missing some common options available on PC games, the game isn't a true full screen in that the taskbar isn't hidden, and the screen doesn't scroll automagically when the mouse hits the edge. However none of these things have prevented me from playing the game. The map can be moved with either the arrow keys or the left mouse button. The taskbar can be set to auto-hide if it's that distracting (or just deal with it). In regards to price, I do think that PC gamers unfortunately do end up paying a premium over the mobile platforms. This isn't the first game and it won't be the last.Finally, in regards to expectations, I think people saw Sid Meier's name along with this being set in space and left their expectations unchecked. First, the low price point should have been a major indicator that this wasn't going to be anywhere near the scale of a Civilization game. Second, a Sid Meier games doesn't automatically infer an epic game. The past few years 2K/Firaxis have had smaller Sid Meier titles such as Ace Patrol, Ace Patrol: Pacific Skies, and Civilization Revolutions which were on the mobile platform.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												Very cool idea, very boring execution.This feels like it was supposed to be "Civ in space." In reality, it's not even close. This isn't even Civ lite. The idea is cool. Instead of cities, you have planets. You send your eponymous starships on missions to help the residents of various planets in order to win them over to your side.The glaring problems:You get one fleet. The game is built around only having one fleet, so it kinda works. Just doesn't make any sense. Why would a space-faring civilization artificially limit themselves to a single fleet of eight warships? If this game didn't have Sid Meier's name on it, I wouldn't mention this. If it wasn't obviously meant to be viewed as "Civ in space," I wouldn't mention it. Want Civ in space? Go play the "Final Frontier" mod from Civ 4's Beyond the Sword expansion.Diplomacy is stupid. It's a ridiculously stripped-down version of the Diplomacy mechanics from Civ. You're always either at war or have a peace treaty with every other federation. If you're not at war, you can't move onto one of their planets. You must first declare war (using the diplomacy menue), then the move will be allowed. Here's the stupid part. Try this:1. Declare war.2. Conquer one planet belonging to enemy faction.3. Move to second planet belonging to same enemy.4. Accept bribe.5. War is over. "Enemy" will not attack you on their turn.6. Repeat.Battle AI is stupid. Enemy ships tend to stay in groups of at least two ships, making them very susceptible to torpedo attacks. Even if this wasn't the case, the AI hardly ever uses torpedos or stealth, making your opponents boringly easy to dominate.Conquest is the entire game. There are apparently other victory conditions but I can't see why you'd pursue them, since this is a game about spaceships fighting each other for control of planets.Battle tactics quickly become about filling the map with as many torpedos as possible to make sure you take out enemy ships without having to get lucky. You could certainly swarm the enemy with fighters instead, or pump the crap out of your plasma cannons and stealth units, getting in close for the kill. The point is: any "tactic" you choose simply works. The AI provides no challenge whatsoever.I'll admit that some of these things might be the result of me only playing on "Normal" difficulty. I'm going to go try it again on hard but I'm not hopeful that I will meet a much greater challenge or that I won't be able to loop a war with one opposing faction at a time.TL;DRAfter playing Doom 3 or Colonial Marines, go back and play Wolf3d or Catacomb Abyss. Starships feels like a 1991 PC game that should by now have 4 sequels, each one a bit more complicated than the last (like Civilization). In reality, it just feels undeveloped. Not unpolished or incomplete; just featureless and bland.

												After reading quite a few reviews of this game, it seems as if it is the reviewers expectations that missed rather than the game itself.  As a few others have said, if you want a big sprawling 4X then go play Civ or Beyond Earth.  This is exactly the game I wanted, sort of a Gilligan's Island (or How I Met Your Mother for the millenials) - mindless entertainment to let my head decompress after a day at work. I just wish it ran on my laptop, but that is my problem, not the game developers.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												*sigh*  I've played several games at this point and feel that I have a really good handle on the AI in the game.  I *do* find the game enjoyable as a general time-waster, but the game is basically unfinished.  I really, really, really wanted to be able to recommend this game....  I honestly did, but as it stands right now the game is far too buggy, its rules too simplistic, its tactical combat far too imbalanced, and that results in an experience that is frustrating and extremely shallow.  I've been playing on easy and, as expected, the AI hasn't really surprised me.  In 10 hours I haven't lost a single battle.  However, I've also lost every single game.  How can this be possible?!?  Well, it's because the victory condition system is horribly broken for the type of game this is (similar to how it's horribly broken in Beyond Earth, only worse).  In every single case, I've been defeated by a Wonder victory.  "Disable Wonder victories and just allow a Domination victory then!  Problem solved!"Yeah... that's what I've been doing, and it doesn't work.  So I decided to shift my tactics and aggressively go after building wonders... which worked until I got 65% of the galaxy and the rest of the enemies all spontaneously decided to join up together, resulting in a collective Wonder victory.I am literally cleaning the floor with the computer AI and it just declares victory with ... math.And that's possible because at its' heart, all this game is ... is a linear resource race.  Every. Single. Aspect of this game is a linear resource race... and victory would be entirely guaranteed if the Victory system wasn't totally broken.I really wanted to like this game.  I had really high hopes upon reading it and, like I said at the beginning, it's a fantastic time-waster... but the game needs more than bug fixes to solve its' issues.  It needs a rules and mechanics redesign, so I really can't recommend it.  I guess at least I don't feel cheated.  I got almost 10 hours out of a $15 game and something should be said for that.  I think the people who worked on this game honestly cared about it, and I think the same is true for Beyond Earth... but ultimately I feel like I just keep dumping money into this franchise because Civ 5 was so darn amazing.  Unfortunately, Firaxis has been basically unable to live up to that triumph with both offerings.I hope that both Beyond Earth and Starships go through an overhaul to fix these massive issues... if that happens, I'll happily return and rewrite this review.Until that happens, I can't recommend Starships.  It's far too broken right now to do so.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												Very shallow and buggy. Crashes often on start or when winning. There's really just a hand full of different unit types, and realistically you ever have access to three of them. The integration with Beyond Earth is a neat idea, but it really adds nothing of real gameplay value. Some buffs, etc, but it doesn't make the game any more interesting, just easier, which it doesn't really need help being. Diplomacy is limited, as is what you can do with planets, so there isn't really a diplomacy "win". Most planets have a wonder, which makes the "culture" win objective really easy. Most of the objectives are rather easy now with how extremely streamlined this game is, with population being at 51% (you can pump up the population of your planets infinitely with city upgrades) and conquest being the regular old "kill everyone", which is now by far the hardest objective to aim for what with population boosts from taking over enemy federations.A lot of AI behaviors are locked off behind difficulty walls, so if you play normal or whatever you'll usually never see AI get aggressive enough to invade your homeworld. I kept digging looking for some sort of "rare" encounter, planet, etc, but it seems like no matter the difficulty or size you'll probably see most of everything.I've definitely played worse strategy games, but I feel like the Sid Meier name gets affixed to titles that tend to have some depth. I came in thinking this would be something like a "Civ lite", but it's more like "Civ barebones" with just the most basic of gameplay elements left to the Sid Meier name, almost to the point where it looks like a halfassed attempt to clone the Civ franchise.

number of helpful: 47 of 80 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I will not write an extensive review of this game for a few reasons, one being that the problems with this game are already being vocally expressed, and secondly because I believe the game in it's current state is very incomplete and has the potential for change over the coming months if the developers are open to feedback and implementing it.I will probably just focus on the one thing that bothers me most about this game and that is Immersion.Civilization 5 is already universally accepted as being a great success in the Civ franchise, while lacking in some of the hardcore elements of the previous titles, it still makes for an enjoyable and immersive experience from start to finish, with engaging mechanics and DLC.Civ:BE - A game I wanted so much to fall in love with, being a huge fan of SMAC, lacked in new and engaging mechanics, and felt slightly hollow, despite it's somewhat empty nature I still found my experience with Beyond Earth to be fairly immersive, and this immersion is what drives me to commit a few hours to enjoying the games content.Now onto SM: Starships, unfortunately the immersion for this game ends not long after you've chosen your leader and faction, and gained your first territory, after that you begin to realise the game offers very little after that in terms of a feeling of progression, success or any kind of immersion in the world.I like the mechanics of how the missions are fought, I like turn based strategy games played on grids so I enjoyed these aspects somewhat, but found they were not very challenging or interesting enough to remain immersed in the action and cause of the game.The AI at this points seems fairly dead, they will make their presence known and then afterwards there isn't much diplomatic use for them. You will find at some point you're either going to have to betray your allies or make peace agreements with them which completely block you from travelling into or through their territory to reach new unclaimed planets, this can lead to you getting completely isolated and unable to progress.The game needs a lot of work, it has the workings of a great game, but it feels as if it hasn't been worked on enough yet, the UI needs to be more engaging and helpful, think back to Civ 4 and 5, while Civ 5 did not offer as much as Civ 4 did in terms of the advanced customization of how you can play the game, both titles gave you enough to build yourself an engaging and immersive experience. It seems the developers have been limiting that customizable freedom which has been such a defining feature of the Sid Meiers Franchise, starting with Civ: Beyond Earth and now with Starships, I hope the devs are able to look back to the past and remember what made their games so successful and work on keeping their reputation alive.One of the main criticisms of this game right now is that it feels more like a mobile app which is what it has also been released for, and right now it seems as if it has been limited more for the mobile app platform, rather than developed as a fully functioning game that can stand the test of time on both platforms. While smart to break into the booming market of mobile applications and mobile gaming, I feel they should of perhaps decided on either releasing a standalone mobile app, a desktop exclusive release, or simply put more effort into developing the game mechanics and elements further.At the moment I cannot recommend it, for the very simple reasons that I don't believe you will get much enjoyment out of it for too long in it's current state, and is certainly not worth it's current price in what it offers.I look forward to following where this game goes next, and what the supposed cross-game functionality with Beyond Earth will offer (it seems to me that whatever that feature is has not yet been released), but for now I'll be letting this one sit in my library.

number of helpful: 13 of 17 people (76%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												If you think of the Civ Series "Beyond Earth" as the "meat and potatoes' of Sid Meier's 4X games, you can think of Starships as the "snack food" equivalent. Most people have had a beef with this Sid Meier spinoff game because it doesn't look or feel like any of his similar 4X games. This one is built for speed and playability, but still has depth if you want to go deeper on the building and resource explotation aspects. Most fans of the regular Sid Meier games who expect something like it in Starships aren't going to find it here. However, if  you take the game for what it is, a 4X lite game where you can jump in and finish a game in under a half-hour when you just want to jump in but don't want to play something that's going to suck you in for hours, it's quite satisfying.  It does have some downsides, the integration to Beyond Earth is kind of a throw away feature that seems like a a good idea never brought to fruition. In any case, I would still give this one ups if you want a "Sid Meier's Light" game in your collection you can play with a non-gamer cousin.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Overall, this is a good mobile game, 6/10 for PC. Unfortunately, it is not worth $15.00. I would pay maybe $5 for this.I'm just including the negatives, I had a good time play/learning but I don't think I'll be investing too much more time into this as it doesn't have the "Yes I've won" satisfaction of other strategy games I've played even though it has a really fun combat concept (execution was a bit off but you'll read why below). The "grand strategy" portion was very mobile-y which is okay since it never claimed to be anything more but a man can dream...What I didn't like:The game features only 8 leaders. The affinities from Beyond Earth are there but I didn't really notice a worthwhile impact of including them when it comes to gameplay.No tutorial, just "this how things do" page before the start of a game.Customizability of the ships is awesome but not reflected in gameplay (lack of clarity of weapons/shields, vision not really helpful).The wonders offer diverse spread of gameplay modifiers, however some are way more powerful than others and the planets determine what wonder is available so there is a luck factor involved (not bad, but annoying).Price scaling on techs/wonders didn't seem logical at all to me.In terms of combat gameplay, there are a few graphical glitches that were distracting but not hindering.No obvious tell of what weapon I would use in what situation, so I kinda just upgraded both (lasers and plasma cannons).Scanners and stealth didn't seem that relevant in combat unless the always active stealth wonder was owned.The lack of pre-battle deployment was the biggest negative of the combat. Sometimes my "carrier" type ship would be spawned on the frontlines with my "corvette" type ships in the back. Or the wonderful spawning of my destroyer with asteroids on 5 sides.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2016
												This game would be a poor effort at a stand-alone game.  Frankly, it's a pretty poor effort at a mini-game spinoff of a stand-alone spinoff of a good game (Beyond Earth and Civilization V, respectively).The real problem that I have with this game isn't the stripped-down options, the modest graphics, the periodically-uncotrollable game volume (I'm serious - have your hand on the volume when you win or you'll lose hearing), or the clunky and insipid AI.  No, none of these broke the game for me.  What broke the game is that when you capture an enemy capital you suddenly control the entire enemy empire.  Ta da!  It's like a game show bonus round worth more points than all of the previous game show rounds, making them a complete waste of time.HOWEVER, if you really enjoy Civilization: Beyond Earth, Starships does have some really neat unlockable content for that game.  The new goodies are two new maps and two new customization options each for starting ships, settler attributes, and cargo when you start a new Beyond Earth game.  That alone was kind of a consolation prize as I worked through the achievements for Starships.There's a catch, though.  These games, although running through Steam, do not track each other's achievements through steam and require a 2k account (free, linked on the title page of Starships and Beyond Earth) for the games to "talk to each other."  That is not at all clear and I only discovered it later as I tried to figure out how to get the Beyond Earth save achievement for Starships.  The achivements are not awarded retroactively - I had all of the Beyond Earth achievements before I linked the games through 2k and so had no unlockables for Starships.  Frustrating.Unless you're a fan of Beyond Earth, pass on this one.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Unless they vastly expand the content (for free), stay away from this one unless it's on sale for $5 or less.  It's got the depth of a tablet game, and a casual one at that, not a modern PC game.  You also can't change certain starting parameters like Victory Conditions for the AI, only yourself, so even the "huge" maps (which are actually very small) will only last a couple hours even if you're trying to draw out the game through a domination victory.The initial gameplay is actually quite fun, and the battles interesting, but you'll achieve everything possible within a couple hours at most and as soon as you realize that there's nothing new to discover about the game that initial excitement quickly fades.I squeezed 6.3 hours out of it and I'm not sure I'd play it again unless something changes.  Even for $15, that feels like a rip-off to me.

number of helpful: 18 of 28 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												I played for .9 hours. Im not being sarcastic but thats how long my game lasted. I accidentally went to war, won a battle or 2 but was not quick enough to pull a "suddent-death" population victory. It was that quick. Certainly not worth 14.99. I would have liked and expected something more indepth- social engineering, ship design options, a Federation-esque council, an interface that reflects my affinity, maybe even a full screen presentation. Yeah, the Civ series was never one to show awesome graphics in units. The tradition still carries on with Starships. The ship designs look more like sprites from an old 2000s or late 90s game. Eitherway, its not detrimental. Its just I would have expected to see more in that arena of a game with the title "Starships". Like other Civ games, opponents are placed way too close to me. Most interesting was that I was placed in a corner in Starships. Where is the buffer- the exapnse of space/planets that allow me some peaceful expansionturns? I know this is a civ simulator, war is going to happen but I always wonder why the AIs are spaced out but I am placed right nextdoor to an AI. Diplomacy and/or War Room screens, like BE, are paintings. Nice to look at but offer nothing in terms of universe immersion. I can overlook the short game, the bland UI or cartoony ship models. But I am tired of seeing paintings. Give me a reason to care about my people, show me videos for Wonders (What is the Dadaleus Ladder?), show me more background on the faction leaders- do something! Please! For 14.99 (on top of the original 50 for BE), I have Chessmaster X in Spaaaaace. As someone who loves to get engrossed in story (and hearing that the fiction for this universe is kept at Firaxis), this not something I am overly happy about. Perhaps its a bug or maybe its by design:At default, the game opened up in Windowed Mode. Going full screen still leaves the Windows Start and Task Bar visible.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												Sid Meier's Starships is a terrible port of a mobile game. To start off, the game's options are lackluster - there are basically none! When you select to fullscreen the game, it's fullscreen windowed and the taskbar is still shown. Also, there is no Quit Game button so you must hit escape of Alt+F4. The gameplay is very one dimensional, you have 1 fleet that goes around to different planets to accquire them by completing a mission. The missions are tedious as your ships have to slowly move around to destroy the enemies. There's almost no strategy involved and with no auto-complete option it's a chore. At the macro level, all you do is level up your planets and fleet - that's essentially the game in a nut shell so it's a very slimmed down version of any Civilization game.

number of helpful: 25 of 42 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												I started on an epic galaxy with six computer players.  One of them spawned on either side of me, and both of them took influence away from me on the first planet I visited and gained influence.  Then I took a mission where you had to escort a colony ship to a jump gate, and every move took 2 HP away from every ship.  There was no way to heal, and there were too many spaces between the ship and the gate for it to survive.I cannot believe how dumb this game is.  I was expecting a 4x game, like a Civilization in space.  Instead, I got an epic failure of a game.  I was very excited to play it, and now I'm completely turned off.  This all happened in about 10 minutes of gameplay.  I don't even want to give it another chance, because it's not even the right type of game.  It looks like a 4x, but wow does it fail.Also I want to add that the user interface blows.  I expected to be able to interact with and rotate planets when I was zoomed into them, but no.  However, you can slide the top of one of the lists up and down in a klunky, unnecessary and superfluous way.Sid Meier made one of the most brilliant games ever in Civilization.  He's cloned that model so many times now, that it seems he has forgotten what a fun game is.  He got money from me this time purely because of his name, but he won't again.  I'm bitterly disappointed.

Leaving it in windowed mode cuts off the bottom of the screen with the task bar, cannot read the bottom of the screen.  Even moving the taask bar does not help with this. I bought due to SM's reputation and becuase of the potential future connection to Beyond Earth without doing my research first.  Shame on me.  They really pulled a fast one on us.  Here's hoping I can help you from making a purchase you'll regret.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												This is a great game.  It has a connection with Sid Meier's Beyond Earth.  I've never played Beyond Earth.  I bought Starships because everything I read reminded me of the best parts of SM Railroads and Civ Revolution, in terms of presentation and style.  The play is split between tactical turn-based combat with a handful of ships and empire management.  All aspects of the game are simpler to carry out than in a full-fledged 4x game.  But this is not a 'casual game' any more than Advance Wars or Master of Orion were casual games.  The game has elements in common with both of those icons of pc gaming.  More on that later.  Shipbuilding is quick, easy, and elegant.  A simple table shows your ships and their abilities (of which there are eight or ten).  Just click on the box to upgrade X ability for Y ship.  It's one of those panels that could be dull and lifeless.  It isn't because the UI is friendly and well-made.  The combat is so streamlined and straightforward, I can look at those boxes and see in my mind the maneuvers and tactics I can pursue.Is combat too fast and easy?  I suppose it depends on difficulty level.  This is one of those games that wants you to not just win, but to win without getting hit.  To win with style.  You can destroy every enemy ship, but if all your own fleet goes limping back to the shipyard with gaping holes, you will fall behind the building curve.  I mentioned Advance Wars above, an very simple tactics game that involved zero luck in combat:  No such thing as a miss or a fumble, and no damage roll.  All the values are fixed.  Starships is like that.  Combat among the asteroids is a game of cat-and-mouse, and it's fun!  It's actual strategy.  When the enemy ship moves right up behind your ship with its plasma cannons, you know you're dead before the weapon animation plays.  Now, there are elements of luck - a warp point (teleportation square) could drop you exactly where you do (or don't) want to be; you could end your move near a cloaked ship and see it too late to do anything about it; a severe hit could cripple your engines.  Things like that.  But all attacks hit always, and with fixed damage, unless modifiers zero out the damage completely, such as firing through too many asteroid fields or from too far away.On the imperial side, the game's diplomacy and construction takes just the right amount of time.  Enough to engage you but not enough to drag you through tiresome clicks and endless notifications.  Strategic turns end when you grant the crew shore leave (almost like dividing the treasure in SM Pirates).  Empire management is quick and easy, and it all makes sense.  I feel compelled to repeat that:  It all makes sense.  No arbitrary or clumsy features at all.  And the possibilities are legion.  You can have a couple of uber ships or several lesser ones.  There is a lot to experiment with.  Empire and fleet mirror each other in a sense - each has to fit the other's strengths.  The other empire leaders and admirals have just enough artwork and personality to give you the sense that the galaxy is alive and populated.  Dialogue lasts just the right amount of time - not very long.  You can examine the shps you will be fighting, and you really should to avoid nasty surprises.Really, SM Starships is a computerized board game, just at the border of a full-blown pc strategy game but not going over the line.  It is clearly a game, not a sim of anything or an attempt to capture the whole universe in a gigabyte.Many games offer a thousand paths to victory, all of them dull.  It's hard to put a finger on what it is that makes a slew of possible strategy all sound appealing, but Starships succeeds in that, with bright colors and bright ideas.  I feel in charge of all my fleet and empire's doings, with no compromises just to make the game or the dev's  happy.  It's about me.  Or you.  SM Starships is good stuff.

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Its a bird? its a plane??? NO ITS... a bunch of space hippies in green ships planing on stealing my planets... darn... at first glance this game is something to be admired. It takes Civ BE, and expands the story into space and allows you to unite planets colonized by humanity during our exodus into the stars into your federation. So i thought "WOW COOL ITS LIKE CIV... BUT IN SPACE!!!" i was quickly given the idea of galactic Civ games, with a touch of that good old Sid meier's magic. and who wouldnt want some of that magic!?! Those damn space hippies thats who!Then i was hit with a game i can only describe as a briliant and stunning idea... that was hastily designed with the sole intent of making a quick buck based off the name brand...  this game would be perfect... if it were for Iphone IOS or the like. The only justice it does to the sid meiers name... is that it has the name "sid meiers" in the title. while visually decent, the animations for combat (I.E. explosions, weapon firing, movement, missiles and ship destruction and what not) are just... no... to call them bad is giving them too much credit. The voice acting for the combat senarios are just as bad. Every civ leader from BE who has been "expanded" in this game all share the same dialog with their predecessor. and the game just tosses you into the map with a horrible "tutorial" if it can even be called that, with an equally bad user interface... the tech tree is very strange at first, the way you gather resources and spend them was confusing, and from my very small amount of play time all i have seen are the same ships with different extentions on them, nothing different or new, just different shiny objects on your already similar body ship.it makes me sad writing this review... i want to give it a thumbs up... because i have never thought bad of any sid meiers game... I want to like this game... i really do... I am a huge fan of the sid meier's brand and absolutely loved Civ V and even BE, to an extent (personally i feel like they need to add more DLC's for BE creating religion and a united nations like body like the expansions for Civ V did), but this... this just made me a little sad. maybe in time with some patches and tender love and care, this game can truly blossom into something beautiful like it should have been. but it seems sid meiers has fallen into the "lets dish out as many "games" as we can and profit from them because our fans will pay anything for our "products"" pit just like ubisoft with Assassins creed, and the publishers for Call of duty. I hope this was just a test run for an idea, and that they will expand this game... or at least expand BE... because ive been waiting for that for a long time and it doesnt seem to be going anywhere. All i can say is that if you want to put forth the money for this, go ahead. Maybe you will enjoy it? and i hope you do because that is what i wanted for myself. however, as of now i have to say im truly dissapointed in this game in its current state. maybe in a month or two il come back and see a picture of what it should have been, and i will change it to a thumbs up... but for now i just see something that could have been the greatest thing ever, and fell so far short of its potential. like when god gave me a llama farm, and yet i cant ride one as my trusted steed to school. life can be so cruel at times :/

number of helpful: 36 of 65 people (55%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I think this best way to sum up this game would be to simply called it "pocket/mini sized strategy."Starships comes at a weird time Firaxis and 2K games.  Beyond Earth left many consumers wanting more and genuinely confused.  Why did they charge for a full price game that amounted to nothing more than an expansion pack for Civ 5?   SO what do they do?  They make a game even smaller in scale than BE and charge much less for it.  I assume the strategy now is: "the price should match the experience" and what you get with Starships pretty much feels like a $15 game.I'll get this out of the way immediately: this is a mobile game that happens to playable on the PC.  What does that mean?  Well, it means that a lot of the complexity of the Civ series is stripped out and the player is left to make spot decisions and map movement choices.  The interface was clearly designed for tablet touchscreen.  The buttons are in weird places and the menus/screens are stripped to the bar bones essentials.  That said, there is an enjoyable strategy game to be played here.  Let's take a moment to talk about it...The gameplay:Players familiar with Civ 5 will immediately recognize the hex grid format.  The player starts on the grid with a small fleet of starships and a planet.  Each "turn" basically boils down to this pattern:- Spend Resources on starships, planets and various upgrades- Move your war fleet to a new planet- Complete the mission on that planet (aka combat, more on this in a moment), thus gaining influence over that planet- MAYBE move again and do a new mission on a different planet- End Turn (aka Shore Leave)Let me touch on the combat scenarios (missions) on each planet:When the players arrives on a new planet that isn't already in their empire, the citizens of the planet will request help in the form of some type of starship mission.  This is where the real strategy of the game comes into play and the theme of "starships" really plays out.  Whatever war fleet the player has assembled is now used in a turn based mini strategy game.  It is important to note that SOMETIMES the mission doesn't use the player's war fleet but instead presents some type of puzzle.  But most (>70%) of the time the player must use his/her forces to defeat a squadron of NPC starships.The battle scenarios are most similar to "war" in Civ 5.  Each mission is played on its own hex map (separate from the overworld map) where the player manuevers their starships and fires various weapons to destroy the enemy NPCs.    Each starship is its own character on the map so if the player has five starships in their fleet, they now can battle with five ships on the combat map. This is defintely the BEST part of the game.  This is where all the time spent buying new ships and upgrading them pays off.  The player can choose to stay back and use long range weapons to try and get up close and personal with fighters or close range weapons.  If the player is successful, they "win" influence over the planet and eventually it folds into their empire.The players wins the entire game when they control most of the overworld map (or lose if they fail to do so).  I *think* its 70%. (Update: There are several victory conditions present but in my play time, so far, I have usually won by accidentally acquiriing 70% of the map.)  When playing on easy mode it is very easy.  Medium and Hard present much better challenges.The truth is that the game isn't very deep.  Upgrading planets and ships usually involves just buying everything.  There aren't really any penalties or drawbacks.  Even if the player concentrates on, for example, energy production, eventually it all evens out.  And that's where Starships is arguably very weak.  This is not a deep game.  The best part of the game is the combat and the starships.  Everything else is nothing much more than a big map the player simply uses to move and drive the game.I found the $15 is worth it.  The strategy of the starship combat is fun albeit not engaging.  The game does retain the "one more turn" type gameplay but that's where it ends.  The overall, 4x strategy simply isn't present.  Bottom line?  This is a $15 strategy game and I recommend it based on the starship combat.  If you want a bigger strategy, with more depth, look somewhere else.Final Score: C

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												From what I've seen of Sid Meiers Starships, I have to wonder why it wasn't just a DLC for Civ Beyond Earth. It's pretty basic.   In fact it feels like it was designed for the Commodore Amiga  30 years ago... If I had played this game 30 years ago I probably would have thought it was brilliant.It's missing many of the things that we take for granted in PC games, like fully adjustable graphics options and the ability to run in full screen.  The mouse controls are clumsy and you can't scroll by moving to the edge of the screen like in other Sid Meier games.At least if it had been a DLC it would have been able to use the in-game display settings of the base game.Sadly I cannot recommend this game. It's the first Sid Meier game that I'v ever been disappointed with...----A quick addition for people who think this game could never have been done as DLC:It wouldn't have been hard to get this to work as a DLC.The game may look different, but it uses the same basic engine (albeit greatly slimmed down). All they've really done is replace the flat terrain maps of Civ with a star field and planets and replaced the normal ground and water based units with space ships. It's basically CIv trying to give the impression of space when it's actually just a 2D hex based RTS like all the other games in the series. Basically the ships aren't flying through space, they're moving along an invisible ground plane, or the equivalent of, with a star background replacing the terrain we normally see. With all that in mind, it wouldn't have been all that difficult to add the maps, units and other features to the main game. There's nothing in Starships that couldn't have been accomplished in the base game. It could have been an add-on for the base game, and added new gameplay features, in the same way that The Sims add-ons often add in new features that weren't built into the base game, but expand upon the original game mechnics.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Overview:A decent turn-based strategy game that doesn't require days to play through. However, after about 4 hours, the fun is starting to wear off for me. There's more cons than pros for this game. I'm really on the fence about recommending this or simply saying skip it. On the one hand, it's fun for a few hours, on the other it gets repetative and isnt very immersive. I'll only recommend it if you want a change of pace and have the $15 to blow.Pros:Strategy-based gameplay is fun at first. You have to plan your moves around asteroids, debris fields, etc. You have to pay attention to which way your ship is facing, manage your weapons systems and keep track of enemy movements. Once you get past the initial learning curve (there's really no tutorial aside from some "advice" boxes) it's easy to play through. Upgrading your fleet and managing your systems is easy (perhaps too easy).Early on the game is challenging. Go into the wrong system and you might run into a fleet of carriers while you only have three cruisers. However, there is no shortage of "easier" battles to build up your fleet.Cons:It's repetative. After you expand your fleet and upgrade your ships, every battle becomes repetative and very one-sided (in the player's favor). I was pretty much destroying every fleet I encountered with little resistance (this was on the medium difficulty setting). I have a feeling regardless of the difficulty, once you reach a certain level of upgrades and fleet size, every battle turns into move ship, destroy enemy, repeat.System management. You can upgrade each planetary system by building cities, and resource generators (food, energy, etc) but again, as the game progresses it becomes unbalanced. Every time I won a battle, I had enough resources to pretty much build out each system with every module (food, energy, metal production). At that point there's no challenge to resource management.Enemy AI is not aggresive. I dont think I ever saw an enemy attack one of my systems. Again, this makes the whole game too easy and too one-sided. Since the AI never takes over my systems, I just continue to expand and build my fleet.Ship upgrades are confusing at first and too simplified. You basically increase the number of lasers, cannons, torpedoes and fighters. This isn't clear at first and I was left wondering if upgrading my weapons increased damage output or range or some other spec. Lasers or cannons are automatically chosen based on range - which I guess is ok but not very immservie. Increasing fighters gives you more fighter groups to launch. As you upgrade your ships, they also automatically change class (frigate, cruiser, battleship, etc.)Torpedoes are way overpowered. Put a torpedo in the right place and you can destroy any number of ships within the blast radius in one shot.Very little in the way of a tutorial. Some basic advice like "upgrade your fleet" or "research this technology". Aside from that, there are no real details on how weapons systems work, etc. Even the in game info section is lacking.

content:
Posted: January 25
												I initially didn't like this game. I thought, "This isn't CIV!" Well, that's right! But after a recent replay of it I really saw the appeal of it. It's a bit like a mix between Civ: Beyond Earth and Rome Total War. You control a single fleet that is your army and yet you still control your empire's planets, building cities and buildings that increase output. However, battle is centered around staged visits to planets and is a little more fast paced. It even uses the traditional board in a completely new way, in battle style reminicent of Master of Orion I & II for the DOS people out there. Anyways, I think it's best played after a playthrough of Beyond Earth and using that as your character for Starships, but that's just my preference.

												I can't speak for the game's content yet but as a PC port, it's pretty lousy.  There's an inexplicable 30 FPS lock in place unless you happen to have the in-game settings menu open, in which case it runs at 60.  ..but don't get your hopes up.  It looks like the game is simply running at double speed instead of a proper 60.  There also doesn't seem to be a way to play the game in fullscreen.  Not without the Windows taskbar being visable, anyway.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												A lot of people expect this to be some sort of Civ clone, when it frankly isn't, and shouldn't be treated like one. Starships is a small 4X game, which I guess you could say is like a Mini Stellaris. It takes 1 - 2 hours per game, but doesn't feel like a slog neither a really rushed experience. It is quite balanced in that matter.  It is a nice game to play if for example your internet is having a rough patch and you want something to pass the time thats quick, and isn't like a full blown game like Civ V is.There are obvious problems though. The first is a lack of workshop, dlc or any further updates to the game. What you buy is what you will forever play in Starships, which is a massive shame as it could really work.It also lacks a tutorial, but it is easy to pick up, graphics settings (though it is pretty lightweight) and biggest one: Multiplayer. Now for some this is fine, but they did miss a chance to build a decent multiplayer, that doesn't go on like Civ  ones to.In conclusion, I do reccomend this game. It is pretty fun to play, but does lack certain things. If you hate 4X/Turn Based Strategy Games, this isn't for you. But if you do, this may be a good pick up, but wait until a sale as the £11 price tag is a bit too big personally.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I am a fan of Sid Meier and FTL: Faster Than Light.I thought this game is a mixture of Beyond Earth and FTL and preordered it with this dream (actually I dreamt it would be a mixture of FTL and Master of Orion but I'm sure most of you don't know/remember the best 2 MoO games).Actually, well it is. But it's a lesson called "How you can ruin the mixture of these games".Honestly BE has many flaws but it's a fun game overall. The fun facts are; 3 tendencies have a meaning, the story is cool,  science means a lot, logistics mean a lot, and it's a challenging game.FTL on the other hand is a small budget, short game with bad graphics. The adventure concept and clever micro control (over crew, weapons and economy) are what make it shine.Now first off take FTL - substract choices. Substract micro control. Substract clever battles. Substract any interesting encounters you may follow. Add stupid, meaningless battles. You move from system to system as in FTL but all you do is to click yes and blow stuff up. Add huge amount of resources that breaks ship development.Secondly take BE. Substract any meaning of factions (bonus wise and storywise). Substract meaning of leaders. Substract challenge. Substract story. Substract science (there is science in this game but it's the same thing with ship development, nothing new comes out of science except "your shields work 25% better). Substract logistics - cities are only additional source of income, they don't mean anything at all.Imagine a Sid Meier game that anything, including tech, wonders and  buildings are done instantly with a single click - no planning is needed.Even worse, imagine a Sid Meier game that looks ugly. A Sid Meier game that wonders (or anything) you build has no visual, at all.But worst of all, imagine a Sid Meier game that shows no sign of intelligence (pun intended).I am sorry to say this but I have played better 1$ iOS games... There is absolutely nothing attractive about this game except the fact that you can literally rip your opponents apart in 3 hours in Normal mode (Not that it's a hard game but undetectable torpedos wonder break the game too bad).So, if you MUST try this out, wait until it gets 90% discount. It's not worth more.I kept the worst thing to the last: There are no aliens in this game.

number of helpful: 14 of 25 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												I waited over a month for this game after hearing that it would be released.  I was eager for it. As a fan of BSG and Mass Effect, I felt the idea of a nomadic fleet finding purchase on cooperative starsystems would be a unique experience.  After just an half-hour playing the game I can say it is a feeble attempt.  I expected more from Sid Meier.  This game is a shallow, flimsy attempt to expand on the Beyond Earth franchise.  The resource management is rudimentary. The story is nonexistent. The language is belittling (I feel it's condescending and dumbed down). There is ultimately no difference between choosing any of the affinities as the leaders all give the same rewards no matter which affinity one selects. This is a sad, sad iOS port to PC.  It's a vapid shell.   The starbattles are tactically childish.  I might have some challenge with the game if I were 10 years old and suffering from some kind of brain trauma.  Starships is a poor title as a few minutes of playing the game is sufficient to eliminate any exclamation the player might have expected.  Meier must have lent his name and his name only to this hunk of junk, but frankly, a man that I have idolized for years as a trend-setter and revolutionary designer has seriously let me down.  I would never have attached my name to such a trivial, casual game, not that casual games themselves are bad.  Just this one.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												This game has such a bad rep, because people see the name Sid Meier and assume 'Alpha Centauri 2!!!' You're wrong. It's a sci fi spinoff from Civilization: Beyond Earth.The galactic conquest and expansion side of the game plays in a similar fashion to the Civ games, albeit a very simplified version of Civ. The tech tree consists of 8 or 9 different fields of research, which can be upgraded from 0 to 8. Planets you conquer can have cities added to them, as well as a number of structures built to improve planetary resource income. These structures again go up to level 8, although there does not seem to be a limit on how many cities you can have.Each planet also has the possibility of being able to build a Wonder. Unlike the Civ games, these Wonders do not increase income or resources, but instead have a direct impact on your fleet.The fleet is the main part of the game. As with everything else, upgrading it is simple. There are a number of different options depending on what you want your ship to be good at, and the upgrades go up to level 8. You can also have up to 8 ships in your fleet.Space missions and encounters are the main part of the game. To bring new planets into your Empire, you need to do missions for them. They may limit you to a single ship for the mission, or you can take your entire fleet. Missions range from escape, to protect a colony ship, to defend from pirates, or capture an escaping fugitive.These missions take place in a fairly large area of space. The planet in question forms the centre of the map, and the mission takes place around it.  They are fun, easy to learn, and mistakes are rarely fatal (not at the normal difficulty levels anyways).One last touch I did like was when I was going for a domination victory. I defeated one race, leaving only two left on the map. Both of our Empires were pretty big, having split the galaxy almost down the middle. The next turn, I got a message from the NPC controlling the enemy faction, saying "There's just the two of us left. It's been nice having peace with you for all these years, but what do you say we now find out which of us has the best Empire?" Very friendly-like declaration of war. It's not about the conflict. It's about the honour.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												10/10  Yes, that's right ney-sayers, I repeat 10/10.  [Notice that I have a fair number of games, but I don't write a lot of reviews and almost all of those are negative.]I noticed a consistency when I read the other reviews for this game.  The players who tried it more than 10 hours recommend it, the others don't.  And why not, because it isn't Civ V, plain and simple and they went into it ready to not like it and bash it.I don't understand what people don't like about this game.  It is not Civ V, so what?  Who cares?  It is a totally different game, and exactly what the devs said it would be (not Civ V, so get over your selves, you whiny bytches).  And guess what?  It is brilliant.  Let me repeat that, it is brilliant!  It is easy to get into, quick to understand, quick to play, and down right fun.  It brings back memories of the first Masters of Orion (MOO).  Really.  Seriously.  Try it, you will like it.It is a very simple 4x game, but it is not Civ V, which is a much more complex, detailed-oriented, resource managing, city and army building, click-fest, that in my opinion was fun for one play through, but then... who has time?  So it beats me why they want to compare the two and then be bummed out it isn't the same? This is a simple, straightforward, fun game with nice UI controls, nice graphics, no bugs, etc.  You have a fleet, you move it to planets, you fight various types of battles, you win the hearts and minds of the local planetarians, they join your Federation, and you move on to the next system rinse and repeat until all of the free systems are taken.  Then you duke it out with the other expanding empires.  Once you conquer a planet, you build cities and upgrades on your planet (each system only has one planet, so again, it is very easy and fast to manage your planets).  You build wonders.  You invest in research (a very simple science tree of maybe 10-12 categories which increase your ship powers.  You can buy and sell a few commodities like science, metal, fuel, and food, all of which are needed though to build cities, ships, upgrades, etc.Building ships is the fantastic part.  It is dead simple.  You use metal to add points to your defenses (hull and shields), engine, weapons, hangers, tubes, sensors and stealth, and that is about it.  You can upgrade your ships to super dreadnaughts, or create lots of smaller ships to swarm the enemy.  You can add fighter bays and launch fighters.  You can add long range lazer weapons or short range kenetic weapons that do a lot of damage up close.  You can also add torpedo tubes.  At first I didn't like them, now they are my go-to weapon.  I sit back and launch spreads of torpedos, watch them run, and then manually detonate them when they get into range of enemy ships (if you aimed accurately).  I built 4 battleships that were well rounded and I was able to conquest a medium-sized galaxy in a couple of hours on easy mode.  You can too!  Try it today (or at least the next time it is on sale).  For $15 it is worth is straight up, but on sale, it is a no brainer.  Good luck, have fun!  My tip to the biginner, start with the ruler who gives you 3 ships, not 2.  ;-)Sid, guess what, I like this "lite 4x" version more than your big fancy games, lol.  You knocked this one out of the park.  What a joy to play.  I am going back in now to play a bigger, harder universe, now that I know the basics.  =)   10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5
												If you're expecting an In-depth game of intrigue, war and complex resource management, prepare to be disappointed. This game is diet Sid Meier’s.  It has the resources you expect from playing Beyond Earth and even ties into the game nicely giving you the ability to continue your political chess match into the stars after you have conquered the land. All the Alliances and wars you had follow you.  I think that’s cool.  Just don’t expect the same amount of subtly and finesse in this game as there was in Beyond Earth.  This game is almost casual in its approach to strategy.  Each time you go to a planet you are given a scenario and if you complete it, you get a reward and you gain some influence over that world.  Do enough for them or just loiter around long enough and they will join your team. GO TEAM! There is research but it’s purchased with points.  There are buildings but they are also just purchased with points.  You can grow your colonies on the planets you control but… you guessed it. Purchased with points.  There is strategy involved but it takes no patience or time to play this game, especially on easy.  One thing that I do find annoying is that there is no load function in game.  You can save all day long but you have to exit to the main menu to load.  But that’s just a minor inconvenience, really.  The main reason this is an issue is that, like all of Sid Meier’s games, this one can be quit unforgiving especially in the beginning.  If you don’t make the right decisions earlier on, prepare to be left behind by the AI and hopelessly out gunned.All in all though, this game is a decent time sink and easy to pick up if nothing else.  It can be a little unforgiving but it’s easily to lean and if you manage to spawn in a good location, you can beat this game in an evening then play a new game as someone else tomorrow.
