content:
Posted: April 9
												This is a tough game to boil down to a simple Yes/No recommendation.  It's not full Civ.  I wouldn't even call it Civ Light.  So what is it?  Imagine you took all of the hexes that weren't cities out of a Civ map. Then convert those cities to planets and change the background from surface map to a star field.  Now, eliminate all of the units from the map except for one.  On your turn you may move this one unit (which is actually composed of multiple starships) from the planet it is on to an adjacent planet for a "crew exhaustion" cost. Once it arrives you will engage in one of a handful of templated battles: destroy the enemy fleet, survive for 5 turns, escort a ship to a warp point, prevent an enemy ship from reaching a warp point, capture the resource point, and so on.  You'll see exactly what you are running up against in the mission preparation screen.  When you succeed in the mission you will receive between 1-4 "influence" with that planet.  Once you've reach a full 4 influence, the planet aligns with you and becomes part of your empire.  You'll typically have enough "exhaustion points" to engage in at least two missions per turn.  The missions themselves are turned based tactical battles.  You can upgrade your existing starships with features like torpedoes, improved long range lasers, short range weapons, deployable fighter ships, stealth cloaking, and more.  The more features you load on a ship the slower it gets, so you'll also be pumping points into your engines to keep your range up.  You'll eventually want to purchase additional ships, but don't go overboard because not every mission will allow you to bring your full fleet.  Once the mission begins you'll find yourself on a new hex field cluttered with planets and asteroids that block movement and weapons, "Narrow Passages" are gaps that toggle open and shut between some asteroid sections. There are also warp fields randomly littered around the mission area, and random is truly the word because if you move into one you will be warped to the location of another random warp field.  This can be really frustrating, as you have no control over where you come out, and you can sometimes step on one when not paying attention to your ships pathing.  Each ship will have a set number of movement points and may take one action per turn, whether that is firing a torpedo (which is a special type of timed weapon), shooting directly at an enemy, engaging a cloaking field, or detecting cloaked ships.  Battles quickly become repetitious as you maneuver behind a ship, fire, and move away.  Planets you have influence with you may modify.  You can add more cities to improve their population and production. You may build improvements which increase production of certain commodities: science, energy, metal, and so on.  Planets within your empire can have Wonders constructed which provide unique advantages.This probably sounds very similar to Civ, and it is.  However, in Civ, especially on harder difficulty levels, you can easily improve a city into weakness.  You have to carefully balance your improvements, purchases, science, and so on.  In Starships you would need to make an effort to build your way into weakness.  On the contrary, the game seems built to provide unbalanced advantages to you.  Unlike Civ where you can only reach higher tiers on tech tree after fulfilling a set number of base technologies, in Starships you are free to Min/Max the techs.  Want to quickly annihlate your opponents? Spend all of your science points on upgrading torpedos and outfit your ships with multiple torpedos.  Each mission will be a breeze.You declare victory in the game in one of four ways: Population (over 50% of the total galactic population is yours), Domination (last player standing), Science (have three Lvl 6 techs), and Wonder (control 9 wonders).  Population is definitely the easiest of the conditions to meet.  Once you win, you're done.  There is no "Just one more turn" option.Starships lacks the depth of a full Civ game, intentionally so.  So where does this game fit in your game library? Steam often has sales for Civ V that discount the game to $5, so I can't recommend Starships at full price with a straight face. On sale for a few bucks, though, and Starships might have a niche spot.  You can play a campaign in just a few hours without spending too much thought on it. Have a long conference call that you need to be on? Starships in the background would be a fine distraction.  It doesn't replace full Civ, but it also won't keep you up until the wee hours of the morning.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Review as a standalone game:Let's be honest here, it's probably not worth the $15 (or about $20 AUS, as the exchange rate goes). The combat is kinda fun, and the simplistic universal overview is easy to pick up. That's about as far as it goes. It is reminscent of other tactical space-combat games like Star Wars: Empire at War. Despite space being 3D, your ships can only move in 2D. The objectives are always some variation of "destroy target, get ship from A to B, or survive for x turns". Ship combat is sometimes satisfying, but otherwise plain and unoriginal.Empire expansion has no real downside. You have a number of different resources which are used for different things. Energy customises your fleet, food lets you expand the population of a planet, etc. You gain resources at the start of every turn. You only have 1 fleet, and it's actions are limited by "morale". Morale is one of the only limiting factors in the game; once you're out of morale, your fleet cannot take any more actions this turn. Morale is consumed by moving or by instigating combat, and is fully replenished each turn. Lower morale makes your crew less effective in combat. Empire expansion is done planet by planet, and there is no downside to expanding your empire.The key interesting feature of Starships is the fleet customisation. Ship classes are solely dependent on what customisations they are given, and every ship is 100% customisable witht the same base stats. You can experiment with what works and what doesn't, and come up with some interesting combinations. Ship size is dependent on it's maximum HP. For all intents and purposes, there is no cosmetic customisation options. What your ship looks like is determined by what your starting affinity is, and the stats you give your ship. I've enjoyed making different roles for my ships, from slower and tankier carrriers to fast, hard-hitting stealth assassins.All in all, there are some interesting elements, but nothing that hasn't been done better in other games. If you're looking for a tactical space game, buy it when it's at least 50% off.---------------The other review:Sid Meier's Starships is, for all intents and purposes, an overpriced standalone DLC for Beyond Earth. It's main purpose is to unlock content in BE, and likewise BE can unlock extra content for Starships.It's an interesting take on an expanded BE game, and people who enjoy roleplay and immersion might enjoy continuing games of BE in Starships (yes, you can do this). The unlockable content for BE might even be worth it.If you're looking for a breath of fresh air for BE, you might want to look into this game (treating it as a DLC). However, I would recommend getting it at a discount.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												Overall, it's a good game.  But I do wonder if this is a pet project under one of Sid Meier's proteges. Strategy and negotiation are bit limited for space faring races battling for domination. While it is a good idea to keep the screen readout in a technical/tactical format, the graphics leave a few things to be desired.  They're not bad, but for a Sid Meier's project, I expected more time and effort and definitely smoother eye candy.  I like the idea of controlling planet economies with food, metal, science, energy but I couldn't tell if I had a true effect nor how to make an effect.  The only way to distinguish yourself is choosing Superiority, Harmony or Purity.  But even then, I couldn't see any true benefit other than changing the character's profile or ship designs.IMHO:  It doesn't engage the player to want to be a part of any side in particular.  Again, I couldn't see any advantages or disadvantages to choosing a particular affinity.  Perhaps what's missing here is more to the Beyond Earth story? Bottom line:  This is certainly worth a look if you're into the strategy/space/sci-fi/turn based strategy sort of thing.  Consider waiting for a special offer.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
Sid Meier's Starships is a game wherein you use ships that travel between planets (and presumably stars) on a map to do missions where you shoot lasers and torpedoes and other spacenaval things at other craft that ply the space trails. There's also some lightweight empire management in the shape of upgrading planets and making your ships shootier/faster/have invisible torpedoes, but 90% of your gametime is going to consist of: going to a planet, kicking in the teeth of anyone who looks at you funny, repeat until there are no more people who need to be kicked this turn.It's definitely not a very complex space game—it's an iOS port, what were you expecting?—but it's pretty fun as a hex-based Battlefleet Gothic. Without firing arcs or the accursed cannon table. Or much inter-faction variation. But it''s got the torpedoes! By god does it have torpedoes.Good: Lightweight, Hexagonal Space Combat!Bad: May not be crunchy enough for the embittled space grognard.Reccomended for: People looking to ease themselvesinto the inky void of space, People who play Civ:BE and want Ultrasonic Emitters[civilization.wikia.com]

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												A simple game where you use a single fleet of ships to conquor the universe. If your looking for a long, well thought out game where you masterfully plot galatic conquest through a combination of diplomacy, military strength and technological superiority you'll have to go elsewhere. If your looking for a simple strategy game that offers more than one path to success and can be finsihed in less than 6 hours this might be for you.One of the things I like most about this game is the multiple upgrade paths for the ships. Every weapon has its strength and is a valid path to take to victory. Both focused and broad upgrade paths are viable. Wonders can make a strategy go from good to overwhelming. Which path you choose to follow can be heavily influenced by the worlds you have access to. All in all, it is very much a "light" version of civilization. What it lacks in depth and polish it makes up for in easy of play.I haven't played the hardest settings in the game yet, but one definate flaw is the enemy AI. The AI is fairly simple and after a while mostly predictable. It does occasionally do something I wouldn't predict but generally how it moves is perdictable. Also there is a wonder to allow you to move first, but I find that I'd rather go second most of the time as enemy ships usually start behind cover and their first move exposes them.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												So I've played this game a few times now and I have a love-hate relationship with it.Things I love:1. It's relatively easy to learn how to play2. The controls are straight forward3. It's a quest like, planet upgrade system based, sci-fi starship combat game4. You can customise your ships with a range of weapons and/or defenses5. Turn-based tactical combatThings I hate:1. Ship upgrades have absolutely the bare minimum of information attached to them.  Want to know how much damage an extra point of "lasers" will do on your ship - sorry, that's just too much information for you to handle, so no.  Want to know how much damage a point of shields can handle - "you want to know the truth? well you can't handle the truth!"Shield upgrade information says "damaged shields regenerate each turn", but during combat you have no idea what the strengths of the shields are or  by how much they've been damaged.The truth is that there is about as much information on things like shield strength and weapon strengths that they may as well have said that this weapon upgrade will improve your firepower by three bananas and a pineapple and that would still have been more information than you're currently given!2. The tech tree is very simplistic, and every time you buy a tech, every other tech goes up in cost - there's of course no information that this is going to happen or by how much, because information is a dangerous thing in the wrong hands!3. Ship combat - well, suffice to say that I have found the path to victory is fighters - upgrade them to the max and equip a couple of fighters on each ship - by tech level 6, they're deadly and you can literally spam them out in sufficient quantities to overwhelm your foes without ever really risking your capital ships to any damage.  Of course YMMV...4. Wonders...they range from meh to OMGWTFBBQ!  And the great/sad news is they all cost similar amounts.  So if you're lucky enough to get the "two actions" wonder early on - congrats, you've probably just won the space race!5. The diplomatic options are so underwhelming, it's like some kids from kindergarden got together to try and form the UN and then realised that politics is just way too complicated for them and decided to go back to just playing cops & robbers.6. No multiplayer options :(Overall I rate this game about 6 out of 10 for the style more than the substance.  If you're looking for something deep, this isn't the game for you.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2015
 A neat, small-scale gameSid Meier's Starships is a simple, quick, fun little strategy game. Don't go into this game expecting a 40-hour campaign and hours of careful planning, because that's not what this game is made for.Starships feels and plays like a very casual game-in fact, everything from the UI to the simplistic controls and systems screams that this game was built for a tablet or phone rather than a full blown PC. This isn't exactly a bad thing as the UI is clean and easy to navigate, with oversized text and icons.Combat is on a 2d hex grid, with various objects(asteroids, planets, etc.) either blocking vision and fire, or reducing the damage dealt when firing through them. Positioning, shields, and weapon types all factor in as well, giving just enough depth to combat to keep it from getting too stale.There's not really any alien species, just different flavors of humans. All the ships have similar looks and feel, though you can upgrade their weapons and systems in anyway you want, which is neat. I'd have liked more variety but what you get is servicable.You can only have one 'fleet' on the campaign map though, which is a bit annoying.Really my biggest gripe with this game is in the achievements, as you need Beyond Earth (or at least a save game from it) to perfect it. Final Verdict:Decent buy, especially on sale. Scratches that strategy itch without needing 40+ free hours.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
												I was excited for this game after I saw a Quick Look video for it on Giantbomb[www.giantbomb.com]. This game looked, to me, like XCOM, but in space!And it is. Sort of. When you're in combat, anyway, and most of the time you will be. Your starships exchange fire with enemies while darting in-between asteroids and moons, effectively using them as directional "cover". Space, it seems, is simply packed with asteroids (which I will admit is a little unrealistic), but nevertheless these debris-strewn starfields provide you with dynamic (and occasionally, changing) battlefields to fight upon.Aside from that, combat mechanics themselves are quite simple. Mostly you will be attacking enemy vessels, and there are four ways to do it: With lasers (long range), plasma cannons (short range), torpedoes (area-of-effect), and fighter jets. For defense and utility, you have cloaking devices and sensor sweeps. That's it! These six mechanics provide the primary functions of your ships. While this may be too simplistic for some, they nevertheless provide enough complexity to allow for emergent tactics.The only other way to change how your ships work is to build "wonders" for your civilization, and each one will grant your fleet additional powers. Usually this is fun, as the powers are interesting and vary widely, but unfortunately, it is entirely random as to which planets can build each type, and if a civilization gets lucky and acquires the best wonders early on, you will find that they have a distinct advantage over everyone else.I was a little disappointed that there weren't any customization options for the starships. Your ships will change shape when you add new modules to them, but there are no purely cosmetic options whatsoever (like paint jobs, etc). While that should be a minor gripe, it can actually become problematic when you are fighting against enemies that have ships that look almost identical to yours, and this happens a lot because there are only three types of ship construction, and a proper game has eight players.The other main thing you do in this game, aside from fighting battles and building your ships, is manage your colonies. This part of the game is reasonably fun, but it mostly just boils down to looking at menus and spending your accumulated resources. There isn't a lot of depth here, and it seems to just serve as a bookend to the combat missions.The diplomacy system isn't all that deep, either. Aside from declaring war and making peace, there isn't much else you can do - there are no trade agreements, no cease-fires or non-aggression pacts, really no minutae to speak of. This area of the game is sorely lacking, and in some ways does not even feel finished.Which leads me to my next point. Polish! This game sorely needs it! I found plenty of spelling errors in the text, and the clunky animations in combat (particularly when ships explode) left something to be desired. It almost feels like the game was released too early, or perhaps the project was prematurely abandoned.There's also a marked lack of features. For instance, there is no multiplayer! Why? This game would be a lot of fun against a friend, but instead you're stuck playing against the lackluster AI.On that note, I think I should mention that this game is REALLY, REALLY EASY. Even on "impossible" difficulty, I found the game to be ridiculously easy regardless of the chosen win condition. The enemies are simply too easy to outsmart. Occasionally they will even take stupid actions on their own, like firing a torpedo point-blank into a planet or moon, causing area-of-effect damage to themselves and their allies. The AI seriously needs work in order to feel complete.Finally, this game is short. You're looking at only a few hours per playthrough, even with eight players and an "epic" sized galaxy. Certain win conditions can extend it, but the basic win conditions of "all" or "population" victories will end in extremely short order. This is not necessarily a bad thing, but it means that this game is a more casual experience than you may be used to, especially if you're a Civilization fan.I know what you're thinking. I've trashed the game quite a bit, so why am I recommending it? The answer is simple. It's fun. The combat is solid and the empire-building is too, even if it's a little on the simplistic side. It's a great game to play when you've got a few hours spare and, perhaps, don't want to commit to starting a huge, long game of Civilization or Beyond Earth.I enjoyed this game, and I hope it will continue to receive support and updates so it can become the great game that it should be. For now, though, all I can say is that it's worth the money - If you get it on sale.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Civilization in space this is not but what it is a great wee game. There's not a lot of nuance to the game but then, I think, that's the best time. It allows you to pick up and play without spending lots of hours figuring out research trees or particular bonuses. Sure each planet has a wonder you can build and a resource they'll produce more of but, if I'm honest, you don't need to pay that too much attention. The battles are the fun part and whilst the maps in which they take place are a bit repetitive they're fun, engaging and the part of the game I look forward to the most.In the end Starships is a game for a quick session. If you set the difficulty level down you can thrash out a game in around an hour or so and moving up the scale, obviously, makes things harder. Either way if you're expecting some kind of 4X competitor to the likes of Sins of a Solar Empire you'll be disappointed. However approach this as a game to just have fun with and you'll have a ball.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												8.5/10Overview: I recommend this game because it has a surprising amount of strategic and tactical depth yet is simple to pick up. Steam's returns policy makes it well-worth trying out and returning if you don't like it. I am not a huge 4X fan; but I enjoy Starships because while it provides a light introduction to the genre it also, IMO, provides a satisfying degree of strategy at the map level and tactics at the system levels of the game. Some people don't like the game because they claim it lacks depth, but I believe they haven't tried to play on tough enough difficulty levels. One of the things I've noticed about several 4X games is that there are a lot of turns where you don't do anything, you simply press the End Turn button and let things develop. There is NONE of that in Starships; every move and action count.The game requires you to balance your ship capabilities with your play style. Do you like to use lasers at long distance? Or do you build ships and armor and Plasma cannons to mix it up in close? Fighters and Torpedoes can be cannon fodder and simple barriers to your opponents movement or, properly built, can be decisive scouts and salvo weapons that can devastate your enemies. The hex grid at the system combat level makes it look like a board game, but that is a refreshing change IMO.Balancing resources appears simple, but at higher difficulty, you have to build the right improvements on the proper planets to get maximum resource benefits. You should also connect your planets with Warp Nexus' to allow movement with no morale point penalties. Strategically, you can assault your opponent's planets to take Wonders away or deprive them of resources; or you can drive accross their empire, cutting off their fleet and allowing you to defeat the AI in detail.In all, this is a simple introduction to the 4X genre, and on the Mac, where options are a bit limited, it is a good start.

												Soooo, helllo guys first,Let´s begin with the Bad things of this game,  at first you need to know that in my knowledge of the Cid Meier´s Series I found this game realy to short, in Sid Meier´s Civ. 5, and Beyond Earth u had the possibility to play only 1 savegame for hours and hours, researching Techs, Exploring the world, Trade, make war and also things, and now you have Sid Meier´s Starships, you start with your little fleet on your home planet, and you fly from one planet to another, doing some missions for the other Civilizations/People on the planet becoing their friends, some one declare war to another , and then it End. My first game ended after 90 Game minutes, 90 ! Just because one Bot controled 51% of the Map, i found this extremly short, my first Civ 5 campain took me 3 days (with breaks don´t be afraid), i found this REALLY shortly for a Sd Meier´s Serie Game, so thats the first "bad" point the duration.Secondly I found it kinda bad that you can just and only have 1 Fleet with Max 8 ships, I mean their are pretty strong at the end, but it makes the battle during some very long  time witch is borring at all because the ennemy just make himself Invisible, and ten you can have some fun for Catching him !For the fleet i guess that it would be kinda usefull to be able to make a second and third one, so, 1 for Missions , 1 for Defence or something like that, or i also dont like that if 1 of your ship get destroyed in battle, that after it it "comes"  back to your fleet and just need reparations, i mean it´s usefull at the begining when u only got 2 ships, but at the end, i had to fight and take like 10 planets and all the ships (mine and the one of the bot) were all max level, and it was very boring at all to do 10 times the exactly the same thing .!Another Bad point which i guess is gonna be the last one, is the THAT THERE IS NO MULTIPLAYER !!!! content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												I waited to buy this game when it was on sale because of the mixed reviews but I was pleasantly surprized at how much fun the game is.  There is depth to this game in many key areas.  While not MOO, Masters of Orion, it manages to create its own niche in this genre.  What I really like is how you can customize each ship, even within the same class.  For example you can have 2 corvettes, one a long range attacker and another a carrier.  There are many more options available to you.  Also planetary upgrading is fun and important strategically as well as tactically.  There is a lot to be said for this game that is positive.  But suffice to say, that you should not wait for it to go in the bargain basement to get it.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												If you liked Civ 5, and if you loved Civ: Beyond Earth, then get ready! This game will likely dissapoint!Seriously, if you're gaming on a Windows Surface, you may find this a good time waster for $15. But if you, like me, are on a real PC and interested in a fun 4X experience, then know that this game greatly fails to live up to the Sid Meier name. It is repetative, essentially relying on a singular game mechanic where you pilot a single type of ship through about 5 puzzles. There is a maze, a capture and control, a hunt, etc. The ship types are naught, you get a ship that has a largely linear upgrade path. While I could have plenty of fun on the bus with my tablet, on my PC this game feels like solitaire plus. A let down. Now, while this doesn't cost as much as a landmark game it still could have more flavor. The civilizations feels like different theme colors, and the technologies and cash have a more passive feel than I'd like.

												I would recommend this game whole-heartedly, with the caveat that this is NOT a full 4X game.Rather it's a diet 4X game for when you want those warm fuzzy feelings that come from seeing your empire expand and grow, without all the time and setup of a full 4X session.What is the main attraction of this game is the Starships (it's in the title). Firaxis, would it have killed you to take a day or so to fix that?

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												So... new Sid Meier game and as usual I was first out of the gate. Like many reviewers before me have said - I really wanted to love this game. It combines the world of Civilization with more sci-fi elements and what could be wrong with that? Well, sad to say just about everything. The game is built around "mini-missions", but they hardly ever change from escort, seek and destroy and survival. You have a game world comprised of star systems! Use them! The replayability, a mainstay in Sid Meier games (hey, I have almost 1 100 hours of Civ 5 on record... and that's just single player), is just not there. And for the price of 15 friggin Euros I expect a lot, lot more. The only Sid Meier Civilization themed game to date I can not recommend. I feel ripped off.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I never learn.I told myself after Civ: Beyond Earth that I wasn't going to pre-order any more of Sid Meier's games, that I was going to wait and see how they were recieved first and then make an informed decision. But the lure of Firaxis is not so easily resisted.Sadly, in this case it should've been. The sirens have once again lured us all onto the rocks.Now, full disclosure, I am writing this review with less than an hour of play time on this game under my belt. It honestly doesn't take all that long to get a feel for the game, I'm afraid. The entire thing was obviously designed for the mobile platform release first, and then reverse-engineered for the PC relese as an afterthought. It was bad enough when this was being done with console games...The interface is a joke. The game starts off windowed, has no graphical settings to change other than setting it to "full-windowed" (And when IN "full-windowed" mode has no way to exit the game other than reverting to windowed mode or alt-f4... seriously, there is no "exit game" option on the menu.), and everything inside of the game was designed with a touchscreen in mind. And then there's the gameplay...If you ever wanted a "simplified" version of a civ game, this is it. Tech tree? Nope. There's a set list of technologies, and you just level them up from one to six. If you get three of them to six, then you win a Science victory. Because you're smart. But what about unlocking buildings? Nope, there are set buildings ("Improvements") that you can make on planets. You build them, you upgrade them, they make more of resources as they're upgraded. You can build Wonders, if you stockpile a ton of Metal over a lot of turns, and then if you have enough of those you can win. You can win by standard Domination, but if you're playing against the AI be prepared for it to be its standard cheating self-- don't bother using cloaking devices. It will go straight for your position every single time even though it supposedly can't see you. (...why no, I'm not bitter.)Planets have cities, cities produce metal, food, energy, science. You spend science to research tech. You spend metal to build improvements. You spend food to build new cities. You spend energy to build and upgrade ships. And... that's it. Everything else is going from planet to planet and fulfilling "missions" with your ships.Oh, and they even managed to put one more annoying mobile thing in-- a limited amount of stamina! Yes, your fleet has a "morale" limit. It goes down each time you do missions, or travel. When it goes down, your crew becomes less effective. This keeps you from taking your potentially awesome ships of awesomeness from mission to mission, getting every planet to join your federation, all in the same turn.Oh, wait, it's not really a turn. You don't hit "end turn", you hit "shore leave" in order to end your turn. It refills your morale. That's not made entirely clear, but that's what it does.There's more I could bring up, but really I think you get the gist of it by this point. This is not a game worth spending $14.99 on. This is a mobile device time-waster that should be on an app store for $5 or so.I suppose we can at least be glad that they didn't put the name "Civilization" anywhere near it.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												It's a decent game with simple ways to win or lose.Pros:+Map Environments change with each battle.+Strength of you and your opponent can depend on many factors.+Each leader has a certain bonus to them and a more advanced portrait in their Affinities.+Missions can constantly change on one world outside of borders and not on Pirate and Maurauder homeworlds.+Each planet has it's own special category of populace and can boost certain things.+You can be heavily outnumbered and still pull a victory.Cons:-Even if you set only one winning setup, the game will still accept the rest from other empires.-I feel like diplomacy is half baked or still in a doughy form.-Idk how or why empires of different affinities can come together, makes little sense.Overall it's pretty good, it's meant to be a short little side game after Beyond Earth.It's got the quality, but it has a few unwanted and confusing perks in it.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
												This is the worst game to bears Sid Meier's name."Surely it's not that bad" You say.I'm afraid it is.In the build up to the release of the game there was little doubt that it was going to be a less involved game to play then the typical Sid Meier fare, more Ace Patrol then Civilization 5. When developers were discussing the game, that was pretty clear and I have no qualms with that.In fact I was quite happy with the idea of a strategy game designed so I could play over an evening after work.Initial impressions are poor. The game launching in a tiny window and into a bare, personality-less main menu that could have been ripped from any sci-fi title (it reminded me of the Sword of the Stars 2 menu). I sought out the settings menu and within that I found volume controls and "Windowed Full Screen mode".I'm sorry what?I know the game was being made for tablet as well, but this is Firaxis. I asked another friend playing it "Am I missing a settings menu somewhere?" bemusedly. "Nope" He replied "It really is that sparse"Oh well. Not a great first impression, but not necessarily the end of the world. I setup a game.Setup lets you pick a faction and a leader. Each faction gets the same leaders, with slightly rejigged artwork. Which comes across as a bit lazy. The factions have a unique bonus with the leaders adding an additional bonus of their own. I was a little bemused at what the various bonuses meant as I only knew about one aspect of the game (crew morale) from previews nothing else made a lot of sense and there was nothing to explain the benefits of a choice, no tooltips, nothing. The lack of tooltips persists throughout, with a general lack of accessible information.I setup my game, stabbing blindly in the dark at things that sounded useful The galactic playing field looks alright and I wait for the useful tutorial to kick in and explain things to me over my first few turns. I get nothing. I understand there's an info button to click but I don't understand why there's a lack of tutorial and I fumble around the first few turns getting to grips with the games systems.As the game is all about moving a fleet around space bringing disparate planets into a federation you'd expect load out/designing of the ships to be one of the most involved aspects of the game. Instead, you're presented with a list of things to click away at to upgrade or downgrade (removing components nets you some resources back to spend elsewhere) different aspects of each ship.My fleet consisted of three ships throughout the course of the game, starting as corvette's, ending as battleships through upgrades and the games automatic ship classification. All 3 focused on speed, one was paticularly tough and loaded with close range weaponry. One was less tough, also had close range weaponry and could cloak. One had longer range weapons. The limitation to what you can actually do with ships meant all of them had max speed, and were stupidly tough by about mid way through. But this simple setup felt game breaking. I could defeat any mission or enemy fleet, outside of the missions where you have to defend an outpost that can only survive two hits with fast enemies that just head straight for it.The empire building aspect of the game is no more involved. "Click this to make numbers go up, because numbers" about sums up this aspect of the game. There's no interesting trade off between balancing metal, food or energy. Get lots of whatever you can, click stuff to have more stuff.I actually beat my game accidentally. I was working my way from planet to planet, building one ludcriously over powered wonder after another because why not, then a conquered a planet which also had a wonder and triggered the wonder victory.Well victory nets you a much more rewarding end then it does in Beyond Earth at least. You get 10 seconds of video which is better then a text box. But does it really matter when the rest of the game is so unengaging?Overall, it's an ok game to have on a tablet, nothing stand out, even where there isn't much competition. But on the PC there's tons. Weird Worlds in Infinite space did something similar but better years ago and it's Early Access sequel likely will to. There is no reason to buy this game for the PC, and very little for a tablet.BTW - SOMEBODY ELSE WROTE THIS REVIEW, BUT IT SUMS UP THE GAME FOR ME

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												EDIT: As of today there are 41 PAGES of technical issues about this game. The issues thread was set up by a 2K moderator so that the community could help each other but there is no official developer presence on the Steam forums. When I mentioned that it would help us if 2K would at least give us a word about a possible patch I was told quite tersely that 2K devs do not READ the Steam forums.I have profound respect for Sid Meier, but, that said, if the developers are not being made aware of 41 pages of crash issues about this game and we are told that we should submit a support ticket to 2K, then what is the purpose of the issues thread? Indie developers have a much better sense of customer satisfaction and 2K/Firaxis could learn a LOT from them.--------------The game plays well for some but there are some things prospective buyers need to know. There is a thread in the Community Hub for this game that is of this writing 33 pages of posts most reporting that this game will not launch or else it crashes after the logo splash screen. A minority - including myself - are reporting severe memory leaks. The game IS a lot of fun AS LONG AS YOU ARE NOT EXPECTING A 4X. This game is a tactical game reminiscent of Amarillo Design Bureau's classic Star Fleet Battles but obviously due to licensing is not set in th Star Trek universe.Most people cannot launch the game, some of us CAN play it but is suffers a severe memory leak, others have had to adjust their mouse polliung or disable certain features in theor sound cards. To be fair, some folks aren't experiencing any issues at all.Buyer beware. The game has been out for 12 days as of this edit and no patch or hint of a patch is fortcoming.

												Imagine Civilization Beyond Earth as a tablet game about spaceships, and you have this.It's not bad, it's just shallow and lacking in areas that make a Civ game so good. Normally I would spend hourson this but... it's too simple. I understand the 'simple to get hard to master mechanic', but here its simply ' easy to get, moderately annoying to understand'.The leaders are not animated in any way, there are very very few voice files, so expect to hear the same things on repeat.The combat is an extension of Civ V's system aplied to spaceships, and not much else, some battlefield obstacles mixed in perhaps.I'm glad they only charged £11 for it, because this isn't worth £15, let alone a full game.If you take it as a concept mini-game, it's great. As a standalone, you'll be done in a couple hours, easy.

												At first impression the game itself is not bad, a streamlined space 4x that shares Beyond Earth setting. Altough it's not a mobile port and the PC UI works fine, the simple nature of the gameplay makes it more appeling for Pads. This does not influence the gameplay in anyway, and you can also hide the taskbar to have a complete fullscreen. I wouldn't destroy the product for this, i saw other Fireaxis launches way more crappy.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												As with all things, what you think about this game is really down to expectation management. I've read alot of the negative reviews and they focus on how they were expecting the game to be different in various ways. More or less related to Beyond Earth, more like a full game, more polished etc... For my part I purposefully didn't learn alot about the game, I have enough faith in Firaxis to get their products without copious research, X-COM and Civ being the standup gems that they are. For my ignorance I was rewarded with a surprisingly enjoyable experience. The game isn't deep but it has emergent complexities in play. It isn't as customisable or strategic as Civ but that's what Civ is for, this is something different. In a way it brings the fresher innovations in game play some of us hoped Beyond Earth might bring. If you wanted something different you can't help but be dissapointed, and I get that, but I guess my advice is to be open minded, go in with a clear head and experience the game for what it is, an interesting little adventure that won't require the hundreds of hours to master that Civ does. If you're interested I'm doing a Let's Play on youtube: https://youtu.be/_ggv6so0sGk?list=UUVAUBrmofKasUbNIm0E2ktw Check out what the game is like!

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												I think a lot of the negative reviews of this game may be due to people expecting a MoO/Civ hybrid, which this game certainly isn't.  However, it is still an excellent game in its own right, much faster moving and with better depth than Sid's Pirates, which is also a game I enjoyed.This game is really quite reminiscent of a tabletop miniatures game combined with an extensive campaign system.  There really are three parts to the game:  resource development, resource allocation, and tactical starship combat.  The first two are accomplished during those times when you grant your crew "shore leave" -- a fancier way of pressing the standard Civ turn button -- and watching the enemy players go through their turns.  You have to upgrade planets, develop galactic wonders, repair damaged ships, conduct diplomacy, and research newer and higher levels of technological advancement.  At any point during or after this process, you can send your fleet into combat by attacking another system.This, to me, is the most engaging part of the game.  The tactical combat has a distinctly tabletop feel.  If you've ever played Starmada, Full Thrust, Star Fleet Battles, Battlefleet Gothic, etc., this will be very comfortable territory for you.  The tactical play is straightforward but engaging, with you maneuvering your ships through asteroid fields and around planets trying to both find a clear shot while trying to hide your ships from return fire by using those same obstacles to your advantage.  The maps with asteroids aren't static, either;  the asteroids float about between turns, so you are constantly having to keep an eye on how the tactical situation is changing.  The graphics are absolutely stunning.There are only three weapon types -- a short-range plasma gun, long-range laser, and slow but extremely powerful torpedoes (which can often kill a large ship in one shot).  I find that to be a little disappointing, as I think it would be great fun to design your own weapon systems, as can be done in Starmada.  Still, it gives enough variety to require you to think carefully and plan ahead as to how you will upgrade, employ, and protect your ships based on your resources and intended style of play (charge in, stand off and snipe, torpedo volleys...?).A few other things I wish were different:-- You can only have one fleet.  I'm not sure why this is, as I would far prefer the more realistic model of having fleets assigned to various sectors to reduce reaction times or enable pincer strategies and whatnot.-- It's easy, if you don't stay up on diplomacy and allow the AI players to gang up on you, to become quickly overwhelmed, as your planets are captured faster than you can recover and repair your fleet between combats.-- The diplomacy options could use some fleshing out, and I would love to see some espionage incorporated in the game.Overall, I'd give it a 7.5 out of 10 on my own ludicrously non-scientific grading scale.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												Basically Civ Lite - you have only one unit available, but the unit is vastly customisable and upgradable - becoming very powerful.  The unit is used in missions, which give influence with the various planets you visit; and when 4 points of influence are accrued, the planet in question will join your federation, giving you access to all it's resources.There are several ways to win the game:  domination, population (controlling 51% of the population of the galaxy), science, wonder (building 6 wonders).  You can choose to have them all available, or just one.There are a good number of leaders available, each with different skills, and with three different versions of each leader to choose from, allowing yet more customisation.Despite all this the game feels a little unfinished and clunky, and is frankly in need of a decent tutorial level - as it can be a little confusing to start with.  There's also no real warning when the AI's about to win, which would be nice - so something could be done about it, like in Civ 5.All in all, I'd give this game 7/10 as once you get to grips with things it's a fun game.  I'd like it to be longer, but you can't have everything.  I consider it worth the money.  Took me about 25 hours to complete it on the hardest difficulty, which made it about 50p an hour.

												To some people it is a good game, and to others it is a bad one.I, myself, find that it is a rather good game to spend a couple of hours on battling your way though astroids and fleets of starships launching torpedos and scrambling fighters.I think I find this game entertaining mainly because of the battles. In most, if not all, of my Civilization games I end up being the passive diplomat whether in history or Beyond Earth but because of focus on battles and fighting in this game I can enjoy the otherside of conquest that I fail to meet under the white dove or neutrality.However the game does come with a few flaws to those expecting a huge 'triple-A' title. Each game is short and missons do get repetative if you replay each game on the same difficulty. I believe there are a few minor bugs in the diplomacy and which leaders relaliate too who owns what planet (which is not fully governed by a single 'Empire')However if you are looking for a quick Hex-based spaceship battle game you are in luck!Otherwise just give this one a pass; There is no reason to moan at the developers for creating a game that some people like and some people just want to cry about like two year olds with tantrums.

												I wish I knew what I was getting before I actually paid for this.  I have played Sid Meier's games off and on over the years, but this is one that is truly sorry in execution, playability, development, everything.  First experience:I played what was defaulted small,Easy, 4 AI, All victory conditions.  The game lasted about five minutes with it laughing in my face saying: going through the tutorial noob...  oh wait there is no tutorial, or any of the sort of helpfulness to get into the game.  I gave it another go: Epic map, conquest...  my bad, I mean domination.  I had thought I had to mean conquer your enemies and all their territory...  Nope.  Just take over 42% +/- of the map.  this includes waiting for your galactic neighbors to become nice and ripe and take over their homeworld and all their space becomes yours...  and the A.I. knows this too...  and is horribly imbalanced.  An AI corvette can kill an AI battleship no sweat.  Which by the way, it should take a bit more work to conquer an enemy homeworld or enemy space.  Sure striking their homeworld could hit their moral, but an AI shouldn't just up and give up all their space at the loss of their home planet.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I have read a number of reviews that have already been posted here.  I understand why there's a lot of mixed feelings about the game, that's to be expected when you slap Sid Meier's name on something.  Many came expecting a deeper game, albiet not as deep as a full-on Civ.  Others came expecting more choices and options.  My main gripe is the lack of the everpresent tooltips we've come to rely on in other Sid Meier games.That said...this game is awesome.  If you're looking for a quick, fun, tired-as-hell-after-work-all-day game, this is it.  Games can be a fast 2-3 hrs, or you can drag it out on very hard difficulties for a nice weekender puzzle.I'd have liked more fleet management complexity.  For example the automatic ship class upgrades.  I'd have preferred to have a choice of hulls and paid more or less to have bigger or larger hulls.  Smaller hulls having a maximum upgrade level or some such.  I'd have liked being able to split my fleet into 2 or more fleets, especially as controlled space got larger and harder to defend.  The diplomacy is a little weird.  I tried to figure out how to form an alliance with someone, and there's....nothing.  It just somehow *happened* anyway as the game went on.  I found myself at war with an empire I'd only just discovered, and there was no way to end it diplomatically.  I had to just waltz in and annihilate them to get it over with.Research is almost pointless.  Even with getting tech as fast as I could via research points, I had only a couple techs to level 2 (of 8?) by the end of the game.  Grab what techs you want/can, and move on.  Your fleet's upgrades are much more important.Also, once you've collected a few specific combinations of wonders, your fleet becomes virtually invincible.  I had extra actions, auto-stealth, and a couple others that made my shields invulnerable to lasers and torpedos...toss up a fighter screen in the first turn, and the enemy will NEVER see your ships, and waste themselves on your massive fighter screen. All-in-all a good game, but there are places where they clearly oversimplified it.  It could have been more complex and engaging and still been a hit for PC as well as tablets.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
First things first, this is a 90% positive review! I loved it!A damn good little game...As a huge fan of the Ace Patrol games, Starships was right up my alley. Quick, brutal, and lightweight, it hits all the right notes for hex based combat with none of the clutter, something far too few developers seem capable of. What it lacks in the aerial flourish of Ace Patrol's dogfights, it makes up for with strategic depth, provided by the galactic map on which the player completes missions, sways planetary systems under his or her influence, and chooses either war or peace (war, let's be honest) with his or her neighbors. All of that, though, is contained in an easy to learn, easy to come back to little package of simple game mechanics we all know and love.Still, some things feel missing...The game promises modular shipbuilding and doesn't really deliver. What you get is a simple fleet of ships (of which you can only have one) with a handful of stats to be individually raised. Ship look is determined entirely by your choice of the Harmony/Purity/Supremacy triad of Beyond Earth. As stats are raised, the relevant modules on the ship will beef up and become more characteristic. That's pretty much it for modularity. I played around with specialization of particular ships (destroyers, carriers, etc), but as long as the empire is stable and able to produce resources, all your ships will end up a little same-y.Additionally, the lack of any kind of story or scenario mode isn't glaring, but it would be welcome. Ace Patrol had real wars to draw from, granted, but this sets up like a Civ game without being as deep or engaging in the long term. Even just more control over the rules or map generation would go a long way.Why it's for you...->You've been itching to play a lightweight hex based game->You played both Ace Patrols instead of doing real work until you ran out of game->Starships are coolWhy it's NOT for you...->You're looking for another 4X->You'd like to spend the next 10 hours glued to your desk chair->You, for some reason, think starships are not cool. You'd be wrong, weirdo.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												After playing an half of an hour, I can say that - at the current stage - it's not worth buying.A lot of serious issues on the PC version. There is already a guide available how to bypass/workaround the most issues, but some of this won't work for me. For example:1. Borderless FullscreenThe game offers a borderless fullscreen mode to play. When you activate it, you still have your Windows taskbar visible. You can workaround this issue by using the tool "Borderless Gaming". This really works good.2. Not able to save the gameIn some circumstances you won't be able to save the game: special character in steam user name, not running in admin mode, running the wrong executable (i.e. 32bit on 64bit). Most of this is not working for me. I really don't want to change my user name to be able to save in a game. That is weird. They should be able to fix this, other games (also Beyond Earth) works fine with saving. Also in Steam Cloud, so why?3. Game is crashing in the introThe workaround described in the link below is not working for me. I need to just bypass the intro by clicking left mouse. If you forget to click, game over.For me it seems the game had absolutely no testing at all. That would explain the price. My recommendation is currently to wait for a major patch that addresses the most issues. If you still decide to buy this game, then make yourself aware of the workarounds:http://segmentnext.com/2015/03/13/sid-meiers-starships-errors-bugs-crashes-full-screen-save-game-and-fixes/I will update this review once a patch is available and the game would maybe playable for me. Currently it's not because saving is not working for me.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Kyu's Review for this game, Sid Meier's Starships:Me:  I play way too many games, almost all the time.  I grew up on RPGs and turn based strategies, but I would play everything given the time and money.  That being said, I mostly stick to strategy, rpgs, fps, arcade, rhythm, ccgs, lcgs, board games, fighting games, etcI am going to tell you how I boiled the game down, and win relatively easily.  I don't have a sample size of 100 games, but I am 3 for 3 on easy, moderate, and hard, with max players, small and epic sizes, all 3 affinities, etc.  Impossible is the only mode i have yet to touch.#1 strat:  Fighters.  The names may not be exact, but here is what you need:Dual Command Wonder -- allows ships to perform 2 actions per turn (but cannot Fire twice)Hyperlauncher Wonder -- allows your fighters full movement when launchedUpgrade as you normally would, engines, armor, shields, primary weapon.  Get more ships, 5 or 6 is a good strong fleet.  Then, get 2 or more fighters on every ship.Here is why 1 starfight is not good --> If you turn is to move ships up, and launch a fighter from each, opponent can move up, and destroy them easily.  So nothing is gained, your fighters are dead, effectively a waste of your energy on that upgrade, right?However, with the Dual Command Wonder, you can launch two fighters.  So even if half of them are destroyed, you are now up the other half on the enemy. If you have 4 fighters per ship, you can do that again next turn.  The Swarm is an achievement, and its a very real thing.  Make sure to science upgrade fighters 2 or 3 times for the random modules on them.  Even on hard, I had Fighters that could take 2 or 3 hits from enemy ships.  You can also use the Hyperlaunch to get a full move out of the fighters, and hit them, before they are destroyed, even if you dont have the dual command wonder.  Dual Command Wonder also applies to your Fighters, though all they can do is double impulse, or fire+impulse.The rest of "how to win" is upgrade sensibly from the bottom up, find the cheapest thing, upgrade it first.  Get the most for your money.  BE SURE to get every planet a WARP NEXUS.  This will allow you to be able to protect all of your planets from any of your other planets.  You will be able to move between them without crew exhaustion.A note on torpedoes, use them to Zone the enemy fleet.  You can see where they will be in 2 turns, so aim for places you dont want the AI to move into.  If they do, boom they die, if they dont, fine they are in worse position and you get to move in.  Just watch out for their torpedoes, especially if they have stealth torpedo wonder.So what will happen is, you do your turn, the AI does theirs, and if you have a strong fleet of Fighters and Warp Nexus upgardes everywhere, you can defend everything successfully, taking little to no fleet damage, meaning you dont need to repair or worry about attrition from battle to battle.  New turn, go dominate someone.  Survive the counterattack, and this continues until you finally win.I will say that on Hard, the AI fleets were better upgraded significantly.  They are more dangerous early on, so be a little wary.All in all, a 1 thing beats all strategy means its not good gameplay balance.  But... its just comp stomp i guess.  So nobody can be too mad.  For $15 you will get your value out of it, but it doesn't offer any super great planning or depth of thought.  I was hoping there would be more to it, I thought you would be making separate fleets, possibly an actual tech tree, so on.  I don't hate what is there, I just think it could have been a little better.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												Sadly this is a large let down to the Sid Meier's IP. Where I was expecting and pre ordered what I thought to be a new type of Beyond Earth with the possiblity of a Horde mode or defence in classic Civilizations fashion, I got what would be good for an IOS or Andriod game. I beat the game within 2 hours on the hardest difficulty. It blended the Battles of Xcom with a hybrid and to be honest really crappy version of Civilization managment into one whole hot mess. While the battles were fun, they were incredibly easy and unsatisfying for a long lasting Civilization fan like myself. For a few dollars this game would be worth it, but sadly that would be charging a high price for it. The 22$ I paid for the pre order was a complete rip off. Overall I cannot recommend this game to nearly anyone, with the exception being the few games who only have an hour or so to spare every once in a while or those who have very low end PCs.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Horrible game is horribly brokenI am rather dissapointed with this game. It is a nice idea but poorly implemented. Feels much more like a prerelease than a fully finished game from Sid - and I have been a great admirer of his for many decades!Easy enough to pick up and play - the game comes without any kind of guide or tutorial.Many achievements are not working - despite fullfilling described conditions, they do not activate.Graphics could be a little more interesting. There are only 3 ship graphs for the player. Upgrading your ships does not change them in any way - only in their description.The different starting characters and affinities do not really make the game play vastly different.It is rather difficult to determine during missions where and when what ship will be able to move and shoot, which takes away greatly from tactical play and makes it too much about brawn rather than brain.Missions while interesting almost always come down to the same boring tactics, which when mastered leave nothing to the imagination.The calculations of success of missions are way off.Diplomatic Negotiations are rather bizzare and often end up with player unable to tell what was concluded or how to improve matters.Play in Starships button in Beyond Earth while present is permentantly greyed out. A lot of the achievements don't work....Makes one wonder - what sort of testing went on before this pre-alpha was pumped out on Steam as a "finished result".End result - I just hope Modders have enough to work with here so that they can turn this title into what it ought to have been!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												A leap forward ? Or a step backwards ?When I think of Sid Meier Games, I think of complexity, good balancing,  time investment. If I think about the first day I saw Starships announced, I was very enthusiastic about a space game made by the creators of Civilization. I couldn't wait until the day it comes out on Steam, checking every day the time left.And then the time came, and I made the leap of faith to buy it and play it. What happened next not only puzzled me, it saddened me quite a bit. The first time I launch a new game I always check the options menu to set up my audio and video settings. This time I couldn't find ANY graphic options and I started thinking of Starships like I would an unfinished/unpolished game. It felt like an Alpha version of a future game.Nevertheless, I still wanted to see the game mechanics and what was in this game content wise.A couple of clicks and choices later I was in a brand new universe managing a planet and 2 starships. 5 hours later and a few restarts I already finished the game on domination and I slapped my face because of the lack of a challenge behind the game. I'm not even inclined to open it another time for another game. :(If you are looking for a quick, skirmish like, march of war style, starship game, this is the game for you, if not, don't bother.My packet thoughts :- over simplified options (every option included ! actions/buildings/research/ship modules/wonders/even the EPIC galaxy is tiny)- very stupid AI (shoot 5 torpedoes towards them and they will turn tail and run)- few research options and too easy to reach- lvl 8 capacity on every ship module (WHAT?!)- 8 maximum ships in a fleet !- only 1 FLEET !- very weak graphicsI hope with all my heart this is not a finished game. It had potential and it was a very, very, very bad failure!Overall feeling for a PC game : 8 year old mentalityI think this game is much more suited for tablets or phones. Even those are more complex..... did you know they developed MMORPG's on tablets?!?!?!??Please tell me your going to make massive changes to this game !

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												I feel cheated by this title. Anyone expecting a rich, rewarding, deep Civ game is going to be as disappointed as I was. This is a mobile game at best- not a great one either. The tech system is BS, no new trechnologies, just levels in existing ones, The ship upgrade system is BS, you don't get to design the layout of your ship, you just increase stats and the model changes slightly. The city building is BS, again it's just increasing stats with little to no progression. Missions are BS, they're either obscenely difficult or iunsultingly easy with no means to gauge just how hard they are. Not tried out the interface with Civ: Beyond Earth and I'm not sure I can be bothered attempting it. This game made me sad. It made me feel like I'd been conned. 3/10, Avoid. There are better examples of games like this for less money. Come on Sid, we know you can do better than this.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												My review of this is simple. Thsi is the description for the game. Taken from right here in this window:Build and command a fleet of starships and travel between planets as you explore, build, negotiate, and fight to preserve your vision for humanity.1.) Yes, technically you have to click a button that makes the ships get "built". There is 0, zero, nada, zilch, NOTHING that you do to influence this process otherwise. You, the monkey, click the button.2.) travel between planets, welll DUHHHHHHHH! it is a space game. That is ALL you do half the game. 3.) Explore? No, the maps are the size of ... well let me give you an analogy: If space were the size of say the Pacific Ocean than this game is the size of a drop of coffee spilled on the table this morning.4.) Build - You already said build dipwads and saying it more wont make it any less of a disappointment.5.) Negotiate.... ummm are you friggin kidding me. The "diplomacy" function in this game is about as in depth as a teenager's world view. Let's break down the options: I like you/I hate you - Let's fight/let's hug.6.) Fight... HOORAY! finally something that is actually in the game. This game is about the tactics and only the tactics. It is only a $5 game being sold for $10 extra due to having Sid Meier's name on it. But as a $5 dollar game it is decent. It is mindless fun at smashing ships.7.) And at last we come to "...preserve your vision of humanity" Yeah, if you were blind.Buy it on sale but do not expect it to be anything.

The AI in my opionion was good,trying to setup the opposition was not easy and that added to the stategy, all to many games can be won because they are predictable. SMS was not predictable, and was fun. The only con is interaction with so called other planetey leaders is almost commical in the interaction, there are little to no real options for the interaction when compared to other SM games.I give it a 8 outta 10.  Fun and nice game play and good graphics and sound.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												I don't know what's going on at Firaxis, but their last two games have really been duds. I love TB Strategy games, and Firaxis was always my go-to for quality, fun TBS games. However, between Beyond Earth and now Starships, I'm beginning to wonder if the devs at Firaxis have thrown in the towel. Even at $15, Starships is woefully inadequate, especially with Sid Meier's name on it. The macro-planetary conquest game requires no thought or strategy to win and the tactical combat micro game requires onlly slight strategic thought - very slight. I can't help but feel there is only 1/2 a game here. It's a surprising shame this game came from such a great studio. I hope this and BE are not indications of where Firaxis is headed in the long run.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												Lots of people are panning this game for failing to live up to their desires of an epic level strategy 4X game. Lots of people are forgetting that this game is $15 base and even less on sales and never advertised itself as an epic level 4X strategy game. This game is exactly what it's advertised and priced as: a space ADVENTURE game where you command a small fleet in exploring the frontier, putting down pirates, engaging in tense standoffs or small scale battles with the other players, establishing trade aggreements, and bringing planets into your Federation/Empire/whatever, all through episodic missions with light storytelling. Think Star Trek Next Gen with an emphasis on combat.If you're cool with that, great! Get this game! It's fun and worth your bit of money. And if you want a more vast, epic, and detailed game, please, PLEASE, don't buy this $15 game and then come back to leave scathing, raging reviews because it wasn't the $60 game you were looking for.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												It is a fun game set in Beyond Earth universe.I enjoyed it and would recommend to anyone who liked the setting (or enjoys flying around in a star fleet of stealth bombers :D).---+Easy to learn!+Awesome ship/fleet builder. Do you create a hulking flagship, or a swarm of smaller ships? Speed vs armor? Drones? Torpedoes? Stealth? Fun choices.+Engaging tactical battles. Always nice choice whether to create an ambush, flank the enemy or charge head-on. Different missions have varied objectives and modifiers that can affect the randomly-generated battlefield.+Wonders. They can be the cornerstone on which you build your entire battle tactic.----Lack of depth. It's a lite game and is nowhere near Beyond Earth - let alone Civs - in terms of depth of its mechanics. -As result of above, the replayability will be lower than in BE/Civ.-UI could use some improvement.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												This game is quite interesting for the first few run throughs, but it totally lacks the addictive elements of Civ5 and Beyond Earth. The graphics and interface are much more basic than I was expecting, and not in a good way. It's not particularly challenging, even on the higher difficulty settings, there's not really much scope for changing your strategy, and the fact that you can't continue the game once another player has achieved a victory, the way you can in Civ5, is really irritating. Could be a good game but it feels much more like one made specifically for tablets or even smartphones than for PC gamers, or possibly a beta for a much bigger and more immersive game. Not really worth the cost.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												The game is very simple. It took me about 1 minute to get the basics down, learned a few new things along the way, and ultimately cruised to victory on the moderate difficulty level.Having said that... I had fun. I felt that there wasn't much depth to some elements, namely resources and tech. The diplomacy is minimal and wasn't worth pursuing in my playthrough. The combat was enjoyable and the missions seemed varied enough. The wonders work better than you'd expect, though are so expensive that many aren't worth getting.Great game if you've got a few hours to spare. I'd definitely recommend picking it up on your tablet for plane/car trips.Not so great if you're hoping to burn the midnight oil in a long, detailed game similar to Civ.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Sid Meier’s Starships - for people who like star ships and turn based combat with the faintest smattering of light strategy on top. It was designed for PC and iPad and consequently it’s low in price, complexity, graphical fidelity and currently has some strange omissions in terms of PC controls. The main course of this game is boldly going with your fleet to wage turn based tactical combat in a variety of different missions. Succeed and you’ll eventually convince each planet to join your Empire. Through the wonder of a my2k account victory in Starships and progress in Civilization Beyond Earth will also unlock some cool rewards in both games.The combat is a lot of fun and if you like laser beams and torpedoes this game will scratch that Captain Kirk itch. It’s a fun game that will satisfy you in brief short bursts but it lacks the complexity for long term engagement.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												This is not Civilization, Or Galactic Civilizato, Or Masters of Orion.You are an admiral. You lead your ships, run missions, earn influence of the worlds you visit.The emphasis is tactical. Expect to spend a lot of time on a battlemap. Lasers are long range but planets block them and asteroids can block them or reduce damage. (There are a LOT of asteroids on a map!)Plasma weapons do more damge but are shorter range.Torpedoes are area affect and can pass through asteroids. Great for flushing quarry from a spot thats too good.You also have fighters, stealth systems, shields...You will build wonders, improvements and the like, but as I said, the emphasis is tactical or these elements are lighter fare.The game can be small and played quickly. The hardest victory conditions on the biggest map is about a six hour affair on easy level.A lot of people complain about the small window but playing full screen is trivial. There is a fullscreen button you can click in the menues...you can also simply maximize the window.A lot of people want a longer game...I recommend if you feel that way you play a "Population" victory, or "Domination" if you want an even longer game.In the end there is not as much here as there is in Civ or Beyond Earth. Then again, look at the price tag...On a 1 to 10 I give it an 8.2It's entertaining.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Just finished my first game (on normal), so these are all initial impressions:Much like the Civilization ports for iOS, Starships is linear and short. I actually stumbled into a Wonder Victory while stomping through the galaxy to little resistance -- a domination victory probably wasn't that far off. I'll definitely have to increase the difficulty level in my next try.I didn't find much use for researching tech other than the ambiguous notion that it's helping me somehow. There's little context to tech developments like Artificial Intelligence (what does it mean for fighters to have a 'random module'?). It seems, though, like once I got fighters, the only thing I really needed to focus on was making sure that my starships had too much HP to be taken down. And there's absolutely no use to diplomacy other than to use it as a war on/off switch. You won't find the modifiers that you're used to in the Civ franchise, no helptext around why someone is angry/happy with you other than the general assumption that the closer you are to their border the less likely they are to want to be your friend, and maybe I'm an idiot but I didn't see anywhere where you could trade goods. Also, I found the fact that the other leaders were willing to give up all sorts of information about their empire (like how many ships they have, what their upgrades are, etc.), even in a peace treaty setting, a little weird, especially since war can be ignited as easy as clicking a button (there's no penalty for breaking a peace treaty, near as I've found). Though, I have to say that it's not like I had a bad time. The game seems fun enough for $15. I guess I haven't had a chance to experience the AI at a higher level, so maybe I'll feel like there's more strategic depth to the game once I do that. I mean, it's $15. Obviously not a fully fledged game. It's a time waster, so look at it through that lens before you pull the trigger.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												     While I recomend Starships, I also give fair warning. This is NOT something you would expect from a Sid Meier's game. I do enjoy playing it, but I also see the short playability of it. Other games from Sid Meier's I can waste many days worth of hours playing. However, after playing this for only a handful of hours, it is already becoming a bit stale.      The technical and tutorial issues expressed in other reviews are (as of this writing) are true and in many ways annoying. They do not greatly effect the overall experience though. That is, to me, probably the saddest part of the whole thing. The game is so shallow that even though there are some fairly glaring issues, they do not greatly affect the game. Were they all fixed this instant, it would hardly be noticable in the end. For example, the victory conditions only affecting the player and not the AI. It cuts the game a bit short unexpectedly, but the game play for the most part would be the same.      So yes I recomend Starships as it is. The price was reflective of its small stature of a game so it was worth it in my opinion. Try to suspend your disbelief in reguards to its being a Sid Meier's game, or try your best to completely forget it. If you can do either of those thigs you should be fine. Otherwise I suggest seeking professional help from either a psychologist or your local micro brewery.      It is at this point I would like to direct my words at Sid Meier and Faraxis ... please, oh please, redo this game in the grand history and style of every other Sid Meier's game made. It has potential and good ideas backing it in story and hope. Please do those things justice and meet the high bar you set for yourselves. Price it as you did Beyond Earth and Civ 5 and if it be as they are in grand stature and bredth, I would happily give my coin in trade.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Nowhere in the title of this game does it say "Civilization" anywhere.With that said, Sid Meier's Starships is a solid enough game in its own right. You can dive into a game fairly quickly, and you'll pick up on what ship and planet upgrades work for you as you move through your first game.Combat is simple, quick, and aggressive. Most engagements throw you into the fray or require you to act quickly to complete your objective.There's not much more than peace or war for negotiations in Starships. You can usually aim for the opponent's home world to capture their empire in one go, which makes the game rather easy at some points.I personally don't see how people thought this game would be a full on Civilization game at a $15 pricepoint. If you're looking for a game to tie you over for a few hours at a time, then this might be what you're looking for. If you're looking for a $15 Civ game then you're obviously on the wrong page because this isn't even an entry in the Civ franchise. Wait for Civ 5 to go on sale or what have you.Overall, it's a solid game that makes for a good couple of hours of play, much like Faster Than Light.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Light but fun, it is easy to pick up and play.   While it works somewhat like civilization games, it is very light on the management aspect of it, and instead focuses on tactics.  I believe people have come to expect a bit too much out of games, especially at this price.  For $15 out of the gate, I think this is priced fairly.  It is not as refined as other Civilization games, or Beyond Earth, but it is an enjoyable addition to the series.  I can't say I was disappointed.  I enjoyed it much more than Beyond Earth, to be honest.  Also, you should not expect some epic civilization building marathon game, because this is not it.  Games are done relatively fast.  Or maybe time just passes by quickly.  Either way, I think it is worth the price

												Sid Meier's Starships, I don't even know where to begin. It's a great game. It really is. Although the beginning was a little rough to understand the concept of the game, and how to play it correctly but you'll eventually get the hang of it. Also when they say "Turn based", they mean every AI unit has its own turns. I'm really confused too. The story is about traveling the stars to find our lost brothers, yet when you play the game it's the same leaders from Sid Meier's Civilization Beyond Earth. I can personally say it is a great game, happening I am a HUGE Sid Meier's fan. Although I am going to recommend his game to those who like a good Sid Meier's game.
