content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												First things first, I really wish when they released this game they had released it without Sid Meiers name as this seems to be where alot of the negative reviews are based around. Looking at the game from Steam it SEEMS to be a giant 4X like Civilisation or Beyond Earth in space, however this is misleading. In no way is starships in the same league as the Civ series and while it may share the same 'universe' as Beyond Earth i dont believe it is in the same league as it either. Sid's name comes with expectations form the community that this game simply does not fill. However, if you look at this game independantly without his name attached it isnt a bad game. More importantly this game at $15 is still cheaper then a movie ticket.My advice, stick it on your wishlist and wait for the summer sale next year. Pick this up at a discount and give it a try while its not the best buy on Steam its not the worst either

content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												Starships is a nice little game, but don't expect the same amount of game-play as in the Civ titles. This game is more sort of an arcade type of game. You have to move fast but smart in order to gain control of as big a chunk of the galaxy as possible, before the other factions have you completely surrounded and the only possibility for expansion is war. This is not a game with hours on hours of micromanaging your planets, establishing interstellar trade routes and high level politics. It's about using your highly customisable star fleet to turn other planets to your side, either by assisting these planets, or by conquering them. A normal play through is about 2-3 hours, and you can easily have the game running while you're doing something else.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												It is a fun game set in Beyond Earth universe.I enjoyed it and would recommend to anyone who liked the setting (or enjoys flying around in a star fleet of stealth bombers :D).---+Easy to learn!+Awesome ship/fleet builder. Do you create a hulking flagship, or a swarm of smaller ships? Speed vs armor? Drones? Torpedoes? Stealth? Fun choices.+Engaging tactical battles. Always nice choice whether to create an ambush, flank the enemy or charge head-on. Different missions have varied objectives and modifiers that can affect the randomly-generated battlefield.+Wonders. They can be the cornerstone on which you build your entire battle tactic.----Lack of depth. It's a lite game and is nowhere near Beyond Earth - let alone Civs - in terms of depth of its mechanics. -As result of above, the replayability will be lower than in BE/Civ.-UI could use some improvement.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												This game is quite interesting for the first few run throughs, but it totally lacks the addictive elements of Civ5 and Beyond Earth. The graphics and interface are much more basic than I was expecting, and not in a good way. It's not particularly challenging, even on the higher difficulty settings, there's not really much scope for changing your strategy, and the fact that you can't continue the game once another player has achieved a victory, the way you can in Civ5, is really irritating. Could be a good game but it feels much more like one made specifically for tablets or even smartphones than for PC gamers, or possibly a beta for a much bigger and more immersive game. Not really worth the cost.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												Lots of people are panning this game for failing to live up to their desires of an epic level strategy 4X game. Lots of people are forgetting that this game is $15 base and even less on sales and never advertised itself as an epic level 4X strategy game. This game is exactly what it's advertised and priced as: a space ADVENTURE game where you command a small fleet in exploring the frontier, putting down pirates, engaging in tense standoffs or small scale battles with the other players, establishing trade aggreements, and bringing planets into your Federation/Empire/whatever, all through episodic missions with light storytelling. Think Star Trek Next Gen with an emphasis on combat.If you're cool with that, great! Get this game! It's fun and worth your bit of money. And if you want a more vast, epic, and detailed game, please, PLEASE, don't buy this $15 game and then come back to leave scathing, raging reviews because it wasn't the $60 game you were looking for.

												I gave this game the benefit of the doubt thinking that it could not be as bad as some of the reviews were saying. I was wrong. This game does not play anything like any sort of 4X I have ever played, it is barely a 2X.Pros:-Was on sale for <$5-Light graphics seemed to play smooth-Quick play-through-Only a single unit to manageCons:-Colony management is a joke-One fleet-No real diversity in anything (weapons, ships, etc)-Each Faction plays exactly the sameIt was on sale for less than $5 and I am still requesting a refund.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												I get that this is not supposed to be a full-fledged 4X strategy game. It's more of a tactical fleet combat game with a basic empire management layer thrown on top of it. It's just that it doesn't do the space combat that well either. Very simple system for fighting in space crowded with asteroids with not that many options considering that it's supposed to be the focus of the game. The strategy layer is even more halfhearted.I'm just not having that much fun with it. Might be worth it if you can get it for peanuts and really want to get a tactical game for a tablet. Otherwise Ace Patrol is much better choice for Firaxis light strategy games.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												Sid Meier's Starships isn't that great of a game from what little I played of it.The text on any written aspects of the game were using a font that doesn't translate well to an hdtv monitor. The graphics in general though, seem pixelated, and not in the good way.The tutorial it pops up at the beginning of the turn isn't that useful when it does it more than one time in a row with the same information. Information that isn't all that useful on how to control the ship or giving you any input on if that is your only ship or if you can eventually control more, etc.I guess for only making Sid Meier's Beyond Earth $2 more expensive, it isn't a huge loss. It just needs some polishing for me to choose it over Endless Space.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												I think this is an excellent game for $15.If you enjoy sci-fi and strategy games, I encourage you to give this game a try. There are a fair amount of negative reviews out there, and they share valid concerns, but I believe they all had expectations that would apply to a full on AAA title. Unfortunately the people who enjoy the game most likely are busy playing the game instead of posting positive reviews. Belly achers love telling people about their butthurt. Do your research online before you buy the game, and if you like what you see, you won't regret spending the $15. It's a tactical combat game for starships, with a small portion of Planetary resource collection. Build a fleet of 8 ships or less. Research tech that improves your combat performance. Colonize planets to gain additional resources every turn to improve your fleet. GOOD STUFF!!

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												I really wish i could recommend this game, i really do... This is supposed to be my favorite type of game. Maybe i had too much expectations for it, some kind of ''tactical 4x'' like if xcom and endless space had a baby but the gameplay is way too redundant and shallow to play more than a few hours. It could have been a lot nicer if it wasn't all about the combats phase and more about managing your empire and diplomacy which, by the way, is a joke : you can either be at peace or at war with other empires and nothing else. No spying, no trade, no borders tensions, nothing ! Oh and did i mention that science and warfare are jokes as well ? it kind of reminds me some browser game like ogame or some cheap smartphone game.I liked the drawing that are used as cut scenes though.Sorry devs, your game... sucks. I guess that's what happens when you don't have enough time to give all the love it deserve...

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												It's a fun little game, bringing more tactical gameplay into the civ universe, but keeping enough of the strategy to let you know it's a Sid Meier game. I'm very hopeful that cross connectivity takes off in a big way, well done to Firaxis, 2K, and everyone involved for taking the plunge with it here.It feels like a mobile/tablet game that's also been released on the PC, and so some will find the price a little steep - but if it's a mobile game, it's a HUGE and complex one with a surprising amount of depth and diverse viable strategies to experiment with.It does have some technical issues, for me it crashes sometimes if I try to move the camera below the plane of the map, but has thus far always reloaded without losing any progress.I recommend it for fans of Beyond Earth, and I think it's worth picking up on sale for anyone else who likes the concept.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												When I first played this game, I wondered why it received such low reviews.  Now I know.  While the basic game mechanics are really a lot of fun, the late game combat gets so tedious and boring that I dread when enemies attack me.  Sure, I know I can beat them, after a 45 minute battle of them running away while I chase them down, one by one.This game would've been better with a 3 or 4 ship maximum (currently 8).  Also, combat turns are slow and tedious.  Movement and attacks are about half as fast as they should be.  When you get an extra movement action and want to spend it on using the impulse action twice (move 1 extra space), there is no hot key, so you have to click the icon, select a location, click the icon, select a location.  It may not seem like much, but when chasing down enemies, and you've got a full fleet of 8 ships and something like 10 fighter ships (or whatever the max is), it adds a minute or two to every turn.The animations for attacks are also really slow.  It's supposed to be a laser, but you have to watch it for ups of 5 seconds as it travels through space and hits the enemy ship.The combat seemed like it was going to be fun, but it just burns my brain at this point.  I'm scared that the enemy will attack me, cause it'll be soooo boring.If they would fix that, I'd highly recommend this game.

												Why I like this gameI see a lot of hate on this game, but i realy like it, and here is why.Its a very light turnbased strategy game, i have it open on my work laptop and can speak to clients over the desk and on the phone while i play.The game it self is, yes light, but that makes it easy for me to do work and come back to it and not lose the idea of what i was doing.I feel the people who cast it away after 1 or 2 games might not see what i see in it and that is fine, we dont all have to like the same things.If this game was 50-60 €/USD I would be mad, but at this price i think its a realy good game, im planing on buying it for my iPad also.To me and alwais looking at the price tag, it a 9/10 game, thank you Sid Meier for yes what will be hours and hours of fun strategy.

												I have seen quite a few negative reviews on here, and that really surprised me. This game is pretty brilliant for what it is, a 15 dollar game. It is sorta simple on many levels. I see people have it though, so I am sure the game isn't broken. I am doing something wrong is all. I did manage to get my home world attacked on the second round of the game and lost, so that cheevo didn't happen. :DI have to say, it delivers exactly what Sid promised. Nothing more, nothing less.  I am hoping that as time goes on, more content, multiplayer options and such are added. With the 15 dollar price point, I would gladly purchase DLC to keep Sid employed. He has kept me entertained since 1982 after all. Only seems fair. TL;DR - Buy it. It is 15 bucks that will be well spent.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												First let me say that I came into this game knowing nothing about it but being a huge Civ's and Ace Patrol fan.This game is similar to Ace Patrol in its combat, though you dont have pitching and height mechanics, it feels the same.  Its out of combat screen however is a simplified 4x map.You get one fleet, it travels between planets and does missions to gain trade routes (similar to Spore) if the planet is owned by someone else you go to combat with their fleet, simple enough.  The planets can have their facilities upgraded and more cities added, each choice gives you more resources per turn.Your fleet can be upgraded, better weapons, shields, armor or change to new tactics like cloaking, torpedos, and launced fighters.  You will be able to do all of these eventually, you wont lock yourself out of any design, though you do have to balance your ships components with speed.The tech tree is tiny unfortunatly, the prices scale quickly so you will be sitting there a while if you're trying for a tech victory, its small but not short.The victories are done poorly, instead of a civ style advanced setup option you get to pick between all the victories (Population, Science, Domination, and Wonders) and any single one of them.  In practice the All games tend to end in domination or population quickly, wonder victories can come out of no where and science takes too long.The starting options are a bit generic as well, each civilization has a unique bonus and each captain has a bonus, the captains are the same reguardless of race however their portrait gets a slight change.  Some say that its lazy I think its cute.It has a pretty cool integration with Beyond Earth, you can earn starting choices for Starships and Beyond Earth by playing the other game.  For example because of some Starships gameplay I get a new starting option in Beyond Earth as well as a map for an achievement and for playing Beyond Earth I can choose hybrid civs with double the bonus abilities in Starships.Over all I hope it gets polished because it does have short falls.  Its not a bad game, its pretty fun in fact, and the cross integration with BE is something I can't support enough I love it.

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												The game runs well and it looks good graphically. it is really nothing like CIV BE whatsoever, there is a bit of resourse management and research, but all the research is for your ships. Really everything is about your ships, you fly around and do missions for other planets. There are a few different missions you can do, each giving a differnt reward, money, research etc... you have to do a few missions per planet to gain enough influence for them to join your empire. It gets a little old fast doing the missions, depending on what the mission is you may need to outfit your ship(s) diffently. Some missions you only get to use one of your ships, and in others you need to avoid combat more than provoke it. Once a planet has been claimed by an opponent the battles become slightly more interesting and it becomes more about the ship battling and tactics than the missions, which felt like playing minigames. In youre planets you are able to build cities and planet upgrades, the cities boost overall income and the upgrades range in different things like planetary defences and the like. you're crew will allow you to travel a certain distance per turn, limiting how much you can do, without certain upgrades traveling between your cities can eat up you're turns. I did not find much use in the missle weapons, though they seem interesting they are fairly useless, atleast in my experience. The missles travel a certain distance per turn, you may choose to detonate them at any time during their travel but i didnt find the range to be worth it, i rarely used them but when i did i used them to cut the enemy off. The combat zones are riddled with space debris and asteroids, both allowing cover and hindering or dissalowing fire comletely. they are filled with narrow passages between asteroids that open and close (for some reason) between turns. Overall, due to its lower price tag i will recomend it, but it would be best to get it on sale if at all. The game gets old fast but it should be fun to go back to every now and again. I give it a 5/10 and hope that they update it and dont charge for micro-expansions.

												This is not Civilization. An  "epic" game only takes a few hours (at most) if all victory conditions are enabled.  That being said, it is FUN to play. There is very little strategic management of your "federation (empire)". However, small changes have cumlative effects on the outcome of battles. You have the correct combination of effects on the right map and you can defeat a much larger force.  That is actually the best part of the game, the nuances. If you are looking for an epic space 4x game that takes days to complete, look else where.  If you are looking for tactical space battles chained together wtih strategic elements, this is it. Cons :1. The interface is a little flakey, could be improved, but it does function well once you get used to it.2. Game seems shorter than it should (epic really should be epic).Pros ;1. Fast to play2. Easy to learn3. Interesting tactical problems in the battles. Summary - it's only 15 bucks paid waaaaay more for games not half as good or half as fun.

												This isn't a strategy game - or at least not one like Civ, MOO, SINS, etc. It is more like a role-playing game that uses spaceships and turn-based combat.That said, for $10 (its initial release price), it's not bad. I actually quite enjoyed it, it has some replayability, and is worth a few bucks - especially if you can get it on sale. content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												It is, as far as I know, a brand new subgenre of 4X games. Your singular fleet and its advancements are your sole concerns and unlike other 4X games you spend most of your time fighting based on a very fun and surprisingly deep combat system.  The addition of "wonders" and battle cards makes a lot of difference on the hexagonal battlefield riddled with environmental obstacles and effects that are a lot more significant than in any other 4x games.However, people hoping to find complexity of a $40+ title are going to be dissapointed. There's been some debate if the game is worth the current price ($15) and my personal subjective oppinion is that a game with this degree of polish despite the lack of $20-$50 content such as "next gen graphics", "unique races". "diplomacy". "religion" or "multiplayer" is well within it's 10-15$ range. It's a tactical combat game with 4X elements - not the other way around.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Sid Meier's Starships is a very light 4X game. You control star systems and move a fleet of upgradable ships around while competing with the AI doing the same. There are four victory conditions (wonders, population, domination, science). Once two fleets meet or you attack an enemy planet the game switches to 2D hex-based, turn-based tactical combat.  You can attack enemy ships with lasers, torpedoes, plasma guns and fighters. There is a simple stealth option and there are obstacles on each map that can be used as a cover for ships. On the strategy map you can also upgrade your ships, buy new ships (but you can only have one fleet at a time) upgrade your planets, build cities and wonders and improve your tech level (there are different resources for each task).Now before I start on listing my personal pros and cons I'd like to get this out of the way first: The game is in no way comparable to great 4X games like Master of Orion, Endless Legends and so on. It's a simply game, designed for tablets much like Sid Meier's Ace Patrol. If you want a large, complex 4X-game then don't buy Sid Meier's Starships. Starships is much more of a "let's play something for 20 minutes" game than anything else.That said, here are my pros and cons:Pros:- Good Interface- Fast paced combat and strategy map- Fames don't take long to complete (I finished an epic game on normal in 2 hours)- Enjoyable if simple turn based combat- I really, really like the artwork in the game.Cons:- Diplomacy is useless.- The options are a joke (for example: Fullscreen mode only works on my system if I hide the task bar. If the task bar is   not hidden it's always visible and the game doesn't go fullscreen)- The different factions really don't play all that different. And choosing an affinity is mostly about what color you like- The turn based combat is simple. It's really easy to find a strategy that works for you (I enjoy mass torpedo spam for example) and stick with it. Once you have upgraded the first two ships to the max level there is almost nothing that can stop you)Conclusion: I recommend buying the game if you look for something to just play for a couple of minutes and if you enjoy simple turn based combat.I do not recommend buying the game if you look for something complex or challenging.

												Utter trash.  In case it's not obvious from the movies / screenshots... this is literally nothing more than leftover assets from Sid Meier's: Beyond Earth, reworked into a junkpile flash game.  It's not enjoyable, no real sense of accomplishment (or difficulty)... really it feels like one of the old "classic" TBS games like Master of Orion or Galactic Civilizations, only all the choices have been removed and the game runs at 10x speed.  I do NOT recommend, even at a discount (I got it about $5 cheaper than its current list price).  Sometimes I wonder if Sid Meier even has anything to do with the things that bear his name anymore.... I can't imagine any honest developer took a look at this and thought "Yeah, this is totally not just a half-as sed cash grab!".

												The good thing is: The ship to ship combat is actually pretty decent, and would fit well attached to a traditional 4X game such as Endless Space or Glactic Civilizations that have little or no tactical combat. The problem is, that this game as a whole feels pretty incomplete, and I don't even mean in the "I am mad that this is a ported mobile game" sense. Battles are all there is, and with no other narrative tying it together, it all falls flat. Upgrades to ships, and your tech, are all number increases, with no new abilities added. The buildable wonders give you some special traits, but even these all boil down to "this works better" or "you are now immune to this". This isn't bad per se, it just isn't very substantial. I still love you uncle Sid.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
 I want to start by saying that I clearly put some time into this game, and I do believe that it is on the VERY EDGE of recieving a recommendation.  The bugs and obvious mission features need to be worked out.  The Decent Parts   Tactical Combat - Although it still isn't perfect, the combat sections of the game are actually very entertaining.  Ships can be outfitted with various modules and upgraded to your liking.  Whether your ships are damage sponges with devastating firepower, carriers that can launch numerous fighters at the enemy, or insanely fast scout ships with cloaking abilities to get behind enemy lines, you're going to need to use some strategy and use your surroundings to your advantage.  If caught in the open, you can withstand critical hits, which need a turn to be repaired and leave you vunerable to attack.    Wonders - On each planet that you capture for your federation, you will recieve the option to create a wonder, such as stealth torpedos, 360 degree shielding, and systems that can withstand critical hits.  These can open new strategies and may influence how you build your ships.  Mission Variety - Missions aren't always simply "Kill the baddies before they pimp slap you to death".  While travelling to different planets to increase your federation's influence, you will often encounter missions that require you to escort civilian ships, maintain control of bases, and destroy stealth fighters that conceal themselves in the shadows.  While the missions to gain influence may often seem boring and pointless, it is often made up for by the epic battles between two warring federations.  These final battles as you attempt to capture homeworlds (or defend yours from an assault) often made me feel like I was actually doing something halfway important.  Instead of a 30 second mission where I blow up a fighter squadron, I was spending 30-40 minutes thinking about where to put my ships, which enemy ships to take out first, and how to evade my own destruction as masses of enemy battleships closed in on my carriers. The Not-So-Decent Parts   The UI/Graphics - The UI... isn't great.  At all. On top of the UI size being suited for an iPad and not a monitor, the graphics are just.. ugly.  This game looks like something I would've had on my phone two or three years ago.  Victory Conditions - I don't know what 2K was thinking by letting this slide.  At the start of the game you are given five settings for victory conditions. You can enable Domination, Population, Wonder, Science, or all of these.  Now you would think that enabling one of these would make it so that it is the only possible winning condition.  The sad part is that the condition you set only applies to yourself.  You can set the condition to domination, and after 3 or 4 hours of playing (the normal time for an epic sized map with a lot of opponents) a random opponent will win with a wonder victory out of nowhere.  This leads in to my next point...  Endgame - Nothing.  Unlike most other Sid Meier games I've played, and hell, any strategy game I've played (which is a lot, don't be fooled by my Steam library), you are not allowed to proceed with the game after there is a victor.  Instead you are presented a population chart (no other options) that lacks any type of accurate scale.  I could have 100mil population, and an opponent with 9mil is above me for some odd reason.  If you happen to win, you'll have the pleasure of watching a generic video about how you're some fabulous leader and now there's a thousand years of peace.  Clearly lacks any effort. The Potential / What I Expected Going into Starships,  I was expecting almost a complete reskin of Sid Meier's Pirates!, which, in my honest opinion is a FANTASTIC game.  I expected being able to customize my ships with my own names, specialized guns, and maybe even some visuals.  I also expected to be able to play the game after a victory.  I wanted to feel like I was actually the captain of a fleet, but sadly I didn't get that feeling.  Although I didn't get what I expected out of Starships, I do believe that it was worth the $15 that I purchased it for.  With a few updates and various tweaks, I honestly think that this could be a fantastic game.  Now I'm clearly not expecting an overhaul of the entire combat system or the graphics, but at least add "one more turn", a more varied diplomacy system, and work out some of the minor bugs. The Final Verdict:   5/10 - Average

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												First let me just say that Starships is a decent and fun game to play for the low price it costs. The game has really good graphics which is what I have come to expect from Sid Meier's games.  The loading time into the game is a lot quicker than the standard civilization games which I also liked.   To me it was like a board game based in space using the basics from the civilization games. Their is some micro managing you can do in Starships but its not overwhelming like it is in other civ games.  I also like that the planetary jump gates allow you to keep moving your fleet without adding fatigue.  I played a game on the easy  level and had the largest map. I still finished it in under 6 hours, which is kind of cool considering their is no multiplayer option for starfighter.    I do feel their is a few drawbacks that I feel could have been improved upon.  The game seems to randomly shut itself down, which isnt that huge of deal considering it has the continue option when loading back into the game. The saves could use some work. I dont know where it saves it, I am assuming it is in some kind of cloud. I was unable to locate the save file directory on my computer for starships. I prefere to be able to manually delete my own save files without having to fire the game up first to do it. So if Starships is updated I would like to see a save file directory on my pc.  The in game maps do not seem to be that big in my opinion. The tool tips could use improving, it kept wanting me to develop my ion  engines even after i increased the tech and took ship engines to 5.  Finally their is no multiplayer option with starships. I think starships would be a lot more funner if i could have the option to play with my friends against the Ai's or each other. The one thing I dont understand is why only 1 fleet? Im guessing that is because the fleet is used for visiting the planets and attacking while the planetary defence's are for when you get attacked. So over all the game is fun to play if you dont mind playing it by yourself against the computer.  For the price of $15 I paid for it, I feel it was worth it and recomend it to play.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												Let me start with this: I love Civ Rev.If that statement alone makes you recoil in disgust, walk away from Starships and this review. I didn't come to this game looking for the depth that VI and V offer--or an experience which would redeem BE (I disliked it in fact). Instead I looking for something that can scratch that X-COMy, Pirates!-y, and straightforward Civ Rev itch which this game handily satisfies. Bonust points: Really reminds me of the 4x tabletop game, Eclipse--gathering resources, upgrading planets--extending your influence. Also a simiilar 'rubberband'  (escalating cost worker placement) mechanic keeps you from expanding too far too fast in the form of your crew's fatigue level. If you undertake too many missions, or travel too far your combat effectiveness plummets. There are ways to extend your crew's fatigue, but at the cost of resources which could be better spent improving the planets you control. The game also does a fine job during missions as well. The battles are fast paced and satisfying, even addictive. I often find myself absentmindedly going on another mission when I already decided that the last one was the last one. Penalties: They drop the ball in many places. To start, graphically, there's an appreciable difference between stylized and cartoony, and this game veers toward the latter. There's also ample room for imagination in the implemetation of weapon effects, and many missed opportunities to really differentiate the ship classes between affinities. The affinites are basically skin deep, and only add a starting bonus to the civ that chooses it. Another missed opportunity for depth is laying out the actual armament and defenses of your ships, ala Eclipse. There's no 'energy' cost however, for upgrading aside from the resource itself. Hence, with enough resources your could put every upgrade on one ship since there's no energy cap. Even FTL figured out a good balance in this regard. This game isn't for eveyone but if you found anything I said forgivable or intriguing--for $15 dollars--this game is worth it.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												I'll echo what others have said:  If you're expecting Beyond Earth II, or Civilization VI - that isn't this.  It's a light game with some 4x elements and some exploration elements.  There's a little colonial management, a decent tactical simulator (if you don't mind turn/hex based), and a variety of victory conditions.And that's really it.  It's true there is no tutorial, but there are a few help screens and that's all you need.  This is simple, light fare...and it does what it sets out to do.  In my first game I was one turn ('mission') away from a science victory, when one of my opponents conquered another one and was slightly over 50% population.  It takes 51 to win however and I managed to eke it out.  For all the lightness of the game, it was  a fun and entertaining game that took about 4 hours start to finish.

Posted: March 15, 2015
												Strategy-Lite; 4x-Lite. More filler game than mainstay. A little lacking in the kind of depth one finds in GalCiv or Total War. All of these things are true. And you know what? That is okay with me. Because Starships is not trying to be any of those games. This is a lite weight affair with ample choices and sufficient depth for the game it is trying to be. And that is a game wherein a player can wile away a few hours enjoying excellent theme and some lightweight, enjoyable turn based combat. If you're looking for the next GalCiv or Endless Space, no, this is not your game. If on the other hand you prefer your strategy lighter and simpler and a little less overwhelming - or you just want to kill a few hours with some lite fun - then give this a look. Especially if you enjoyed Ace Patrol, as this really is quite a good game in its own right.

It wasn't running on my PC until I ran the OpenAL installer and I've installed the previous version of OpenAL many times.Game doesn't have proper fullscreen, only fullscreen on desktop, so taskbar shows. This is absolutely inexcusable because it is stupidly easy to code full screen unless the library you're using doesn't support it in which case don't use such a stupid library.No ability to redefine keys. Amateur.Game crashes every time after you exit to desktop. Game is locked to 30 fps. This is absolutely inexcusable because it is stupidly easy to fix.No mouse scrolling on edge of screen, instead it's left click and drag.Game was obviously coded with mobile as least common denominator.See all these negative points?! And I haven't even started playing the game yet.update:The actual game is fun. It's basically a board game where you have your little band of ships and you go around between planets doing missions to get influence. The missions are tactical turn-based battles. It's not as deep as a proper 4X game but it is fun.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Strategy thick starship tactics with adrenaline stimulating tense action. Sid Meier's Starships has a incredible unique mix of elements which come together to create exciting suspenseful battles where fast skillful maneuvering to get in just the right sweet strategic position to fire hull shattering hits upon enemy ships then take off engines blasting behind a planetoid or some asteroids before the enemy can counter attack with devastating effect. Sid Meier's Starships is the first turn based strategy game i may have ever played which felt fast and furious giving a fps shooter adrenaline rush in of all things a turn based strategy game. It was like playing a table top game with friends but against the ai instead. Graphics have an old school style to them with a great hex map setup with many environmental variables which can mean the difference between life and death depending on how the player utilizes them to their advantage. Weapons have varying ranges and levels of damage with lasers delivering heavy damage from long range while missile weapons like torpedoes are usually slower with a chance of being avoided if one keeps their attacks fluid and mobile. Stay still and you are probably dead like a sitting duck.You can buy and upgrade ships to become lethal space faring dreadnoughts of unstoppable destruction. In my first game as i was learning my way around i built two heavily armored ships which were able to take on a group of five enemy ships and fighters for awhile letting loosing terrifying barrages of laser fire into their midst before eventually being defeated with blood curdling audio and visuals during their horrific demise. Talk about getting lost in fun abandonment as if watching a starship battle in a episode of STAR TREK.Planets you rule are used to get resources and do research to improve your battle prowess and keep your empire going. You will come across other leaders which you form alliances with or who will form alliances against you as everyone does their best to thrive and survive in the infinite vastness of the universe.Audio and music is excellent bringing home those peaceful space traveling moments only to be shattered by battle inspiring man your weapons music. Voice acting is quite good and am glad to say the female robotic voice of the computer is quite informative and comforting :)Cons-Ouch that user interface is not intuitive to put it mildly. During my first game session i couldnt even figure out how to move my ships until i watched a Youtube video by AngryJoe who was doing a first impressions playthrough. Also i have to hover my mouse pointer above my selection when giving a command otherwise i will choose the command below it or none at all.  If your into fast paced turn based combat with plenty of thrilling tension while not expecting a CIVILIZATION BEYOND EARTH experiance then Sid Meier's STARSHIPS is the game for you. Just enjoy it for what it is and you will find its more then worth the few credits you have paid to enter the star ship bridge for.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												So, Starships...What is it? The background is a basic two-dimensional map as in, say, Galciv 2 or even Moo2. You have one space fleet, which you can add ships to. You can also upgrade the ships both by adding components and improving your technology (the 'science tree'). Wiith your fleet you take on missions with Star-Trekky names, to gain influence over other star systems and eventually add them to your empire. You can also attack the AI players, who are the same cast that appeared in Civ:BE.You receive resources ech turn from your controlled systems; the systems can be upgraded by spending food to increase population, or metals to upgrade production. You can also build nexuses to get around more conveniently, and megabots to defend your systems. So there is an element of 'empire management', too.Victory can come through: science, population, domination, wonders; however, you cannot force the AI players to select a particular choice, so you need to keep an eye on their progress as well as your own. Game length is short; even spinning it out, you can finish a game with top-level ships (say, 6 levels of whatever components you like best) in 2-3 hours, and that would be a game you could have won much sooner if you'd chosen to do so.The main focus of the game is on starship combat, for at least two reasons: first, because that is the only way to expand, and second, because every player/AI battle at a home planet is sudden death for the empire being attacked; if it loses, all its systems immediately join the winner.So, how good is combat? Well, between equally balanced fleets (ignore what the game tells you about your 'prospects of victory) the AI will give you a challenge. Of course, if you have much better (fast, stealthed) ships, then the AI can be made to look foolish. But then, if the tables were turned, the reverse would probably be true also.Price: there are a number of good older games for the same price or less, but for a brand-new game, this didn't strike me as unreasonably expensive. Reservations1.	The game can end suddenly and unexpectedly if you or another player acquires seven wonders -  a number that is not scalable. So you can find yourself tactically NOT building wonders or capturing planets that have them. The same happens if two AI opponents decide to combine forces, and it turns out they have 7 wonders between them. It's not obvious to me why '7 wonders' should even be a victory condition, and particularly not such an arbitrary one.2.	There is the ability to link Starships and Civ:BE via My2k. It is quite fiddly to do (you need to open a My2k account and log on in both games). The reward is that you can take your Civ:BE persona into Starships against the same opponents and play on there. Also, you can obtain rewards (extra missions, more planet types and affinity choices). Having played 214 hours of Civ:BE and obtained nearly all achievements,it does seem like a bit of an imposition to have to jump through the hoops again on the off-chance I may get an Earth-type world, say, in Starships. At least there could be some indication of how to unlock the extras! More seriously, logging onto My2k while playing Civ:BE caused gameplay lag, and also a screen crash of my computer on restart. I believe you should get the bonuses automatically if you already have the achievements in Civ:BE.Conclusions. Mostly harmless. This is a perfectly acceptable, 'play over lunch' type of game. It isn't great, and it isn't terrible. It isn't hugely expensive, and it certainly isn't  cheap. It needs more content in terms of missions, and there are a couple of gameplay issues to sort out. Overall, it's good fun and is a welcome change of pace from those labour-intensive 4x type games that go on for days. Thumbs up.P.S. Thereis now a guide to the unlockables: 


Welcome to Starships: A Reference Guide 
A Guide for Sid Meier's Starships
By: thecrazyscotsman

			This guide provides an overview of the game's basic systems as well as reference materials for the different leaders, planets, and bonuses you will encounter during your game.

												Not a game that hardcore fans of Civ seem to like from the comments.  At $15, my expectations weren't high, despite the research that I had done prior (once I saw the price point I knew I had to shift my priorities or I would end up disappointed).  Some will generally not like the touch-friendly control, however it still works for the game as it is designed, and it still provides enough challenge to play through with different characters and affinities.  It seems as this is more of a sequel to beyond earth that wasn't meant to be a full fleged game - and in its own right it owns that.  In its current incarnation it could be cross platformed across all Win 10 devices once the OS is released at the end of the year, as the hardware on most if not all computers won't be taxed by the graphics engine used in the game.If you're a hardcore civ fan avoid it - however if you want to give a slightly more casual incarnation of the Civ universe, this is it.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												I think most of the negative reviews around this came come mostly as a result of overly high expectations. A lot of the criticism is that it's not as in depth as civ, or other great 4x titles for that matter. But the fact is, this game isn't trying to be complex. Let's not forget that "Sid Meier's" games are not confined to complex strategy games. I've had just as much in my time playing Sid Meier's Pirates as I have playing Civ, and the difficulty gap between those games is enourmous. Just because this game is light on strategy doesn't mean it should be a let down. Also, this game was barely mentioned at all until a few months before its release; clearly this game isn't supposed to be a big deal. What's more, it really shouldn't matter if it's a mobile game, because it's still a good game. The only reason mobile games are a bad thing is that they are frequenty riddled with poor design and are little more than money-making schemes for their developers. I think it's good that Starships is a mobile game. You know why? It sets a good example. More mobile games should be like this. It's relatively simple, has a low learning curve, and yet still manages to be engaging and entertaining. It's easy to enjoy this game as long as you don't go into it expecting to play a 12 hour long game. I finish games in 30 minutes to 1 hour, and that's fine, because for what it is, this game is great.

												I actually really enjoy the game! If you're big on in depth strategy and resource management this isn't it. Managing planets doesn't have much depth. Build cities to up al resource output by a bit or build individual improvments to highly increase specific resource outputs. The game is mainly about building up your fleet and running combat missions. One thing I really enjoy is the fleet building. You start off with two ships and some energy to upgrade them. The fun thing is that all ships start with roughly the same base stats, and depending on where you put upgrades it not only does it alter that ships apperance but also what role you're looking to use the ship in. As I said, the gameplay is fast paced, not a whole lot of depth but I still really enjoy playing it! Something to waste away the afternoon with for sure!

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												This is a great game, lots of fun!It's NOT a standard CIV game... it's a light strategy, with a light tactical  combat system that has surprising depth (a lighter version of XCom).The fleet combat (the main part of the game) is very fun, with many tactical options depending on your choices with wonders having a big impact on your play style. Tactics I've tried: A fast fleet with powerful short range weapons A fleet with lots of torpedoes and long range lasers A slow carrier fleet A small fleet with super ships (basically putting all your money in to 1 or 2 ships) think Mega Battleships A fleet with 2 'tanks' and the remainder light long range ships A fleet with 2 'tanks' and several carriersThese are just the ones I've tried so far... there are many possibilities, and you will have to responded the enemy fleet composition.In general you'll be spending your time:  Placing facilities on planets to improve output for a single resource or getting a fleet bonus (via wonders) Placing cities that will increase output for all resource types on that planet Acquiring technology for your ships Customisng ships (they change appearance based on your choices) Expanding your empire, by doing favours for planets or attacking other players And a lot of fighting (the game is all about fleet combat)Everything in the game is purchased, so there is no building or researching, you simply decide what you want and buy it with the correct resource. There are 5 resources generated by planets and they can also be traded or purchased with credits.So if you are expecting an in depth 4x space game you are going to be very upset (seriously read / view the marketing material).When you don't want to commit to a 20-60+ hour 4x space game this is an easy choice with games lasting for 30 mins to 2 hours.I can see myself playing this for many more hours.For some other opinions, have a look at: Eurogamer review [www.eurogamer.net] Polygon preview PS: I am confused why there seems to be so many ppl on here who expected Sid Meier's Gal Civ or Master of Orion, I found all marketing and previews very clear as to the aim / tone of the game!

												It's a lightweight but well formed strategy game which may be missing a few PC optimisations (a fullscreen mode and slightly more saturated colours would be welcome) but still manages to be fast moving with a reasonably elegant meta-game and pacy turn based battles. There is no overwatch mode in combat which would have been an interesting addition, but torpedoes, stealth and the ability for your ships to launch fighter wings give you lots of options and the missions (battles, escorts, maze escapes and full on fleet engagements) are surprisingly varied. I've had a lot of fun with this so far.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Sid Meier's Starships......an out of the blue title that generated a lot of anticipation and more than a little wonder at what the package would bring. Now it's here and while it's not socks from Grandma at Christmas, it's not quite the game you were hoping for either. Good but not great, worth the price but perhaps unworthy of the legend that is Sid Meier.This is not a 4x game nor was it ever advertised as such. It's more Ace Patrol than Civ, something fun that won't require huge chunks of your life to complete but something you can come back and jump right in to. While lacking in chrome, this game retains Sid's famous "one more turn" quality. The game is fun to play and the deeper you get into it the more strategies become apparent. I started it, played a few turns and stopped to do something else several times, then fired it up again after dinner and played it straight thru to midnight, surprised at how much time had passed.The lack of chrome, i.e. the ability to rename your starships and planets, the lack of any leaders, not nearly enough starship models, etc..... is disappointing but not a show stopper. Hopefully, given the track record of Meier products, this will be addressed in future updates. I hope to see steam workshop support added as well to let Sid's passionate fanbase come up with their own ideas. This is the kind of game that cries out for a Star Trek/Star Wars/BSG mod from some basement genius and I can't wait to see that happen.Over the years I've bought and played every single game Sid has ever made. This game won't add to the legend that is Sid Meier, but it won't detract from it either. You'll get more than enough gameplay from Starships to justify the cost, you just won't be sitting around 15 years from now saying "remember Sid Meier's Starships?!?! Now that was a game"!

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												After some thought I decided to recommend this game, but with some caveats.The best way I could describe this game is as a simplified version of Master of Orion I, with more emphasis to strategic battles (that cannot be skipped). We have battles, simple planet management, a very simple tech tree. You control only one fleet. You can add ships to it, or upgrade them by increasing the number of weapons, shields, etc...There is no limit on the number of components on the ship, but the cost of additional components increases exponentially.Another difference from MOO I is that you cannot colonize, and every planet is already populated, and by visiting them you can take battle missions, By winning them you gain influence and eventually the planet will become part of the federation. And yes, everything is turn-based.The main focus of the game are the missions. Indeed, you're going to spend very little time managing the planets and more fighting. Battles themself are generally short (about 5 minutes), and you can perform several battles per turn, as you can move your fleet multiple times per turn.Don't try to have long gaming sessions: you'll get bored very soon, because even if there are several types of missions the game mechanism repeats itself over and over again. The game is meant to be played for short periods, like one or two missions at a time. This is fine to me because I'm busy and I have little time playing videogames. No surprise that the game is also for iPad.My main complain about the game is the control system. It doesn't seem really designed for a PC. You can't zoom out in battles or even on the galaxy maps (you can zoom in). Also, it is easy to accidentally move the fleet to a planet you try to interact with. If they fixit my opinion of the game will increase quite a lot.It is good that the game is only $15, but I believe that $10 would probably be a fairer price. So maybe wait for a sale of the game.

I would rebuy it on the Ipad, but for a pc game, it should have had "more" stuff. I recommend this for the average gamer, or for the people who like simple scifi turn-based games. But for the real gamer, I wouldn't recommend it. I'd give it a 6.5/10, the score will rise if the game gets more updates.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												See my Welcome to Starships: A Reference Guide for an in-depth overview of the game and its systems.What you should expect A light-strategy game designed to allow you to do a complete play through in just a few hours. The tactical missions are fairly varied and fun. The strategic layer is very simple. With just a few resources you can upgrade your planets and upgrade your ships. There are some basic technologies you can research with each technology having a direct impact on your ships' effectiveness. All-in-all, a $15 game which isn't trying to hide what it is. I, for one, appreciate the fact that it's light and quick as I do not have the time to put into a full fledged Civ game most of the time.What you shouldn't expect It is not Civilization. It is not a 4x strategy game. You will be disappointed if you buy the game expecting that. This is far closer to Ace Patrol (with a dash of XCOM) than it is to any other Sid Meier game.Watch some gameplay videos. If it looks fun, then you'll probably enjoy it.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												Firstly, choosing between Recommending this game, and not recommending this game was kind of a hard choice, but in the end I decided to recommend it for what it is.The reason: It's a good game.  It's a short game, but it's a good game.Allow me if you will, to delve into the reasons why I will recommend this; It's a mini-game.  The game itself is made as a companion game but can be played on it's own and is still a bunch of fun.  It's short enough that you can fit in a quick game (an impossibility with other Sid Meier titles), and still leave satisfied.You choose a different "leader" which gives you a different boost during the game, but overall I didn't find they made too much of a difference.  Then you really just expand, fight off some ships through an asteroid field, and repeat.  There's a few "varieties" of missions, but it's generally just clear out the other fleet, get your ship to a "warp hole", or escort a colony ship.  If you're okay with repeating these missions over and over again (with more or less enemies, and a few modifications like reduced visibility) then the game is a fun little time filler.If you're not, then don't buy this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												A new Civilization in space? Something that expands Civ:BE allowing it to reach the glory it aimed at? Unfortunately, no. Sid M.'s Starships goes in the same direction XCom, franchise revived by Firaxis, did. And it goes much, much further. For those who may not know, the new XCom is an extremely simplified, tainted with tacky graphics ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of the original game. Although, unlike Starships, it's still very enjoyable. But let's not get ahead of ourselves. What do we get buying SM Starships? Pitifully little. It's a typical tablet/phone game that could be distributed for free if the devs cut down on graphics, basic as it already is. Tech tree does not exist. Instead, we get several options to improve cerain aspects by a % bonus. Boring.Pretty much the same can be said about development of planets. Player is just adding numbers and %.Combat looks like in XCom but is much less intuitive. Will I be able to hit my enemy if i move a little to the right? Will have to see. It's a guessing game, especially when distance grows. Torpedoes and their delayed explosions are a nice touch, even though AI can't handle them a bit. BTW, "lasers" in this game act like tomahawk missiles. Curved lasers... Priceless. Missions are simply boring. All are played on almost identical maps. Only details vary. Special missions, ie. hunt a ship or flee, only pretend to be different.Another thing is pacing of the game. I've seen and done everything in 2 hours. Nothing left to explore. After half a dozen turns you've already been everywhere and done everything. What's worse, you've also upgraded everything worth upgrading and bought everything worth buying. The biggest killjoy comes from fleet upgrades. Cheap upgrades make you invincible. Spend one turn's income on lasers and bang! You are dealing 1000% more damage!All in all, if you have nothing to do while taking a shhhhh..., buy it and play it for a moment. Just make sure you have no problems with moving your bowels because if that's the case, you may get bored with the game before you succeed on the other field.I really hope this game makes a lot of money because after Civ:BE the name Sid Meier became much cheaper, and after Starships, it may be forgotten, or even shunned, by everyone besides older Civ players. After all, money is the only conceivable incentive that could have given life to this little title.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												Firstly, choosing between Recommending this game, and not recommending this game was kind of a hard choice, but in the end I decided to recommend it for what it is.The reason: It's a good game.  It's a short game, but it's a good game.Allow me if you will, to delve into the reasons why I will recommend this; It's a mini-game.  The game itself is made as a companion game but can be played on it's own and is still a bunch of fun.  It's short enough that you can fit in a quick game (an impossibility with other Sid Meier titles), and still leave satisfied.You choose a different "leader" which gives you a different boost during the game, but overall I didn't find they made too much of a difference.  Then you really just expand, fight off some ships through an asteroid field, and repeat.  There's a few "varieties" of missions, but it's generally just clear out the other fleet, get your ship to a "warp hole", or escort a colony ship.  If you're okay with repeating these missions over and over again (with more or less enemies, and a few modifications like reduced visibility) then the game is a fun little time filler.If you're not, then don't buy this game.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												I picked up this game on sale recently.  I have only just played around with it a bit but I will say that it is entertaining. There is the inherant boredom factor that comes with each and every Civilization game and this one is absolutely no exception. It has a similar feel and dynamic as Beyond Earth but I do feel....an almost...emptiness while playing it.  It's a fun quick game but I guess I wish it was a little more expansive. I like the fact that it is a Civ game with a relatively short turn around as sometimes it's nice to just play a quick game and be done with it rather than spending insane amounts of time saving and reloading the same game to infinity.  The lack of multiplayer/co-op is either a massive oversight or a shrewd strategy to market it to the tablet crowd (Android capability please and thank you). Overall if you like the Civ games, like Beyond Earth, and want something that is not going to take 5 days then this is your game.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												It's all about the starships, so the scope of the same is small and specific. It's fun-size strategy. Like the candy that is either good or bad depending on how much you wanted to begin with.Despite real space being very empty, the battle maps are full of asteroids, and wormholes, and that gives you cover and shortcuts to work with so there's more to think about than just who to shoot.The strategic overworld is important though. In several games I've won every battle but lost the game because an AI won more important battles somewhere else.Equipping ships isn't quite what I'd hoped for. I was hoping for more precision in the choices. Situations where I could determine that one more level of shields would make a world of difference because that would mean a ship would take three hits to defeat instead of two. Doesn't have that. It's more a general: I need more protection-get more protection. It's the strategic layer that more determines how your ships take shape rather than countering something your enemy has.The wonders that enhance your fleet and the modules local planets specialize in give you reason to choose one design over another. If a planet offers cheaper armour that would be a reason to choose to use it rather than shields or stealth for defense. A wonder making your torpedoes undetectable would make them a key weapon in your fleet.The resources your planets provide will determine how you enhance your ships. Excess metal leads to wonders, science to research based bonuses, and energy to bigger fleets with bigger ships. Working with what the game gives you rather than a predetermined plan determines how well you do. This adds to replay in that one game may give you lots of science and cheep fighters but the next offers energy and cannons. You could see this as a loss of choice, if your goal is to find one good strategy and stick with it, but if you'd rather be surprised by and adapt to what you have then this will work for you. We should start calling (tagging?) games like this MacGyver games, because you have to win with not what is the bet tool for the job but, with what you can do with what's at hand.Can't tell yet how balanced the various options are yet, or if having a design theme is necessary or if you can just have all general purpose ships and be fine.I've had fun. It's only $15. Probably better on tablet.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I must admit that I came into this game not expecting much.  But what I got is a game that is quite enjoyable.  Whilst the game borrows from the lore of Civilization Beyond Earth the game itself doesn't hold much in common.The game works by having you perform missions at each planet you stop at.  Complete the mission and your influence on that planet rises till you control it.  When you control it you can improve it, gain resources and wonders, and generally have access to more "stuff".The strategy comes in utilising your fleet (you only have one) to your benefit.  You only have a certain number of actions per turn so make sure you choose well.  Do you do a mission on a nearby planet?  Make a run for an emey's home world?  Or spend a turn to repair and make new ships in your fleet?Overall a really good game that ties "tried and true" Sid Meier concepts into the one game.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Read lots of reviews before buying this!First off, I do like the game and I think many others will too.  However, if you're looking for the usual depth people expect from Sid Meier, then this won't be the game for you.It's a fun stratagy game, with some refreshing mechanics and a solid platform for interesting tactics.The down side is that it seems to have been designed for tablets then ported, rather than the other way.  So the interface is simpler than PC gamers will be used to, and annoyingly (at launch) it doesn't have true full screen or full graphics/interface options.If you want a more casual stratagy experience you can play in the background between other things then this is a cool little title. If you want a full emersive stratagy game that will steal hours of your life at a time, this won't do that for you.

number of helpful: 11 of 25 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												tl;tr: It's not Civilization in space! It is a small and fast game, perfect to play after work for an hour or two and have fun. Not very deep but funny! Don't expect too much, if you want to play deep and long games go to Civilization. If you want to relax after work for an hour or two this game could be for you.What is Sid Meier's Starships? You have an intergalactic empire and the goal is nothing less than to rule the galaxy. You can build some basic industry on planets which produce resources like food, metal and so on. With those resources you build your fleet and travel to other planets where you can do missions to gather influence. If you have enough influence the sytem joins your empire. Very simple.There are several mission types like "kill all enemies", "protect a convoy" or "escape from a asteroid field". You can customize your ships, which means you can add long range lasers, short range plasma weapons, torpedos, shields, hull, fighters etc. The fights are the fun part, with the different weapon types one can develop different tactics which makes really fun. The torpedos e.g. are good for a crowd of slow ships. Once fired they can't change direction but you decide when they explode. If the timing is perfect one explosion hits several ships and can even destroy them. Asteroids give you cover and the back of your ships are the most sensitiv part. I managed to destroy a big ship with two or three hits from my fighters in the back of the enemy.The research is very basic, 9 (if I'm not wrong) different techs which can be upgraded some levels. The results are weapons with more damage, faster engines and so on. No new weapons or other ships.You can build wonders, like in Civilization or Beyond Earth, but they do not cust so much. As far as I could see those wonders are powerful, one e.g. gives you clocked torpedos so the enemies don't see them anymore, which makes them even more powerful.Sooner or later you meet the AI players, they want to rule the galaxy too. The diplomacy is very basic (not that its counterparts in Civilization or Beyond Earth are better in my opinion, but...) and is like "hey, how are you, what have you done in the past, lets compare our genitals (fleet strengths, plantes, etc), do you want peace or war?". Sooner or later one AI will declare war on you and you must try to conquer their planets. Or go straight to their home world and end their suffering.The integration with Beyond Earth was promoted as a special feature. You need an extra 2K account for this (not sure if this hasn't been possible with Steam, but anyway). Then you are able to "continue" a save game from Beyond Earth in Starships. Not sure what this means in detail. I managed to unlock some kind of bonus in Beyond Earth, but haven't played this again. I'm sure they extend this feature over time and it might add some replay bonus to both games. We'll see.As I said at the top, don't expect too much. It costs only 15 bucks, I got it for 11 on GMG which is ok for the game. If you are unsure wait for a sale.

number of helpful: 9 of 21 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												This is a good game if you know what you are expecting. First, you need to put two things in mind: one, it's only $15, so don't expect some huge game like Civilization V or Beyond Earth; two it's not a Civilization game.Now with that out of the way, Starships to me, is a unique game that takes the gameplay from many other types of strategy and space faring games. I stated before it isn't a Civilization game, but it still borrows some of the game mechanics from Beyond Earth. It's still mainly just a turn based clicking game, with many different options to start your new game with to spice it up a little bit and to offer some diversity, such as the affinity system from Beyond Earth and the same leaders from it, too. I also like the new feature where you can interact between the two games.Now, to the pros. I've played a lot of Beyond Earth, and this game was still quite confusing when I started. It seems like it's very complex, but once you play the game for about fifteen minutes, you get the hang of it quite easily. Planets are like cities, and you can apply upgrades to your planets to increase science, metal (production), energy (money), and food. You also use the food to increase the population of your planet, which increases the production of all materials slightly, the only thing that's different in this aspect from Beyond Earth is it doesn't take time. The game is turn based, yes, but it mainly only applies to the battles. This game goes by much faster than a traditional Civilization game, which is good if you just want to kill a couple hours. The customization/upgrade system is pretty alright, too. You can use your materials to apply certain upgrades to certain ships which all have their own effect, you can upgrade the planet as said before, and you can instantly upgrade technology with your science points. There are also four ways to win: population, wonders, science, and domination. Also, another thing I liked is the map, I love the variety of planets and all the planets have their own special aspects to them that alter what they exactly do for you when you control them. And the missions you do for the uncontrolled planets are also pretty unique and fun. The game has no lag or glitches in it at all as long as you have a good enough computer to play.Cons, I'll make this short. I don't like that you can't trade with the other factions, you can't go through their territory at all unless you are at war which is hard if you don't like having war all the time, and the interactions with leaders are just pretty limited in general, all you can do is wage war, be at peace, see their progress, and very rarely do they offer you a technology if you fight someone for them. Unless you consider the uncontrolled planets as secondary factions, there are no secondary factions to interact with. You can't name the planets or ships if you're into that, either. Most of the wonders are very limited in their use, and you can only build one per planet and it depends on the planet you control.Conclusion, Starships is a pretty good game to play if you got a few hours to kill or are up at night and can't sleep and it's relatively easy to pick up and learn as well. While it has it's good things, it also has it's flaws, but in Starships, the good outweighs the bad for this one. For $15, you can't really expect a perfect game especially when Firaxis only put a few months into it, but they put good work into this game. While it serves somewhat as an expansion to Beyond Earth, it is it's own game entirely, and it's very fun and time consuming. Remember though before you buy, just because it has Sid Meier's name on the game does not mean it is a Civilization game, it is it's own game with it's own likeness. For $15, it completely worth it to me, and if you can catch this game on sale, I would definately get it.

number of helpful: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Ever since Civilization 5, the Firaxis team has been focused on a casual, arcade-like feel for their games. Civ V never had the intensity that Civ IV and before had, yet it was very agreeable to the eyes and had decent replayability. Moving onwards, we got Civilization: Beyond Earth. A pale comparison to Alpha Centauri, but still a fun game if you were in that arcade mentality. Firaxis continues the trend with Starships, a very simple and pretty game that is practically a tablet app game.Pros:- The visuals are stunning as usual, and seamless graphics for the most part- Very interesting use of tactics, looks like they took a page from their X-Com game- Once you get rolling, the game is straightforward and can bring that "one more turn... one more turn..." feeling that every Civ player has come to love and hate.- the variety of planet missions are great and makes every encounter different.- the save-link between Beyond Earth and Starships is a nice touchCons:- If you hoped for a intense space domination game, this might not be the best bet for you- It is really casual oriented, and that does give the feeling of emptiness and being unfulfilled after playing a game (which could last up to 3 hours)- space combat  does get monotonous, and once you fire torpedoes enjoy watching the AI scarmble right into your lasers.- Controlling only one massive fleet takes a lot of tactical potential away, especially on the large/epic maps if your fleet is on the other side of your federation and your planets get attacked.verdict:In the end, I did enjoy this game more then I hated it, and I hope with some modest mods the game can really shine, just like how the mods for Civ V have made it a new game entirely. If you go in with a asual, arcadey attitude, you will not be disappointed and will find this game enticing and refreshing. Just don't expect any long epic campaigns.

number of helpful: 85 of 177 people (48%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Straight from the Science Officer:---------------------------Sid Meier's Starships is the continuation to Beyond Earth. While BE was more focused on 4x empire management, Starships shifts gear to commanding a fleet of interstellar vessels as you run around completing missions in turn-based strategy fashion. In-depth customization of your ships' systems is the center of the game as lasers tear through your hull because you thought having maximum sensors was the smartest idea. While the tactical map is where you'll be battling, the galactic map is ultimately where you win the war. Here, you'll be competing for influence on various systems against your rivals from BE as you seek to rid the universe of their annoying one-liners. Victory is achieved by eliminating all of your rivals, controlling over half of the galaxy, researching enough technologies to the maximum tier, or spending enough industry to own seven wonders. "Yes Commander"---------------------------(+) Well thought out tactical gameplay - Do I stealth this turn? Fire my weapons? Launch torpedoes?  "Oooh let's hide behind this planet and when the enemy comes, charge guns blazing" (+) Great ship customization - With your fleet of ships, you'll be able to craft each ship to fit your battle plans. You could make a fleet of ships with many engines and long range weapons and kite the enemy or brawlers that hide behind a planet and charge out when the enemy nears. Maybe you'd like to have a stealth carrier that pops out, launches some fighters, and goes back into the void or a sensor ship to detect an enemy fleet that relies on stealth fighters. The options are vast. A bonus kudo goes to the fact the game auto-classes your ship based on its setup. A ship teethed with guns and armor will be labelled as a battleship while a fast ship with high damage would be an assault corvette. It just provides an additional, nice immersion feature.(+) Simplicity - While it can be argued that this is a negative as some people perhaps expected a complex 4x game reminisicent of MOO or Galciv, Starships is a game focused on ...Starships. The focus isn't on managing a large empire but instead on controlling your fleet and completing missions with that said fleet in order to build your empire. (+) Missions - There's a decent variety of missions so you won't get too bored until a few playthroughs. While the mission types get similar, the map and the ships in each mission can change.(+) Price - $15 (in the US) is a great price for a game like this. You'll definitely get hours of gameplay and like most Sid Meier's games, once you figure out the controls, it's hard to pay attention to real-life.(+) Bridge Visuals - Each bridge depending on which faction (harmony, purity, supremacy) you picked gets it's own unique bridge. It's a really small thing but it's something that definitely stands out."We'll get them next time..." ---------------------------(-) No Multiplayer - One of the things I was hoping to do was get a nice game going with some friends. The game definitely has unexploited MP potential. A decent size map can be finished with some friends in a day. It's not going to be like playing a MP match of Crusader Kings or EUIV which can last weekends on ends. The AIs only going to be able to be so unique on designing fleets.(-) One Fleet - Having only one fleet really limits strategic gameplay on the galactic map. There's not going to be any strategy where I can defend one location and fight in another on AI turns. I won't be able to create a fleet for defense and another for attack or specialize one fleet for certain types of missions. (-) Squishiness of Ships - Hopefully this gets sorted out but ships seem like they are glass cannons no matter how you build them at the moment. Unless you're literally building all armor / shields (which makes that ship pretty useless since it has no weapons), most ships die in a few hits. Fighters die in one shot from basically anything short of a maximum range pea shooter. This makes the tactical gameplay more arcadey and will hopefully be improved upon in later patches. (-) Lack of 'One More Turn' - A fundamental Sid Meier's feature. Sometimes you just want to continue but you win, victory, that's it. This was an easy feature that was just simply and unfortunately overlooked.(-) Modding Tools - There's a lot of potential for modding a game like this. It's not a stretch to imagine someone trying to recreate a Starfleet or Star Wars based mod if the tools are provided. Some of the best additions that enhance the value of old Civ games were fan-made maps and mods."Close Victory"---------------------------Overall I'd give this game a 6.5/10. The gameplay is addictive and the tactical battles are in-depth. Ship customization and fleet design is well-developed and serves as the main anchor for this game. Nontheless some pitfalls exists, mainly in the fact that there's no multiplayer in a game that would obviously benefit from having the ability to play a match against your friends. If you're expecting a big 4x game then you might want to stay away but if you want a quick game and you have a love of starships and fleet command then you should definitely pick it up. It's only the price of a dinner and you won't be eating tonight anyways when you're too addiced from playing.For future reference, this review was released on game release date and may be updated in the future.For those interested in a preview, I recorded some gameplay: 


YouTube™ Video: Long live the Space Revolution - Sid Meier's Starships - Episode 1 

			Views: 709		

			Thanks for watching everyone! Feel free to leave a comment and a Like if you enjoyed it and a Subscribe if for some reason you loved it and want to see more!		

Channel if you want more: https://www.youtube.com/user/xBr0wnBear
