content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												First off. Please don't let the "5-seconds after launch Negative Reviews" cloud your judgement of the title. They're the people spiteful about Beyond Earth feeling like a lesser Civ V and want to take it out on the developers they're suppose to love. This game is a cheap $15 for one, and what you get more than justifies the price as it's still complex and well-put together, like other 4X games, but revolves more on space combat while the resources Civ players are familiar with, gained through missions to other worlds and expanding your federation/empire are managed for the purpose of upgrading your soon-to-be armada that deserves "Empiral March" playing as they jump from hyperspace. That tight focus may honestly turn off hardcore Civ players but it's also a great middle ground for 4X fans that still might have trouble with the overwhelming concepts traditonal 4X throw at them off the bat and can become better aqauinted in this game. This game's connectivity with Beyond Earth makes that purpose seem almost intintional. So if you're looking for a game where you can simulate feeling like Tarkin commanding marine warfare from a Star Destroyer and being diplomatic with foreign worlds, and don't have a childish beef with Firaxis because one of the many godly games they made wasn't exactly they way YOU wanted it to be, this game is for you. And if you're still skeptical and have some chump change sitting, you can extend your library by 1 and try it for yourself. And once your comfortable with the mechanics, send me a game invite because I'm always down to play and my friends and I would love to fight for the galaxy with you until one Civ's left standing. Fight for your Civ and Empire! You're Admiral and you're it until you die or they find someone better.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												This is NOT an epic strategy game with the level of detail of a Civ 1-5 or a MOO (if you want to think of space strategy games). If you don't have those expectations upfront, then the game can be interesting in it's own way. At it's most basic level, Starships is actually "Ace Patrol" set in space with themes from Beyond Earth thrown in. The battle hex board layout is exactly the same as Ace Patrol, but the mechanics of how weapons play out is now space themed. There is definiely more detail here than in Ace Patrol when you look at all aspects of the game. There is a simplified research system, planets that are "upgradeable" to harvest more resources for upgrading your ships. All of this is simplified to a point where each aspect of the game could be thought of as an upgrade system, less discovery, and faster. The mission system is also simple and can get a little repetitive, but by mid-game it becomes only battles against other empires. This is a mobile game for the most part, but I don't mind playing a quick game on the PC when I have a moment. Some might say it's not worth $15, but that's actually cheap compared to the $50 epic game. For a fast playing strategy game with more depth than an "Ace Patrol", Starships is definitely worth it. The expectations around this game were poorly set up, so watch a gameplay video to decide if it's right for you.

I am looking forward to playing at harder difficulty levels.  And hey, there is a final animation for winning!

number of helpful: 11 of 26 people (42%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I knew before it was released that this game would be ranted and raged about on release. Why? Because a number of people had expectations which were completely out of line with the game that Firaxis promoted repeatedly on their YouTube channel.Sid Meier's Starships was announced as a tablet game with a PC version from the get-go, but a certain segment of gamers saw the name Sid Meier and convinced themselves that this game was going to be Civilization In Space (a.k.a. Sid Meier's Master Of Orion) despite all evidence to the contrary.Here's what it is: a simplified tactical space game with colorful graphics and impressive music. It has some depth -- it might be worth reading the in-game rules section to understand the game's strategic layer -- but it's basically a tactical starship battle game.Does the game have problems? Yup. The lack of a true fullscreen on PC, for example, really annoys me (you have to manually set your taskbar to auto-hide) but there's nothing wrong here on day one that a few, inevitable post-launch patches won't fix.So, if you're undecided, wait for the patching. Some people report not being able to start the game at all, but I've seen none of that here. (If it won't start, I've heard that skipping the opening cutscene may be a work-around)Day One Verdict? The things I like about Sid Meier's Starships outweigh the things I don't, by a fairly wide margin. I expect a number of issues to be corrected with patches, going forward. This isn't the next great strategy game -- it's a "play it for fast, fun starship battles" tablet game. You won't devote days and weeks of your life to this game, but I think Sid Meier's Starships does what it set out to do very well.

number of helpful: 24 of 53 people (45%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Coming into this game, my expectations weren't super high. There are some features that could be better, no doubt, but for what it is, and the short time that I played it at the time of writing this review, I do recommend it. Compared to other Civ games, it's light, but the features that are in it make it pretty fun (even though they could do with some touching up). It seems like most people don't like the game very much, but for it's price, if your a fan of Civ games and other space games as well, I'd say give it a shot. It's not the greatest by any means, but still worth a look. I'm sure with future patches, the game will get better (hopefully).Pros:-The ships for each affiliation (Supremacy, Harmony, Purity) look pretty good and when upgrading them, their look changes with each corresponding upgrade.-The way you get control of different planets is pretty cool (in my opinion)-A decent amount of leaders to choose from each with different bonuses-The battle and movement animations look nice and fairly smooth-Tactical battles are pretty fun, but may get boring quickly depending on who you face. (Pirates are a constant thing when it comes to the quests)-Easy to learn and understand the mechanics.Cons:-The camera control is pretty awful. I get it was made for mobile as well as PC, but really? You can only move the camera with the arrow keys and it's pretty bad, especially in battles.-Quests to control planets can get repetitive; most of the time it's just beating up pirates of some sort, though since I've only just started playing, it may change as you go along (doubtful though).-There are no graphical options at all, and the fullscreen mode (at least for me) shows my taskbar still at the bottom of my screen. Minor, but can be annoying.-The affiliations are cool, but I wish there was a little more variety with them. The only real difference I've noticed so far are different looking ships and a different starting bonus.-The research "tree" is...lackluster to say the least.That's about all for now. I'll update this review further as I play and as they patch the game in the future.Personally, I do recommend it, but don't expect a huge amount, cause it's not Civ, but nevertheless, it's still pretty fun to play.Thanks for reading, guys!-AwesomeOne

number of helpful: 7 of 18 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Note: Summary at the bottom of the review.First of all, you should know that Sid Meier's Starships is a game more reminiscent of the Ace Patrol series than the Civ series. Do not expect deep or complex gameplay here. What you CAN expect is a turn-based strategy game that delivers a "pick-up-and-play" experience, tied into the "Beyond Earth" story. The game is simple to get into, easy to learn and master, and perhaps not that challenging. This does however not stop it from being fun, but sadly there are some sides to the game that is, well, not shoddy. But perhaps not entirely well-thought out. There is little difference between the plasma cannons and the lasers (the two main types of weapons) in terms of visuals and mechanics, and you have no control over what your ships use. Close up? Plasma. Long range? Lasers. More depth would have been welcome. The maps do offer some nice mechanics (asteroids that block shots, "corridors" that open and close, wormholes that will teleport you and so on), but I still think they could have included gas clouds to hide in, rather than the (somewhat pointless) stealth system. One area where I've always felt that the Firaxis games has excelled, is in the "feel" of different factions. I may have missed something here, but it seems that your opponents are generic in the extreme in "Starships". You can fight them, or not fight them, but you probably won't care much about them whichever way you decide to go. And they won't really care about you and what you do, unless you fight someone they don't like (they'll give you something or other as an incentive) or you pass through one of their starsystems (which results in an immediate declaration of war). Pro: -"Pick-up-and-play" turn-based strategy.-Simple and fun in its own way.-Some pretty good ideas.Con:-Not very polished.-No real depth.-Abrupt ending.-Oversimplified game mechanics.-Not really great graphics.-Ship explosions are extremely lackluster.Summary:Sid Meier's Starships is a turn-based strategy that offers quick "pick-up-and-play", wrapped in a plain package and with mechanics that falls short of what they could have been. This is not deep strategy, but rather "Ace Patrol in space". Keep that in mind, and be ready to forgive the game its simplified graphics and gameplay, and you will likely find a fun little game underneath it all. You may want to wait for a sale before picking it up though, as it seems to me that it is a bit overpriced relative to what you get.5/10 -Recommended, if on sale.For more recomendations and reviews: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/strandedkerbonaut#curation

number of helpful: 5 of 14 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Simple and elegantFor the price I did not expect a game that would blow me away. I expected a polished simple single player experience and that is exactly what I got.At first I was slightly disappointed in the introduction video. It should at the very least scale up to 1080p, but it is a minor aestethic complaint. Next I was confounded by the "Settings". Basically you can only choose between windowed or fullscreen, and you can adjust various volume levels. Thats it. Further on it becomes obvious that you will not need any advanced settings for this game.Visually the game delivers a polished, clean and smooth experience. Various icons and symbols ties nicely in with Beyond Earth. Aduio effects are also very BEish.Strategically you manage planets and one fleet of spaceships through resources produced by said planets and rewards from missions. You have to choose missions wisely because you can only complete so many each turn and those you ignore will be completed by your neighbours.Tactically you move around and attack enemies on various "maps" generated for each battle and there are a handful of random elements thrown in for each battle.  You configure your ships offense based on preferred range and utility, and you have a few defensive options as well.The whole thing ties together nicely and offer a relaxed, balanced single player experience. I can easily recommend this game.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												It's a good little game, I'd buy it full price, but would recommend people buy it for sale. Reminds me of MoO2, only less depth, and alot shorter.It's the most basic of 4X games I've ever seen, and because, good. It polished its core very well, you need to explore to expand, and you need to exterminate your rivals to make sure you end up with a controlling majority of the galaxy. You explore other player by playing off know rivals, for boost in you tech or resources. I've only complete the one play through, and it took me roughly an hour. The controls took me about 15min to learn. Comparing it to MoO2, combat is hex-bases rather than square based, and you take on the role of fleet commander. Very similar to each other, and it was nice.The game is really basic, focusing on the core of what makes a 4X game, well, a 4X game, you can gain tech/recourses from fighting for a rival of a allied faction. I think we need to seem more games like this, games that focus on what makes a good 4X game, before we see another MoO3, or Galactic Civ game. Going to fair done the path of exploration, exploitation, or extermination.

number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I have never reviewed a game before, but after reading so many reviews of others, I wanted to express my opinion.  Whether or not I can recommend the game is dependent upon what you seek, and what your expectations are.  The biggest problem, from what I have inferred from reading reviews, is from disapointed expectations.  Civilization V and earlier Firaxis/Sid Meier games are nothing short of brilliant.  The entire Civilization series (and I have been there since its inception) could arguably be labeled the greatest PC games ever produced, from every which way you might want to analyze it: quality, depth, re-playablility, customization, fun, and strategy. If you are looking for Starships to have the depth, and strategy (long-term planning and maneuvering) to achieve the final victory, you won't find that here.  This is a simple game, almost more like an arcade game with some choice elements to be determined by your preference, such as do you want firepower or stealth?  But not the intricies of long-term grand scale strategy that Civ is famous for.  If you are anticipating even a scaled-down version of Civ, you will be disappoineted.  This is not a game of watching your grand design come to frutuion.   After having played several games of Civilization V, marathons that lasted more than 800 turns and a week of playing per game, I welcome being able to play a quick in-and-out game like this.  This is more complicated than Solitaire or Minesweeper, and can be similarly addicitve.  Starships is NOT trying to be Civ.  Perhaps Firaxis went too far away from strategy on this one, but I had fun with it.    Simple fun.However, I was really disappointed the way ship design and outfitting work.  When I first heard about this release , I thought back to one of my all-time favortie games, Master of Orion II, and shrilled at the prospect of a Sid Meier version of this.  In MOO2, you selected a ship class, which was an empty shell, and you chose how to outfit it, based upon the research you had done.  And even if you were capable of adding your Class X shields to your ship, you could have instead installed Class V shields, allowing more space for other modules (such as another array of lasers) and reducing its cost.   And there were several choices of laser technology to add, based on research and function.   In Starships, there are only lasers (long-range) and plasma cannons (short range), with only a nebulous upgrade by incrementing a level.  I was looking forward to specialized intricate ship design.  There is none of that, as this is the simplest system.  For me, the ship designing  in MOO2 was the most exciting part of any Space 4X game I have ever played, and what I was hoping  Starships would be.  Based upon my expectation, my desire, this game fails.Does this game have depth?  No.  Is the strategy a deep-thinking man's game like Civ?  No.  Was it fun?   Yes.    What you want from a game, the level of complexity and granularity you enjoy,  together with your expectation of Starships, will determine whether you think it is worth it ot not.    For some easy, casual and quick fun, Starships delivers.  But if you want this to be a CIv-like game, or somewhat like MOO2, complicated and full of strategic and tactical choices, it will not satisfy.

number of helpful: 15 of 35 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Let's be upfront about something: This is not a Civilization game, nor does it pretend to be. If you're looking for Alpha Centauri 2 or a rehabilitation of Beyond Earth that isn't a weak Civ5 mod, you're in the wrong place.If you want a board game to play on your computer, then this is exactly what you're looking for.Starships is a compact game probably designed primarily for mobile devices. And you know what? There's nothing wrong with that. Where Starships excels is in its vision and execution of making a game that recreates the board game experience.What's so elegant about Starships is that it takes common board game mechanics and takes advantage of the fact that since the game is being run on a computer, it can develop those mechanics to new heights. Developing planets as your resource generators very much mirrors how a board game might have a chart where you move tokens around to determine how much you get per turn. Special abilities function like cards drawn out of a deck, and the map looks like a game board. Even the victory condition, "Control 51% of the map" sounds like something out of a board game.The combat is simple but deep. You get full customization of your units, and you move around on a hex grid shooting at each other with stuff like line of sight, distance, and cover to calculate. It would be unmanageable as a tabletop game (unless everyone playing is a total Warhammer junkie), but as a video game it's very easy to let the computer do all the calculations for you.Like any game worth its weight, the rules are very simple to understand after a turn or two, but there's enough nuance to them that you'll be spending quite a few hours understanding how to optimize everything and adjust on the fly.Major strikes against the game: Missing a lot of basic computer game functions (come on, let me up the resolution!) and no multiplayer. The latter is pretty bad, but then again, it takes a very special group of people to have the patience to sit through a multiplayer 4X game.In short: It's a board game. Don't fool yourself into thinking otherwise. But it is a great board game that takes advantage of not forcing the players to calculate anything on the fly, and blossoms because of that. If you even enjoy the occassional game of Settlers of Catan, this is probably a game you'll enjoy.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												If you can handle knowing there is a Sid Meiers game that isn't very complex then you might enjoy this spin off title.  I was pretty skeptic when I started playing, but it grew on me a bit.  Imagine an odd combination of Beyond Earth, Risk, and any of the better mobile games out there and thats what Starships is. You are mainly going from planet to planet completeing one of the 4-5 combat missions (elimination, escort, escape... etc) and then slowly taking over the galaxy. You upgrade your starships and planets via resources you gather from the planets and move on. It will be much more straight forward than any other Sid Meiers game. But if you go into knowing its pretty much a glorified mobile game, then you might just enjoy and keep playing.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												ENGLISH"Sid Meier's Starships" is like these three parents become a baby: "Civilization - Beyond Earth", "Star Wars - Empire at War" and "Strange Adventures in Infinite Space" (which had a sequel: "Weird Worlds")!Civ-BE contributes a background story and the Optics.SW-EaW adds the idea, that everything takes place in an entire galaxy. You just see the planets, but you can only see the appropriate suns are only visible in the ultra-cool space combat mode.And SAiIS delivers the general feeling! You are put into the role of a Fleet Commander, assigned to a spacefaring civilization. Your civilization is always called "United Federation". It's purpose is to spread its light over all other planets in the galaxy. Unlike SAiS you have up to six opponents, who try to do the same things like you.In "Starships" you always control exactly one fleet, consisting of a handfull of ships. You're heading from one quest to the next with these ships, until - after a while - it hopefully turns out, that you've been better than your opponents.I can raise my thumb for "Starships", for I like the immersion (that means: "atmosphere") of the game and because - being a 35-year old Gamer - I worship Sid Meier as a God! The game is cheaper than Sid Meier's unforgotten milestones, so don't expect a pretentious masterpiece, that makes history.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------DEUTSCH"Sid Meier's Starships" ist so, als ob diese drei Eltern ein Baby bekommen hätten: "Civilization - Beyond Earth", "Star Wars - Empire at War" und "Strange Adventures in Infinite Space" (dem späteren "Weird Worlds")!Civ-BE liefert die Hintergrund-Story und die Optik.SW-EaW liefert die Idee, dass alles in einer kompletten Galaxie geschieht. Man sieht die Planeten, aber die dazugehörigen Sonnen sieht man bestenfalls im überaus coolen Raumkampfmodus.Und SAiIS liefert das Spielgefühl! Du schlüpfst in die Rolle des Flottenbefehlshabers einer raumfahrenden Zivilisation, die beschlossen hat, ihr Licht auf allen anderen Planeten zu verbreiten. Du erkennst Deine Fraktion immer an dem unveränderlichen Namen "Vereinte Föderation", aber im Unterschied zu SAiS hast Du bis zu sechs Gegenspieler, die das Gleiche wollen, wie Du!In "Starships" kontrollierst Du immer genau eine Flotte, bestehend aus einer Handvoll Raumschiffen. Mit denen kämpfst Du Dich von Quest zu Quest, bis sich irgendwann hoffentlich herausstellt, dass Du besser warst, als Deine Kontrahenten.Da ich Wert lege auf Immersion (sprich: Atmosphäre) und als 35-jähriger Gamer den guten alten Sid Meier als Gott verehre, kann ich meinen Daumen nur heben! Das Spiel kostet weniger als Sid Meier's unvergessliche Meilensteine, also erwarte kein pompöses Meisterwerk, das in die Geschichte eingehen wird.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
This is really sad that people were expecting a new 4X game and didn't care to try to understand what was acheived with this game. Guys if you are real fans of Sid's work go watch videos he did playing the game himself and explaining what it is and stop giving bad reviews to a great game simply because you didn't take 5 minutes to inform yourself before buying it.Now, to the review:This game is a fast paced strategic & tactical game with a very small learning curve, it offers to have great time on this type of game in a short period of time and it does it really well.What other strategy game feels both elaborated in style, content and gameplay but is at the same time simple enough to almost feel casual ? (and no, there are no great mobile strategy games except maybe chess, and side note games of type build something and pay or wait aren't games and even less strategy games, they are a steal and should be deemed internationnaly illegal, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥it)In Civ: Starship instead of building an empire and the story of a world, you build a victory.Game feels polished (noticed a couple tiny bugs but nothing anywhere close to game breaking, i'm just picky on this because i'm in game dev myself), and is really well optimized.Ships are low poly and haven't heard of dx11 :( but visually better than up close models in BE and don't feel as disapointing.Regardless of what people are saying, all this game misses is competitive multiplayer and that doesn't take away from it that it's an awsome game in his own gender, aside from the franchise.To be honest, I thought I'd be as disapointed by this as I was with BE, but it turned out to be the complete opposite and I'm already loving the game. It's a total surprise how great it is, i didn't believe someone could pull it off.My last game almost felt like playing a board game. I can't wait for the next half hour i'll have to poor into this :)Sid if you ever read this, I'm really sorry so many people are blinded and don't understand it but you did an awsome job. Thank you.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												I just downloaded starships and played a few games. This game is awesome! I don't get people who are complaining that this game isn't enough like the civ games...seriously...one of the biggest criticisms of critics regarding beyond earth was its supposed overly similar interface and gameplay (to civ 5). So sid releases a game that is only loosely based on beyond earth (factions, faction bonuses) and all of a sudden this game doesn't play the same as beyond earth or civ 5? wow..talk about hard to please....Anyways back to my review:The good-This game is very tactical (the battlefield has asteroids/planets you can use as cover (to hide behind) and blocking players shots (some weapons can shoot through minimal asteroid fields but then the dmg you take is reduced (it feels good when the comp tells you you have only a 35% chance to complete a mission given your current situation (*ships/upgrades etc) and you still manage to pull it off!-upgrades on planets provide good strategic options (as planet wonders affect your economy, ships, battle, income, repair costs etc the list goes on...)-The ai is pretty sneaky and will come by and try to undermine your influence on planets that haven't been won over to your side yet-upgrading your ships even has some strategy too it (do you upgrade existing ships to have more movement points, higher shield, better weapons, cloaking, sensor range etc) vs buying a completely new ship and thus increasing your overall fleet size-fleet sizes don't seem to get too big, so its easy to manage, and the combat is really fun. of course you have to like turn based hex based combat to enjoy this (but what are you doing buying a sid meier game if you dont'? lol)-the ai will ally with other players against you (but its still not impossible to win...just hard) - so the challenge is there if you want it (as i only played on normal and i found it challenging) -the graphics are pretty good, and the animations look cool (lol its like  startrek but without familiar ship designs)-various parts of your economy to manage (balancing metal (to improve defenses/planets, food (to increase city sizes (and thus increase resource generation), energy (to upgrade your ship) and science points (to provide general upgrades to your entire fleet- all of the crap is pared away with this game..no random stats or updates on your planet populations mood/ or any of that garbage..this has been replaced with the morale of your starships troops (they fight less effectively until you give them shore leave (effectively this is the end turn button)..enemy does its turns and then you receive your planet income and start your new turn (with all morale restored). There is a wonder you can build on your planets so that your starship crew fights at max level no matter the level of fatigue (this is def something to research.). -the defense of your planets is handled well (you buy planet defense upgrade (its called a megabot or something) and they are basically extra ships that will assistn you in defense of a planet (good thing to upgrade...lol). the bad-it would be nice if i could adjust the graphics options (even though it does look really good lol i like the ability to make it even better..thats why i bought an expensive pc....-the trainer (i.e. tutorial) is ok...but doesn't tell you everything you need to know...(tutorial is only a few popups and ends with telling you to click the info button (and it then gives you a suggestion of what to do). Some things i had to figure out for myself (most of it is intuitive so you will figure it out just by playing a game or two) but a little more help would have improved the experience for people who don't want to waste any time figuring out little details (for instance i didn't know i could improve defenses...build cities etc until i started clicking buttons to see what did what), i also didn't realize i could buy a new ship (instead of just improving the ones i had), i didn't know if i could have more than one fleet (it doesn't seem like you can) and it wasn't super obvious to me if i had to manually change weapons in combat (lasers for long range, photon something for close range and torpedoes for really far) lasers/photons activate when you go to attack the enemy by themselves (i.e. if its too far for photons you shoot lasers and vice versa). Torpedoes are weird in that you do activate it manually but when you shoot them (at first they dont' do anything...you have to wait until your next turn to manually detonate it or move it forward more) you have 2 turns to either move it forward a bit more or detonate it (after 2 turns it detonates by itself). generally people see them coming but you can move out of the way...unless you get the planet wonder that makes them perma stealthed (which is awesome). (ok this was long but basically as you can see..woulda been nice if the game just told me some of that stuff..but you figure it out pretty easy. - not much story here...at all (if you care about story this may irritate you)Overall, this game is pretty awesome...its fun to play, different enough from normal sid meier games that its refreshing, but familiar enough that you won't be completely lost if you have played a 4x strat game before. Definitely recommend this game! just buy it already!...at 17 bucks its less than half of what i paid for beyond earth and is just as fun so its a great price point for a game that has a surprising amount of depth at a price thats cheaper than going to a movie at the theater.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Starships builds on the Civ franchise, but is utterly dissimilar from the rest. This is a good thing, judging by the Beyond Earth backlash and the entertainment value of the game itzself. Instead of a slow, highly technical game, Starships brings an experience that, while having many of the 4X elements, feels more like an odd meld of XCOM and turn-based RPG. The game may be rather fleeting (no pun intended) at this point, with seemingly few true options for victory other than domination, but provides a fun, new experience that proves its worth.

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												If you like turn-based fights on tiled (hexagon) maps there's a lot of fun to be had in this game.  Not super complex, but enough so as to make you consider which planet to invade or which upgrade to buy for your ships or which wonders to build in your empire. Games last anywhere from about 30 minutes to a few hours depending on difficulty and galaxy size. If you remember the ship combat from Master of Orion 2, this game is similar to that. The wonders in this game taking the place of some of the more exotic ship components from the earlier game. No one aspect of the game would be enough to win an award by itself, but everything is competent, pretty and the level of polish is excellent as you would expect from Firaxis. All in all, a really good value for just $15.

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I am very thankful I paid no attention to any of the hype for this game.. why? Because I didn't have undue expecations, so I think this game is fun! Yes, its simple.. its meant to be. Thats a good thing to me (and I play a lot of very complex deep games). The menu is sparse? Well.. its meant to be simple, so why would a simple game have a complex menu? You can easily playthrough a whole game in one night.. and again, thats not a bad thing! Its a quick and simple setup "boardgame" style and thats what makes it great! What more could you want for just $15? I have played every. single. sid meier. game. ever. And this game is not bad. Is it alpha centauri in space? No. Its not meant to be. No its not perfect, no game is anymore, not at launch anyway (devs need real feedback from players first, they can't read out minds). I think this game has a lot of potential down the road, especially with integration into civ: beyond earth. A few things I would like to see is a bit more information for the missions before I send my fleet there... some of those missions are brutal! Also, more than one fleet would be especially nice. The game is playable with only one fleet of ships though. Bottom line: if you want a fun, simple, quick and easy(ish) game for cheap that ties into civ: be that can be played in an evening than this is good game for that. If you enjoy tactical turn-based battles and some micromanagment thats not overly complicated this game is good for you. I could easily see this as an actual boardgame someday too, complete with starship figures!

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												I spent a few hours playing this today. I have not played Beyond Earth. I've enjoyed the game so far.What it is:A $15.00 space title, with tactical combat, decent graphics, and some compelling aspects.Ship customization (modular)Tech TreeLightweight turn based systemLow maintenance.This is a great game to play on your ipad or machine when you have a couple of hours to burn and want to unwind after work. It is not a Civ game and will not have that level of cmplexity. I think it has potential to be very moddable if they make that an option.Now with that said there are some things people need to know:The tech tree is very imited and has no appreciable effect outside of combatThe game centers around space combat and gathering territoryYou can only have 8 ships and they always travel as a groupIt can feel a little rinse and repeat in the late game on Epic stick to shorter gamesNone of those things surprise me this is not a $50.00 game. What it does not have is any bugs I have found, it performs perfectly, and I have had fun playing it. I like space games, I like to unwind, I do not like to feel like I am managing an empire when I get off work during the week. This is exactly what I expected when I bought it, I watched a lot of game play videos from the creators before buying.I suggest if you like science fiction and want something to play thats simple and fun. Give it a try, watch a few videos first if you are unsure.If however, you are expecting the next Orions, Civ in Space, Galactic Civ or what have you then you will be dissapointed. It plays like a lightweight X-Com in space. This would not be a game for you.Hope this helps!

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Sid Meier´s  StarshipsThe goodIts a fast pace Sid Merier´s game, it uses alot of mechnics featured in Civ V and Beyond Earth, however its simplified in order to make turns faster and easier. Which i feel make it a good addition to the CiV franchise for those day you dont want  to spend hours or days to play a CiV campaing. Building and maintaining your fleet is easy and quick, upgrading cities and building improvements are easier then ever.  I find it alot of fun.The BadJust like Beyond Earth the different faction personalities lack character, and arent that interesting, unlike its more historical predecessor,BE and Starships dont have humanitys rich history to draw upon in the players imagination and give us instead a barebones universe. I love sci-fi but there is so little lore in this game that can draw you in it quickly becomes a very sterile experience. Starships also lack true fullscreen and a decent options menu.The UglyThe graphics are functional and colorful, but i cant say the game is especially pretty.The VerdictSid Merier´s Starship is a lightweight mobile game that aimd in providing a on the fly fast CiV experience. I think the game achives it goals. It lacks the strategic depth and richness of the other civ games, but it has fairly enjoyable in shortbursts. Its the Sid Meier´s game you choose to play on  the train, before you go to school, a late friday night before a date or a party, If you dont like that idea and want something more substantial, i would not buy this game. However if you want affordable, fast paced tactics game Sid Meier`s starship provides that.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Despite what others have said this game is great. Why they link it to Pirates is unknown to me, it is more like Civ meets Air Patrol. The civ part requires very little management and the fleet system is so much fun to customize. By customize I don't mean the look of the ships, rather how tough, fast, how many hangars, etc. And if you want to reduce points you spent from say stealth to engine, you can in no time flat.It does lack fullscreen mode at this point. But I've played worse games in fullscreen and some awesome games in windowed mode. I'd like to see it added, but I am not gonna whine and say it ruins the whole game. That's extremely petty when the game has much to offer to keep you busy.I think some folks are getting a bad impression of this game because of the lack of micro-management. To me that gets you in to the action that much faster, which is the point of this game. I've already spent hours conquering the galaxy. The maps aren't very huge, in this type of game they don't need to be. You don't have to exhaust yourself building 40 structures from the ground up like you do in Civ, that's a major plus for me. Although I love Civ, I didn't need another one so soon.For the current cost of the game, it is great. It can use some polish, what game can't use some 5 years after it's launched?Update: I expected to get some down votes, can't expect children to understand simple logic with out getting their panties in a bunch I guess. Bottom line, the game is worth the money, don't expect to be wow'ed. It's a simple game, lots of fun.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												First let me put your mind expectation on the right track..This game only cost $10 (at least from my currency to USD) Price might differ from region to region. Anyway from the Game price.. you will know its not a Super Expensive Triple "A" game that cost around $60 and Above. So the Game experience is what you get from a $10 game.. nothing more nothing less =). Even thou it have a Sid Meier's name on it.. it still a $10 game. So put your Expectation in $10 range hahaSo is it a good $10 Game?Yes! The game is worth it. Its a fun game.. more of a casual stratergy game. I myself finish a Game in 3 Hours on Normal difficulty. There is some replayable value to it as well. You have the 3 faction.. Harmony, Supremacy and Purity. Each faction have a different ability and Each faction have 8 hero with different Hero skill. Not bad for a $10 game =)Pros:* Fun tactical game. Simple but engaging enough. You want to be stealth shot from a far.. or.. you want to be a Tanker close up and personal. All up to you =)* Simple and Great Ship customization. The ship will reflect your build.. Add armor for more HP.. your ship will look buffy and Tanky * Simplicity done right. It does not feel overwhelming. Simple yet engaging* Price.. its a $10 game with tons of fun =)* lots of Mission.. There's variety of missions for you to do.. you won't get bored until a few replays =)Cons:* No Multiplayer thou.. but for me its optional..* You basically play with only One Fleet.. kinda limit your stratergy. I wish we have more =)* Some bugs as usual. but i bet it will be Fix soon enough

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Fianlly being able to play Starships after watching hours of livestream from Firaxis, it's exactly what I was expecting it to be. With a not-too-complex playstyle, Starships is a fun short-game alternative to the Civ:BE universe akin to Ace Patrol (only with a bit more simplistic battle mechanics). Also, there's the added bonus of cross-game rewards between Civ:BE and Starhips, although I've yet to figure out how that system works precisely. Some bonuses are straightforward, and other pop-ups I've gotten saying I've unlocked something left me a bit perplexed. I've found that in order to have a worthwhile run of a game lasting more than an hour I have to restrict myself to Domination victory, at which point one can accrue a rather sizable fleet which on harder difficulties can make for interesting battles with the AI. So, bearing in mind the $15 price tag, understand what you're getting into if you're on the fence about this one. And not that there's multiplayer plans I'm aware of, if such a thing happens that would add leagues of value to the game overall.

												This game is underatted by far yes its a simple game but absolutely solid in AI performance and core mechanics sure the settings and window could be improved sure they will with a patch.Its to simple they say yes its supposed to be I found the most fun in the fleet battles and different missions I really did enjoy this game that moment when your best ship gets blasted to peices by three enemy ships at once, it seems well balanced.The main map is well designed easy to understand lack of tutorial is helped by simple advisor mechanic and initial screen shots showing the basics of the game so you don't need a tutorial this game is already easy enough to understand.I played and beat very quickly well thats the point replayability setting up your own game victory condition choosing your difficulty through games can last a few hours.Building a fleet is easy you start with base ships and through various options you can choose to speciallise them I.E ship carrier, heavy Battleship so on reccomend long range.The A.I seemed very competant just played on easy so far to get the feel of the game reccomend you just dive in and have fun with it well worth the price of £10.99 not £30 so don't be exspecting a AAA game.To most of the negative reviews there was plenty of Videos information about the game to know what it was about hell even the steam store page pretty much sums up the game well so you have only yourselves to blame don't put people of who would like the game.overall solid 6/10 high replayability easy controls hard to master, look forward to more games like this very refreshing

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Sid Meier’s Starships is simple and to the point. It's a hex based strategy game focused around fleets of starships. Don't expect the moon, but what's here is pure and well developed. The mechanics are clear and intuitive, as with any Sid Meier creation. You use your fleet to garner influence with planets by either performing missions or taking shore leave there. The planets provide resources and can be upgraded in a few ways. Combat is turn based. Your ship's shields are weak in the back and strong in the front. Asteroid fields either block sight completely or reduce it. Weapons vary with long range lasers, short range cannons and torpedoes that cover a finite amount of space per turn. Researchable technologies are tied to specific ship systems and planetary wonders affect a given gameplay mechanic. It's streamlined down to a fault, but it's a fault they're not trying to hide from you. This is a $15 game made with tablets in mind as much as a PC. The games are quick in comparison to the ‘oh it’s dawn now’ syndrom that’s inherent to the Civilization franchise which is refreshing.I’ve only played two games with harmony so I haven’t played around with the other two affinities. The easy difficulty is extremely easy, so I’d recommend going hard or in the least normal. Though easy is a safe way to get a feel for the game. I’ve also only used a couple of the commanders, but their special bonuses seem balanced enough tied to the right playstyles.This is a good and purposely small game. It’s fun and quick and I really can’t say anything too negative about it. There’s no deception by Firaxis trying to build it up into something more than it is. But it’s inevitable that the game’s disinterest with being bigger than it is will bother a number of people. Thankfully it’s interested in what it is beyond the backlash.

												I want to start off by saying I gave this a good recomendation - but only just good.The game is fun - there's no doubting that; but there's something missing from the game. No clue how it was over so fast... :(The graphics are great - the sound is fine - but there's something lacking and so far, I can't put my finger on it.  I really hope firaxis rebalances and puts more ... well, whatever it is that's missing that I can't just put my finger on... into it.The end result:  It's not civ v, it's not beyond earth.  It is fun, but it's just a lunch break game that you probably won't win most of the time (or so it seems)

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												After reading some of the other recent posts about this game I have edited my review:This game is for casual gamers not for veterans of Galactic Civs or Sword of the Stars are anything remotely on that level. I am a little disappointed that some gamers compare epic games (that cost 60 USD) to this 15 dollar offshoot of Beyound Earth. If you are looking for a an hour to kill this could be for you. If you are looking for 3 hours to get lost in go Mod a copy of Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion.One hour in and counting:Pros:15 USD excellent value Starship customizationGraphics are solid Munition animationsGood Voice ActingIntelligent Diplomacy with aggressive AIPlanetary missions have a sense of urgency (if you wont help them a rival will and soon)Lots of detail without being overwhelmingVery Fluid Gameplay (not nearly as micromanaging as some 5x space strategy)Cons:Surprising hardware requirements (Less stable than Endless Space)Cannot Rename Planets or starships (There is a reason for this, planetary names are spoken aloud adding to voice acting quality)Limited scope compared to space strategy genreOverall: Excellent buy for 15 USD. Simple to enjoyable to those outside the genre. Detailed enough for regular strategy players. In summary: More than the sum of its parts

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Fun game but not very deep. If your looking for a Civ in space thats not this game. More a guilty pleasure game with great graphics and some stratedgy working the battle field. I played on the second easiest level and once I figured out how to play it wasn't much of a challenge so far. I love how you can customize the ships to what battle style you like but was a little peeved you can only have one fleet. Or did I miss something? The options for the planets seem daunting at first but on the level I played at you really didn't need to upgrade them much. Why upgrade them when you can just as easily and with a lot more fun take over a new planet? On my level, it seems that if you make peace with everyone but the people your fighting, you are good to go. I am currently third in ranking as far as the percentage I need to win but all I need to do is attack the ones ahead of me to correct that. I seem to have the strongest fleet quit by accident as I built it before I knew what I was doing. LOL.I give it two thumbs up if you accept the game for what it is. A fun short period of time killer thats great to look at and easy to win. On my level any way. I will bump up the level next time and see if it's much harder.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Because bullet points are cool:---Advantages---+Simple, but not overly simple gameplay mechanics: Click and move. Click and shoot. Resources = fleet upgrades. Get more planets = get more resources = more ships and upgrades+A nice variety of starting customization+Lots of starship upgrades for those who are into that+Battles look cool+Buildable Wonders that grant additional tactical capabilities---Drawbacks----Really short-Poorly balanced: Let me elaborate on this one. Some wonders are just too overpowered. 2-non-attack-actions-per-turn wonder+Full-Fighter-Movement-On-Launch = Swarm all your enemies with fighters on turn 1-Really random at start: Every wonder have a few specified planets where it could be built, so you can get some nearly-useless wonders at your first planets on your first run, and the above-described combo on the next one. Some with missions, as some missions are easier than the others.-No multiplayer--------------------Overall, i have enjoyed the game because i love turn-based strategies and because i simply ADORE upgrading stuff. Despite some serious drawbacks, it is still really enjoyable and i would give this game 7 points out of 10

												A like, with a but - so far it's thin, a bit buggy, etc. There's a fun game here, and an interesting board game style starship combat that I found really fun, but it may require patches, adjustments, etc.There's just not a lot to do here yet, but what there is to do I enjoy. So I'm going to give a tentative thumb to Sid Meyers enthusists, board game enthusists, Gotta have every starship people, and "I buy every game collectors."If you're wishywashy on it, wait and see how patching goes - Sid does a good job of steering into user issues and games often come out with low scores and end up masterpieces via udpates/freeLC (or sometimes DLC that later becomes free.)I'd like to see the team add more content, more story, fix some bugs and generally improve the title however - but the bones of a fun game for people who play these sorts of games exists here and the price of entry is fairly low. (as of now) For enthusists and boardgame freaks only.

												This game does not have as epic of a scope as the main CIV games do, but its still a very fun game to play.  Its very simple and it took only a couple turns into it before I could get all of the mechanics.  The game goes by quick, but if you like strategic combat, this game does pretty well.  Everytime you build a ship, you start with the same template, but the amount of customization you can put into it can lead you to some really interesting tactics in space battles.If you were hoping for a 4x with a lot of empire managment, dont get this game.  The game revolves almost solely on space battles.  But if you love intense strategic turn-based combat, you will enjoy it.The only real things I would change about the game is:1) Allow fullscreen. (You can maximize the window, but that doesnt really count)2) Subtract $5 from the price.Despite these two things, its worth trying out if you dont mind spending $15 on it.  Just dont expect to be spending hours on it in one sitting.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Starships is simply brilliant.  The game is tightly focused on the tactical missions, which is the whole point. The strategic layer is intentionally light to keep most of the playtime in the battles, where it belongs.The missions and ship configurations are varied enough to keep the game interesting through many iterations.Starships is short.  A standard map game can be finished in a few hours, even a huge map game will take a tiny fraction of the time needed to play Civilization. Short is good. I love Civilization, but I can count one hand the number of games of Civ5 I've actually been able to finish in the last two years. And more often than not  Civilization ends with a grinding game of attrition or acumulation of culture points that is simply not that much fun. The strategic game in Starships does a good job of avoiding this kind of slog. The action in Starships builds steadily throughout the game until a satisfying climax in a decisive big fleet battle (at least in my games so far.)There is no multiplayer. This is also a good thing. If you really want a multiplayer online TBS game with both a strategic/political level and a tactical battleboard, then IMHO you really, really have way to much time on your hands and need to get a life. I strongly recommend Starships.I do have two minor quibbles. First, players cannot rename their ships (or I haven't yet figured out how.) Second, the game could use an empire management screen/table to make it easier to find and develop your planets on the larger maps.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												I have owened every Sid Meier game made.  I am a fan.  I am a Civilization Fan as well.   I am also a turn based fan in general.  That said I haven't been near the fan of Civ: BE as prior Civ games, and was a disappointed with it.  That said when I heard about Starships I was interested though I didn't jump on it like I would normally have done.  That said when GMG offered a great sale on the game for just over $10 prior to release I went ahead and figured what the heck and picked the game up.   First off I do believe that Starships was going to be an expansion or even part of Beyond Earth.  Does it feel like a AAA game?  No, but then again it is not selling at AAA prices.   Does the fact that it is tablet friendly make it less of a fun game? No I don't think so.   Is the game complex?  No, but it is fun for when you want to kick back and just have a relaxed turn based game. I know that the game is getting mixed reviews, however I haven't seen any bugs in the game, and have enjoyed it for the small amount of time I have been playing it so far.  Is it ground breaking?  Not  in the least.  But for even the asking price I have hundreds of games that I paid double the price for and found far less entertaining.  The game isn't something I see myself playing every day.  To me it is going to be one of those games that I turn to when I am watching TV and have other distractions yet want something to do when I don't feel like forwarding through commericals.  That said if you like space games, and like Turn Based games, I personally feel the game is worth the money as is.

												Here are my first impressions:+The gameplay and everything concerning it that I've played thusfar (ship building, combat, quests, etc.) is spot-on and very enjoyable. If there are new features added (more quests, longer gameplay options, etc.) alongside the UI fixes, this game could go all the way to "Played Once A Day."

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												For what it is, this is a decent little game. The combat has a surprising amount of nuance for the simplicity of the rules, and the visual effects, while being light enough for older systems, are nicely pretty.The range of starting options also means that there's a lot of different approaches in the game, different starting conditions that you can control - as well as all the random variation that you can't control.It's not a civ game, it's not MOO-like (or GalCiv-like, or SotS-like) - it's all about the adventure and tactical combat, with some light 4X-like elements to tie it all together.And I'm having a lot of fun with it. There are some rough edges, like the lack of an 'exit game' control on the main menu, and no true-fullscreen (only fullscreen window, and that isn'r borderless), but then it's not a game to play for hours and hours on end, but 20-60 minutes here and there.But I'm also going to have to go back to BE to get as much as I can out of it - some minor content elements are locked until you do something in BE to unlock them.

												If you're looking for a positive review, then you're in the wrong place, HOWEVER, if you're here for a tremendous chicken Stir Fry recipe, THEN LOOK NO FURTHER!- Serves 4- 10 mins to prepare and 10 mins to cook- 325 calories / serving- HealthyINGREDIENTS:- 1 orange, zested and juiced- 2tbsp soy sauce- 2tbsp sesame oil- 250g (8oz) tender stem broccoli- 5cm (2in) piece root ginger- 1tbsp sunflower oil- 1 garlic clove, finely sliced- 1 red pepper, deseeded and thinly sliced- 150g Straight To Wok Noodles- 400g (13oz) chicken fillet, cut into thin slicesMETHODStep 1 - Mix together the orange zest and juice, soy sauce and sesame oil and set aside.Step 2 - Blanch the broccoli in boiling water for 2 minutes, then drain well and set aside.Step 3 - Finely shred the ginger. Then heat a large frying pan or wok, add the sunflower oil, heat it until sizzling, and fry the ginger till it's crisp.Step 4 - When it's done, remove with a slotted spoon. Add the chicken and garlic, and stir-fry until just browned. Remove the meat using a slotted spoon and set aside.Step 5 - Add the red pepper and broccoli and stir-fry for around 2-3 minutes until it's just tender. Add the soy sauce mixture, bring it to the boil then return the chicken to the pan and heat through. Serve with noodles.

Posted: November 19, 2015
												 This is one of those games I keep coming back to.  Think of this game more along the lines of a computer based board game in line with Risk and Settlers of Catan.  It is more casual than intense.  I am an avid Civ player and play other 3X games.  If you read any of Sid Meir's notes he did not intend for this game to be an intense massive tech tree brain melting game. This is part turn based strategy part RTS. I can walk away from the game then come back after months of not playing.  I am a pretty big fan of this game.  Is it CIV no, but it is just plain fun to play without all the overlly how did i do that before strategy games. If you want a fun game you can just jump into that has good strategy this is it.  You don't have to spend hours learning a tutorial.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												Meh. Not worth it.I saw Sid Meier on the title, and thought to myself: "A cheap sid Meier Game? Maybe it will be like Pirates; simple but tons of fun..." The simple part was accurate.Over all, it attemps to be a 4X game, but the resources are interchangable and may as well be labeled A, B, C and D for all they affect game play. Combat isn't too bad, but once you get the hang for the mechanics, the strategy is straightforward, and the A.I. acts erratically, sometimes running from you when they should charge in. Also, you know those ships you blew up last turn? they will attack the same system again, and you will have to fight the exact. same. battle. with the exact. same. ships. over... and over again. The only way to break that monotony is to destroy the A.I.s homeworld, and poof! all their planets are belong to you. Did I mention you only get one fleet? it's ok though, because it somehow manages to cover the entire galaxy (through a re-enforcement mechanic, but still".The "wonders" you can build have no back story/picture/etc. you just click build, and poof! it's built? You don't actually see anything happen, so it's kind of an assumption. This is kind of a theme, as the races/leaders/affinities are identical aside from pittance starting bonuses. Past that, no impact on gameplay. Since this was kind of hyped as you could "continue your journey" from the beyond earth, it was a huge let down. Save your money.

												I got this game in a bundle when I bought Beyond Earth and I've put off playing it for some time because there are a lot of negative reviews that make it out to be a terrible game. After having played it I have to say I enjoyed it. It is by no means Ci goes to space and if that is what you go into it expecting you will be dissapointed.However, what it is, is a nice casual space ship game with some empire control thrown in. Mostly the management comes from building cities, improvements, and wonders in the world in your federation as well as upgrading and buying your ships. The combat is fun, it's nothing ground breaking but still enjoyable and over all it is a game you can play in a short amount of time.For someone who enjoys spaceships and casual games this is something I find to be a lot of fun. I'd suggest if you see it onsale or you end up with it because you bought BE and it came bundled in give it a shot it you might enjoy it too.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												Recomended but not at full priceThe game its self is fairly fun but be mindful of your expectations.Think of this as a mobile friendly snack not a full on civ game or even a full on game of any type. Gameplay is simple, easy to pick up and prety easy to master to and thats not bad if you go at this thinking ... casual time sink in the civ beyond earth theme ... because thats what it is and that fills a nice nitch honistly. Thus far I have had 0 luck with any integration between civ beyond earth and starships but honistly I dont care about that aspect.Ship/Fleet building is very simple really its just a matter of adding more to your current set while technologies are simply making what you have a bit stronger/more efficent.Battles come in a handfull of flavors, kill everything, avoid death, and goaly e.g. keep enemy away from this. It fits well given the scope of the game; remimber its not a 4hr play session your getting out of it, think casual time sink.Visualy its expected, would be nice if the PC version had a bit more to it but honistly at this scale I would rather have more lore and story than eye candy. The lore is light I had hoped for a bit more there and that would have been a nice easy tie-in to the 'main game' if you will but its not a deal breaker.If we compare this to what I feel are similar games, not in play style but in purpose I would compare this to say Fallout Shelter. In that case it doesn't have as much to do as Fallout Shelter does, wont hold you as long likely but it does play faster and for a casual game thats a positive I think.Price point wise, I wouldn't recomend it at full price unless you just have spare cash laying about. That said I have paid that much for lesser games and been happy enough. Taking the purly numbers point of view I will likely play this game a few more hours and if we see any more expansions to the 'main game' it will likely see me return now and then. If I dont log another hour im getting about an hour of play for 3.33€ not bad but not as efficent other options out there.I would like to see more games like this, e.g. smaller more casual 'side dish' like games to our fav big games but not at the expence of the main product. They fit well in a buisy schedule, add a little extra to IPs your a fan of and if the devs can manage to keep the price point down and find interesting tie-ins to the main game then all the more better.Honistly I wouldn't want the game to become bigger or more involved, adding a bit more lore or what ever is appropreate for your IP fans to chew on in the main game it supports would be key I think. For civ (and me specificly) that would be a bit more detail on tech, history, etc. perhaps some screens or concept art I can find/unlock what have you. As for the gameplay its self I think its plenty deep and just right on the complexity side all be it a bit easy on the difficulty aspect for what it is.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												Before purchasing this game, I took the time to read reviews made by others, and nearly did not purchase it. I've been a fan of Sid Meier's games since the original Civilization, this and a sale price prompted me to make the acquisition of Starships. Boy, am I glad I made this purchase! It's Civ-like enough to make me happy, but at its core, Starships is a turn-based tactical combat simulator.I've read complaints that it doesn't play like Civ - which is good since it is not a Civ-type of game. It's distantly connected to Civilization Beyond Earth (which also worked for me because it inspired me to play that game again). That connection  primarily gave the designer's a ready-made universe so they did not have to spend time creating one. The designers also made cross-game connections - so playing one, can unlock items in the other.The Civ-like aspect comes from planets that you influence to join your federation. Think of a planet as if it were a city in a regular Civ game - it provides your basic resources; however, your resources are key to your success. The game does an excellent job of demonstrating the principle of scarcity - having one thing means not having something else. This drives your decisions regarding where to send your fleet of Starships and how to best allocate your resources. I found the simplicity of growing/managing your federation ample for this game's purpose. For those seeking a greater likeness to Civ, I can understand their disappointment, but need to point out that the game's name is Starships.Starships is about using your fleet of starships to explore and grow your federation - frequently this involves combat. As such, Starships shines as  more of a turn-based tactical combat sim, and it is on this basis that I recommend this game.Also, you can easily FINISH a game of Starships in one sitting - unlike most Civ games which require an investment in time to complete (at least the way I play them).If you enjoy learning through experience (i.e. trial and error) give the game a try and see what happens. The more you play it, the better your grasp on the game's mechanics. For those not interested in trial and error, I strongly recommend  reading through a guide. I found several on the Steam Community for Starships - one of which I forwarded to friends so that could take a peek at what Starships might have in store for them (Welcome to Starships: A Reference Guide by thecrazyscotsman).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												As far as turn-based strategy games go, Starships is okay. It isn't very complex, but it is an enjoyable little game. Sure, there are a lot better space-based conqure-the-planets-and-build-and-empire games out there, but if you don't want to spend a lot of time in the details of allocating planetary resources, managing planetary defenses, dealing with multiple fleets, yada, yada, yada... then this game is for you. Otherwise, it's a nice break from those other sorts of games.Positives:* Turn-based tactical combat is intuitive and rather straigh-forward* Building and customization of your fleet is straightforward* Resource development and trade isn't overly complex* Wonders add an interesting twist making resource allocation decisions interesting early on* Multiple ways to win* (Very) loose integration with Sid Meyer's Civilization: Beyond EarthNegatives:* Winning is a sudden surprise that ends the game... suddenly* Not a lot of depth to the game* AI in combat gets predictable after a few games* Not Steam Workshop compatible... All in all, its just a fun little game that's worth purchasing when it is on sale.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												I got this game in a bundle when I bought Beyond Earth and I've put off playing it for some time because there are a lot of negative reviews that make it out to be a terrible game. After having played it I have to say I enjoyed it. It is by no means Ci goes to space and if that is what you go into it expecting you will be dissapointed.However, what it is, is a nice casual space ship game with some empire control thrown in. Mostly the management comes from building cities, improvements, and wonders in the world in your federation as well as upgrading and buying your ships. The combat is fun, it's nothing ground breaking but still enjoyable and over all it is a game you can play in a short amount of time.For someone who enjoys spaceships and casual games this is something I find to be a lot of fun. I'd suggest if you see it onsale or you end up with it because you bought BE and it came bundled in give it a shot it you might enjoy it too.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2015
												 This is one of those games I keep coming back to.  Think of this game more along the lines of a computer based board game in line with Risk and Settlers of Catan.  It is more casual than intense.  I am an avid Civ player and play other 3X games.  If you read any of Sid Meir's notes he did not intend for this game to be an intense massive tech tree brain melting game. This is part turn based strategy part RTS. I can walk away from the game then come back after months of not playing.  I am a pretty big fan of this game.  Is it CIV no, but it is just plain fun to play without all the overlly how did i do that before strategy games. If you want a fun game you can just jump into that has good strategy this is it.  You don't have to spend hours learning a tutorial.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												It's a great little game. A joy to waste some hours on. While it's much much simpler than anything else I've tried with the Sid Meier name on it, it still is quite entertaining.While playing it feels like you've taken Master of Orion 2 and removed all the tedious parts. There's still a bit of micro management if you want to do really well, but for the most parts it's harmless. The game isn't perfect though. For instance, several achievements don't seem to trigger reliably. Also I wasn't able to load a savegame from beyond earth as indicated by one of said achievements. Then there's the slightly steep learning curve. You're not being told exactly what each victory condition entails. You'll simply notice, once you get there. And not to forget - the ai diplomacy is lacking. You can declare war and peace, that's about it. And peace has a time limit of only 1 turn, so every turn you can declare war and negotiate peace if you so desire. Anyway, despite it's shortcommings, I find it a rather enjoyable title. Especially since I found it on the internet for 7€

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												As an avid gamer and an older redneck, I have always found Sid Meier's games to be great for hours of entertainment in each gaming session. So, when given the chance to purchase Beyond Earth in a discounted bundle with Starships, I jumped at the chance. Sometimes, you really do get what you pay for.Let's start with overall appearance. Starships uses some rather simplistic graphics, but is more than adequate for the type of gameplay intended. There is nothing overly special graphically speaking. Personally, I find how the camera follows the player's shots to the point of impact in space battles to be the most exciting part of the game from a graphic standpoint. And, yes, just as many players have pointed out, the overall appearance of the game gives the impression of something you would normally find designed for iOS, Android, or a tablet.Now, to game setup and user friendliness. Game setup is extremely simplistic in that you have just the most basic of choices. Options are nothing more than if you prefer a windowed screen and game volume. Setting up an actual game, again, you have VERY limited choices which barely covers the basic criteria for what a turn based strategy game should consist of. Map size, number of opponents, affinity(your chosen race's galactic outlook), player's race/leader, and victory conditions. The last being a subject of what has become quite a heated debate in many forums across the Net, but more on that in a moment. Let's break each of the previously mentioned choices down.The choice of map sizes range from the typical small map to what the game considers gigantic. The choices are fairly accurate to the stated size with gigantic being just a tad bit smaller than the name would imply. Just your basic "how big of a game do you want to play?"Choice of number of opponents is rather self explanatory with 4 being default.Then we come to affinity as well as the player's choice of leader as the two choices are rather intertwined. There are three choices for affinity: Supremacy, Harmony, and Purity. If you are unfamiliar with Beyond Earth, affinity can be simply summed up as how the player has decided to approach the progression and evolution of the human race. Supremacy embraces technology giving way to augmentations and upgrades of the human existence. Harmony denotes a desire to be a productive and well balanced race among many in the Universe. Purity is a choice to maintain the normal progression of the human race while embracing those qualities that make a human, well...human. In the game, you choose one of the three affinities then choose your leader from the given options. No matter which affinity you choose, the same leaders are available. And as you can guess, the choice of affinity/leader each has their own particular pros and cons. Now we come to aspect of gameplay that has caused so much "ruckus" in so many forums across the Net: victory conditions. To start, the choice of victory conditions seems simple enough with each being what you would typically find in any strategy game be it real-time or turn-based. Choices like Domination(controlling the majority of the known galaxy) to Science along with familiar choices like Time, Population, and so on. Are you asking yourself "so what's the the big deal" yet? As it turns out, the choice of victory conditions ONLY applies to the human player and not any of the A.I. players in the game. Each A.I. player chooses it's own victory terms from the given choices. Example: A human player may choose Domination to which the player is required to decisively rule the majority of the galaxy whereas the A.I. player may choose the Wonder victory conditions which requires the A.I. player to complete a certain number of wonders to attain victory. The human player is not made privy to the A.I. player's choice of victory conditions. Now you can start to understand why this type of gameplay has been the source of much aggravation for many players. A human player can choose a strategy that requires a long term outlook such as the tried-and-true "build up, build up, and attack" only to lose the game a few dozen turns in due to the A.I. player building a quick ten wonders. When asked as to why gameplay is like this, the developers stated they wished to add a challenge. Challenge or insurmountable source of aggravation? You be the judge.Finally, the overall impression of Starships. The game really seems to be nothing more than a "dumbed down" and cloned version of Galactic Empires with certain aspects of Sins of a Solar Empire incorporated in. And I must say, a rather bad clone at that. Starships has it's moments, but no portion of the game really stands out. Gameplay is entertaining only for a short time then becomes repetitive. Graphics and sound are less than what many would consider average. The only positive Starships has is it's rather easy to use and simple User Interface. Between the victory conditions "glitch" and numerous reported bugs that seem to cause fatal crashes before gameplay even begins, Starships seems destined to boldly go where no game has gone before: making a negative stain on the otherwise legendary career of Sid Meier.Score:Using a 0 to 5 scoring system, I give this game 1.5. Wait for Starships to become a rather heavily discounted game before purchasing. And even then, don't part with more than $5 plus be ready for only a moment's entertainment.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												If you are a civ snob and have lots of time on your hands, this may not be your game. It is very quick compared to civ (4 hours instead of 4 days). It is way simpler than civ. So if you are looking for a civ game, go somewhere else. I really like this game. Sometimes you want to play a game that lasts weeks and requires a ton of thinking. Sometimes you want to play a game that takes a couple of hours and doesn’t require a ton of thought. That is this game. Don't get me wrong, there are lots of options (customize ships, planets, etc). But compared to huge stratagy games, it is a game you can kind of relax with. The graphics are awesome. The game looks, feels, and handles cool. If you want a quick space strategy game with a high end feel, you really can’t go wrong. While I can only handle so much time with a huge stratagy game (because I have a job and a life to live), I predict playing this game off and on over and over again when I get bored and just want a quick game to goof around with. I will get my $14.99 out of it and then some.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												Essentially this plays like a scaled down and simplified version of Star Wars: Empire at War. The differences are: * Factions. There are a few different factions as apposed to EaW's two* You can chose between three main races and a few different leaders each with different abilities* Only one fleet. Each ship is highly customizable. * The fleet has a few action points which regulates how much it can do in one turn* buying planetary upgrades, research or fleet upgrades can be done anytime in your turn, except when in battle* Turned based. The game is essentially turn based, both in the overview and in the space battles. * There are no ground battles. * A game can be completed in relatively short order. * More control on research In essence, a game can be finished in a few hours. It is interesting enough to keep you playing until the end. it should have a decent replayability value based on choice of starting race and leader.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Well, after some prolonged and frustrating problems I eventually got this game to run, and I must say that as a Sid Meier linked game my expectations were high.  The man is a genius.  However, things had been tempered by reading some mixed reviews and the annoyance of actually getting it to run.When I got the game to play I found it to be pretty much what the reviews had described.  There are several levels of difficulty, 3 different player factions to choose from and each has I think 8 different leaders to choose from, and their skills have a direct impact on your play.The map is basic but pleasing on the eye.  Combat is simple, easy to learn and again fairly nice to watch.  The diplomacy is very limited, but seems to function as intended.However, and it's a big HOWEVER, all is not well in my spiral arms of space.  The gameplay is repetative, to the point were the desire to play "just one more game" eveporates fast.  This is a new experience for me with a Sid game.  Combat, at the heart of the game, is so basic it can be painful.  I have repeatedly seen the AI bring a fleet that should have had me struggling just to survive get crushed as it makes one moronic choice after another.  Another thing I can't say I like is that so far every time I conquer a homeworld of a rival I inherit their entire empire.  While that might work on a National lever (and I doubt even then), it seems a bit lame in this sort of game.  It also makes achieving an outright win over a mighty rival possible in 1 combat.  Wonders are fun, but get a powerful 1 early and your enemies are doomed.Fun? Yes.  Limited replayability?  Also yes.
