number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												This is very much the kind of game which either becomes a cult classic a few years down the line, or simply gets forgotten. It's not really anything like Civilisation at all, there's very little "city" (planet) management, and the research gameplay is relaxed to put it mildly. It's really just a turn-based-tactics spaceship battle game with some persistence elements.Those of you who are old enough, I'd like to take you on a brief journey through time. Back to when UFO: Enemy Unknown/XCOM: UFO Defense was new. Remember how the geoscape felt tacked on, like it was providing the minimum amount of glue to get you to the next battle? It's exactly the same here. Replace soldiers and aliens with space ships and, well, other space ships and you'd have something very close to Sid Meier's Starships. That sounds kind of like a compliment, doesn't it? Well, not entirely. The look and feel of the game would really sit quite well in the mid-late 90s (compare Total Annihilation), and frankly the pared-down Civ-like engine for outside of battle is less polished even than XCOM was in its day.In addition to that, and perhaps in some ways as a consequence, the difficulty seems to be miscalibrated. I put it on "normal" (from the default "easy"??) for the first try at playing, and really got straight through to winning the game with pretty trivial ease - maybe 3 battles lost - and that's without ever learning half the interface or discovering where the last faction was. I'd speculate that players who have a reasonable sense of where to put there upgrade points would find it painfully easy on any but the higher difficulties.Thankfully, the actual turn-based battling is pretty enjoyable, and the ship customisation works well. Good for a pick-up-and-play, assuming that you have a couple of hours to spare, and perhaps a worthy antidote to too much Civ.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												Personally, I enjoy this game and have not been disappointed, as the price is reasonable for the content.   The game is exactly what I would have expected it to be, a small turn-based strategy game with a Beyond Earth feel.  It reminds me a bit of Distant Star: Revenant Fleet, albeit turn-based with a Beyond Earth flavor.  As I enjoy games such as Distant Star: Revenant Fleet, Infinite Space, and FTL, this game falls in line.  Those who are looking for a  deep storyline or an involved strategy game will almost certainly be disappointed.  That being said, those who enjoy sci-fi turn-based strategy that doesn't get overly involved might just find this one as enjoyable as I have.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												I've taken a good liking to Sid Meier's Starships. It's quickly become my go to game when I have just an hour to kill and don't want to get into something deep. I hope they make an iPad version of the game because I feel it's really suitable for those moments where I want to have some fun but don't want to be too engaged: for example a transpacific flight, on the train, or time sitting on the toilet. It's fun and to the point and not too repetative. While the documentation in the game is sparse at best it's easy to figure by giving it a quick go.It's best to think of Startships as being the "Civ: Revolutions" of Beyond Earth. 2k is very clear they see it as a casual title -- something that seems to be lost on the majority of the commentors. This is not a game you sit down and play for 8-12 hours straight and it's not meant to be nor is it priced as such. It fills the niche of a casual tactical strategey game to perfection. And that makes it a welcome addition to my Steam Library.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												It’s a fun, almost “casual” game in the genre. It’s something that be played while waiting for an appointment or during a lunch break. But I can see where other people would decry this one. Most games like this are usually overbearing in its complexity, require a bit of micromanagement for everything, from upgrading colonies and structures, to specific types of research. But upgrades are a simple, one-button click and I love it. This game feels very intuitive. A playthrough or two and you’ve already gotten the gist and feel of it. The combat sections are fun, although the “odds of success” part can get iffy. I’ve completed missions where my chances of success were in the low 40’s. Again, intuitive; once you know of what does what and how they can be useful it all starts to fit together. Torpedoes are to force the enemy out of cover, or try and take them out long-range and en mass. Fighters are heavy-hitters but are fragile. Asteroids are for cover, and so on.  Downside: No ability to name your ships. Considering that you’re entire success depends on your fleet, I thought that was an oversight. That lack of basic-level customization I hope would be corrected in a future patch. I am hoping that this is a test platform of sorts for Firaxis: budget-level games, or just something that can be expanded later on with DLCs or something.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												The game works perfect for me and I have a nothing special laptop .This is very tight design . I suggest playing it on at least hard an you will see there is no wasted turns , no mashing the next turn button . And yes you dont know the other players victory conditions - a time honored convention in many board games of which this game would be perfectly adaptable for . I also like that Starships skips the uninhabited world convention and instead each planet is populated and  will have immediate tactical and strategic advantages that you will need to win.The combat portion is well thought out too but I have to admit once I developed a tactical  doctrine of slow withdrawal and fighters to soak up hits the A.I. 's advance fragments around the asteroid fields where one can counter attack and destroy his navy in detail . I was able to defeat much larger forces where I was given a very unlikey chance of winning . But you can win the battle but lose the war which is what has been my fate so far . No wins yet and I like that .Some have made Starships sound like checkers but there is enough facets to the game play to keep me interested  and give  me that "just  one more turn " experience . I feel for those having crash issues as its always many dergrees  of unfun to purchase a game aand not be able to enjoy it but hopefully they will be fixed soon and then maybe a demo so people can see for themselves whether Starships is their thing .

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												It's a fun enough game for what it is. But don't pay full price for it.Basically ask yourself: Is it $5?- If yes: buy- If no: don't buyMaybe they'll do more with it later, but it seems like this is pretty much it.The game is fun enough for what it is. What it is NOT unfortunately, is Civ In Space.Even the actual starships, the ostensible focus of the game, aren't particularly interesting. You get some buttons to push to make some aspects of the ships better in exchange for resources, or worse and get some of those resources back. The tactical combat actually IS interesting and requires that you think about what you're doing. Unfortunately there's a very real potential for you to just become an overpowered titan of the galaxy here and roll mindless over whatever your opponents throw at you. This can happen entirely by accident.There's no diplomacy to speak of. No meaningful relationships with other faction leaders. And no real way to negotiate for... anything really.The planets themselves are pretty boring, conveying some numerical advantages to you by existing. They're less like planets full of people and more like buildings in a strategy game. They're there to provide resources and some of them can house wonders. That's all.Overall, it's a fun game, but a barebones one. Don't pay full price for it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												Starships starts out relatively fun - you can work your way up through the difficulty chain and the map size while trying out different factions and characters. However, after about 2 hours of play the game becomes extremely repetitive. I have played multiple missions at the highest difficulty with the largest map size and always win - gameplay just becomes a grind, really. I find that torpedoes are the weapon of choice, especially when combined with the wonder that allows 2 actions per turn and the wonder that cloaks torps.Graphics are simple but clean. Sound is good for what it is. The in-game movies for certain events (like firing torps) gets old because it wastes time. The game is very stable - has not crashed at all.The real problem with the game is as I stated in the first paragraph - it is an easy game. It is also simple (not complex), which is a good thing, but the ease of the game means that there is no real replay value. All your games will pretty much be the same, and therefore become more of a grind than a fun experience.Rating 7/10 (8/10 initially, 4/10 later on)

												This game isn't bad, it's just half-cooked - at least that's my opinion. Lacking a decent tutorial my first attempts were a little confusing, but the game itself is rather easy to play. It's basically: buy plants, cities and improvements - upgrade your ships with money and through science - attack and help other planets. Rinse and repeat! That's the whole game. I miss a lot of depth of this game and honestly, a little more gameplay and diversity.Another thing that bugs me are the missing options - whether it is an option to change game settings, graphic settings or even key bin certain actions. The options menu consists of some audio sliders and a full-screen option. That's it.I would really love to recommend this game as I like the actual concept and look, but it's missing a lot of depth and probably not really worth your money.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Well, after some prolonged and frustrating problems I eventually got this game to run, and I must say that as a Sid Meier linked game my expectations were high.  The man is a genius.  However, things had been tempered by reading some mixed reviews and the annoyance of actually getting it to run.When I got the game to play I found it to be pretty much what the reviews had described.  There are several levels of difficulty, 3 different player factions to choose from and each has I think 8 different leaders to choose from, and their skills have a direct impact on your play.The map is basic but pleasing on the eye.  Combat is simple, easy to learn and again fairly nice to watch.  The diplomacy is very limited, but seems to function as intended.However, and it's a big HOWEVER, all is not well in my spiral arms of space.  The gameplay is repetative, to the point were the desire to play "just one more game" eveporates fast.  This is a new experience for me with a Sid game.  Combat, at the heart of the game, is so basic it can be painful.  I have repeatedly seen the AI bring a fleet that should have had me struggling just to survive get crushed as it makes one moronic choice after another.  Another thing I can't say I like is that so far every time I conquer a homeworld of a rival I inherit their entire empire.  While that might work on a National lever (and I doubt even then), it seems a bit lame in this sort of game.  It also makes achieving an outright win over a mighty rival possible in 1 combat.  Wonders are fun, but get a powerful 1 early and your enemies are doomed.Fun? Yes.  Limited replayability?  Also yes.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												As a big fan of the Civilization series I had high expectations for Starships & hoped it would emulate the same fundamental style of gameplay as other games in the franchise. Sadly the finished product feels like a rushed attempt at trying to create something that could have been great but falls short in so many way and ultimately feels like a Civilization: Beyond Earth mini-game.The game revolves around conquering planets with a single fleet of starships & engaging in repetitive battles that feature an uninspiring AI that can be easily defeated once you (quickly) discover a simple formulae for defeating opponents (You can quite easily hide your ships in cover and cripple the enemy with waves of torpedoes & fighters).I don’t explicitly dislike Starships, however, there is very little replay value and almost no scope for variety in terms of how you play the game, due to the almost identical factions and simplistic victory conditions (I’ve found myself winning a population victory by accident on several occasions).Although the game isn’t anywhere near as engaging as I hoped, it does have good touch support and is a pleasant enough game to play on a tablet when on the move or sitting in bed. As much as I hate taking the price into consideration, as I would have much rather paid three times as much for a far deeper experience, I do think that it’s a decent enough arcade game for killing time in short bursts.In summary I’m going to (only just) recommend Starships based purely on the fact that it’s a cheap and cheerful game to pass an hour or so here-and-there, just don’t expect the same engaging experience that you might expect from other games in the franchise.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												This is a mobile game being masqueraded as a PC game. It's extremely simplified and lacks any real depth. The games only options are by increasing the ticks in your weapons and by adding more ships. The planets have ticks as well that give more resources and a unique ability. Combat is grid-based, with asteroids offering cover an unknown amount of cover, you won't know until you fire on an enemy - visual clues are limited to greater or lesser. I'd expect this to be a game for no more than a dollar or two with banner adds. The price point doesn't match the game play.Once upon a time if a game supported the "Sid Meier's" prefix I would preorder it in a heartbeat (and that was one of the few auto preorders for me), but lately Firaxis has been releasing games that don't have anything new or substantial in the games they develop. This was the game that stopped that for me, friends have been telling me I shouldn't preorder games anyway - this is the proof in that pudding.

												It could really use multiplayer (with some serious balance work) and continue after victory. Overall I'm pretty pleased, I think it fills it's niche very well. Most of the critics seem to expect a full AAA $60 game experience for $15 and that just isn't fair. I think this game would be better thought of, and later expanded upon, the way so many great tabletop games have a core module with a ton of add ons. Catan does it, Dominion does it, Arkham does it, Warhammer sure as♥♥♥♥♥♥does the hell out of it.If possible, a little more depth and diversity would be nice, but I'd be perfectly happy with this becoming a platform for DLC or open it up for modders on the PC. Adding an endgame alien invasion mechanic would be awesome; you've united the galaxy under your banner, now lead it! Or add a ground combat miniscenario in a DLC pack. Rig one of your capital ships as a troop carrying drop ship they way you currently can have a fighter centered carrier. Maybe they can launch boarding parties to capture vessels? Bringing in something like the crew specialists from Pirates! is something I think would be really cool, too.I'm sure almost all of this is just wishful thinking, but I think it is a testament to a really great game that it inspires all kinds of ways it could (realistically) expand and be even better.

												Starships is legit, old school Sid Meier.  He programmed the game, did it his way, and it feels like Civ 1 with X-Com style combat (using asteroids as cover).  I've only played it on easy, and it is as easy as a game of Civ on Settler difficulty.$15?  I wouldn't pay that for this game (sorry Sid).  It's solo player and seems to have relatively little to do for a video game.  I recommend trying out a demo if you can, or watching gameplay on YouTube, but get it at a discount; don't spend more than $6 on it.  I was fortunate to get it bundled with Beyond Earth for $27, when Beyond Earth was on sale for $25, so it's like I spent $2 on this game and it was worth it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												I dig it, but of course, I bought it in a Beyond Earth/Starships bundle when both were also being offered on a Steam sale, so I paid $27 for both titles total.  Since BE runs $25 during a normal Steam sale, I ended up paying $2 for Starships - for $2, this game is AMAZING.  It's light...nothing at all like Civ or BE.  To me, to give a perspective/description to what the game feels like or what you should expect, you have to start with a baseline - for me, that's Civ 5 with all the DLCs/expansion packs.  If you start there, Civ 5 gives you tons of options and playstyles...then you simplify when you move to BE where you have a fairly young game with fewer options that still feels more or less like Civ 5 without any of the major DLC packs...then you move to something like "Pandora: First Contact" - a Civ-style 4x game that almost completely focuses on battles, and as such, has a lot of upgrade options for units, lots of unit variety, lots of fun attack graphics, but offers little in the way of multiple play styles...then finally, you get to Starships - a game that is *JUST* fighting.  Think of it as "Risk - Beyond Earth" or "Axis and Allies: year 3400AD Edition".  It's totally not a 4x game - it's just about claiming land, kicking spaceship♥♥♥♥♥ and buying new upgrades.  I think the game normally runs around $10, and by my math, I figure that I'm willing to spend roughly $0.50-$1/hour for a good game.  Well, since I spent $2 and have played for about 50 hours, I spent about a nickel per hour on this game.  I can live with that.  Even at $10, that'd still be less than a quater/hour.  Synopsis - if you want to shoot things in space, go for it.  If you want to play Civ 5, go do that instead.  If you want Civ 5 super space edition, wait another 2 years for Firaxis to release 2-3 BE DLC's and then buy it on a Steam sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												It’s a fun, almost “casual” game in the genre. It’s something that be played while waiting for an appointment or during a lunch break. But I can see where other people would decry this one. Most games like this are usually overbearing in its complexity, require a bit of micromanagement for everything, from upgrading colonies and structures, to specific types of research. But upgrades are a simple, one-button click and I love it. This game feels very intuitive. A playthrough or two and you’ve already gotten the gist and feel of it. The combat sections are fun, although the “odds of success” part can get iffy. I’ve completed missions where my chances of success were in the low 40’s. Again, intuitive; once you know of what does what and how they can be useful it all starts to fit together. Torpedoes are to force the enemy out of cover, or try and take them out long-range and en mass. Fighters are heavy-hitters but are fragile. Asteroids are for cover, and so on.  Downside: No ability to name your ships. Considering that you’re entire success depends on your fleet, I thought that was an oversight. That lack of basic-level customization I hope would be corrected in a future patch. I am hoping that this is a test platform of sorts for Firaxis: budget-level games, or just something that can be expanded later on with DLCs or something.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												Bottom-line up front: I'd give this a solid 1.5 out of 10. This is an expensive version of a free Facebook game... read more to find out why. I REALLY wanted to like this game. From the pre-order description, and the fact that Sid Meier does an amazing job with about 95% of the games that they produce, this had a ton of potential.Branded as a 4x game that related to Beyond Earth, I was a bit hopeful to see something that played like Master of Orion 2 and had the space-ground gameplay of Star Commander. Alas, I got my hopes up too high.Also, before you go too much farther with this, just know that I haven't read the other reviews. This is my own take on this game.Everything from the tech, to the resources, (lack of) diplomacy, (generic) space combat, and AI feels flat.TECH: The tech "tree" is just a menu of upgrade. There are no new capabilities to introduce and no real choices that force you to examine tradeoffs and benefits. After playing BE, you'll likely be especially let down because NONE of that innovation exists in this game.RESOURCES: Four resources, and four very narrow things to do with them. Like most campy Facebook games, using your resources requires no more thought than a button click.DIPLOMACY: My main complaint with most Civ games is that you have options that the AI will not accept... in this case, you don't even have those options. Your two basic negotiating stances are a) war, or b) peace. Given the combat, neither has any particular advantages.COMBAT: This is probably the only (slightly) redeeming part of this game. For about the first 20 turns, the combat and the missions are challenging. Once you've pumped enough resources into your ships, you can pretty well steamroll the AI with impunity.Oh yes, the ship customization (and the reason why I was excited about this game)... yawn. Again, like the tech tree, the characteristics of each of your ships can be leveled up to attain greater advantage. There is no researching of new ship hulls, engines, weapons, or shields; just leveling. Facebook flash games have more options than this... such as Battle Pirates.Final thing that I'll say on combat is this: one fleet? If SM was trying a new twist on 4x games to limit player to one fleet and up the challenge, this was a terrible choice. Any potential challenge is wasted because they let you construct warp gates so that you do not use up movement points while moving between your own worlds.AI: Now for the AI. Like the rest of the game, the AI is stale and offers no challenge. In three different play throughs of the game (each at increasing difficulty), I have as yet to have an AI player declare war on me or attack me. I can roam the galaxy with my large armada of heavily armed ships and tear through pretty much every other empire with little effort.What could have been a stellar game (see what I did there?) is really just a black hole for your wallet (even at $13 - as of this writing).Save your money. Save your time. Don't save this galaxy (or SM's bottom line).

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Starships is a decent game.  The game UI could definitely use some polish/PC-specific tweaks.  But it's a good concept, distills the 4x genre down to a tighter core, with some interesting tactical elements.  You won't have massive space battles, and you're managing a single (small) fleet, but it's got a nice "crew fatigue" mechanic that allows multiple battles per "turn".  The tech tree too, is boiled down to it's barest essence, amounting to generic upgrades of wide areas of tech: "Better lasers", "better engines", etc.  The planet management too, is down to the essence: "Add city", "add more mines", "add more research stations"...It's fun, in a casual-strategy-game kinda way.If you're looking for something with a lot of depth, this isn't it.  But if you can get it cheap, and you want something that won't tax your brain too hard, this can be fun for a couple hours at a shot.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												As an avid gamer and an older redneck, I have always found Sid Meier's games to be great for hours of entertainment in each gaming session. So, when given the chance to purchase Beyond Earth in a discounted bundle with Starships, I jumped at the chance. Sometimes, you really do get what you pay for.Let's start with overall appearance. Starships uses some rather simplistic graphics, but is more than adequate for the type of gameplay intended. There is nothing overly special graphically speaking. Personally, I find how the camera follows the player's shots to the point of impact in space battles to be the most exciting part of the game from a graphic standpoint. And, yes, just as many players have pointed out, the overall appearance of the game gives the impression of something you would normally find designed for iOS, Android, or a tablet.Now, to game setup and user friendliness. Game setup is extremely simplistic in that you have just the most basic of choices. Options are nothing more than if you prefer a windowed screen and game volume. Setting up an actual game, again, you have VERY limited choices which barely covers the basic criteria for what a turn based strategy game should consist of. Map size, number of opponents, affinity(your chosen race's galactic outlook), player's race/leader, and victory conditions. The last being a subject of what has become quite a heated debate in many forums across the Net, but more on that in a moment. Let's break each of the previously mentioned choices down.The choice of map sizes range from the typical small map to what the game considers gigantic. The choices are fairly accurate to the stated size with gigantic being just a tad bit smaller than the name would imply. Just your basic "how big of a game do you want to play?"Choice of number of opponents is rather self explanatory with 4 being default.Then we come to affinity as well as the player's choice of leader as the two choices are rather intertwined. There are three choices for affinity: Supremacy, Harmony, and Purity. If you are unfamiliar with Beyond Earth, affinity can be simply summed up as how the player has decided to approach the progression and evolution of the human race. Supremacy embraces technology giving way to augmentations and upgrades of the human existence. Harmony denotes a desire to be a productive and well balanced race among many in the Universe. Purity is a choice to maintain the normal progression of the human race while embracing those qualities that make a human, well...human. In the game, you choose one of the three affinities then choose your leader from the given options. No matter which affinity you choose, the same leaders are available. And as you can guess, the choice of affinity/leader each has their own particular pros and cons. Now we come to aspect of gameplay that has caused so much "ruckus" in so many forums across the Net: victory conditions. To start, the choice of victory conditions seems simple enough with each being what you would typically find in any strategy game be it real-time or turn-based. Choices like Domination(controlling the majority of the known galaxy) to Science along with familiar choices like Time, Population, and so on. Are you asking yourself "so what's the the big deal" yet? As it turns out, the choice of victory conditions ONLY applies to the human player and not any of the A.I. players in the game. Each A.I. player chooses it's own victory terms from the given choices. Example: A human player may choose Domination to which the player is required to decisively rule the majority of the galaxy whereas the A.I. player may choose the Wonder victory conditions which requires the A.I. player to complete a certain number of wonders to attain victory. The human player is not made privy to the A.I. player's choice of victory conditions. Now you can start to understand why this type of gameplay has been the source of much aggravation for many players. A human player can choose a strategy that requires a long term outlook such as the tried-and-true "build up, build up, and attack" only to lose the game a few dozen turns in due to the A.I. player building a quick ten wonders. When asked as to why gameplay is like this, the developers stated they wished to add a challenge. Challenge or insurmountable source of aggravation? You be the judge.Finally, the overall impression of Starships. The game really seems to be nothing more than a "dumbed down" and cloned version of Galactic Empires with certain aspects of Sins of a Solar Empire incorporated in. And I must say, a rather bad clone at that. Starships has it's moments, but no portion of the game really stands out. Gameplay is entertaining only for a short time then becomes repetitive. Graphics and sound are less than what many would consider average. The only positive Starships has is it's rather easy to use and simple User Interface. Between the victory conditions "glitch" and numerous reported bugs that seem to cause fatal crashes before gameplay even begins, Starships seems destined to boldly go where no game has gone before: making a negative stain on the otherwise legendary career of Sid Meier.Score:Using a 0 to 5 scoring system, I give this game 1.5. Wait for Starships to become a rather heavily discounted game before purchasing. And even then, don't part with more than $5 plus be ready for only a moment's entertainment.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												As a big fan of the Civilization series I had high expectations for Starships & hoped it would emulate the same fundamental style of gameplay as other games in the franchise. Sadly the finished product feels like a rushed attempt at trying to create something that could have been great but falls short in so many way and ultimately feels like a Civilization: Beyond Earth mini-game.The game revolves around conquering planets with a single fleet of starships & engaging in repetitive battles that feature an uninspiring AI that can be easily defeated once you (quickly) discover a simple formulae for defeating opponents (You can quite easily hide your ships in cover and cripple the enemy with waves of torpedoes & fighters).I don’t explicitly dislike Starships, however, there is very little replay value and almost no scope for variety in terms of how you play the game, due to the almost identical factions and simplistic victory conditions (I’ve found myself winning a population victory by accident on several occasions).Although the game isn’t anywhere near as engaging as I hoped, it does have good touch support and is a pleasant enough game to play on a tablet when on the move or sitting in bed. As much as I hate taking the price into consideration, as I would have much rather paid three times as much for a far deeper experience, I do think that it’s a decent enough arcade game for killing time in short bursts.In summary I’m going to (only just) recommend Starships based purely on the fact that it’s a cheap and cheerful game to pass an hour or so here-and-there, just don’t expect the same engaging experience that you might expect from other games in the franchise.

Posted: April 5, 2015
												This is a mobile game being masqueraded as a PC game. It's extremely simplified and lacks any real depth. The games only options are by increasing the ticks in your weapons and by adding more ships. The planets have ticks as well that give more resources and a unique ability. Combat is grid-based, with asteroids offering cover an unknown amount of cover, you won't know until you fire on an enemy - visual clues are limited to greater or lesser. I'd expect this to be a game for no more than a dollar or two with banner adds. The price point doesn't match the game play.Once upon a time if a game supported the "Sid Meier's" prefix I would preorder it in a heartbeat (and that was one of the few auto preorders for me), but lately Firaxis has been releasing games that don't have anything new or substantial in the games they develop. This was the game that stopped that for me, friends have been telling me I shouldn't preorder games anyway - this is the proof in that pudding.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												This game may be of the Civilization heritage however it sorely lacks much of the polish and depth that its predecessors have.The game is very easy to pick up and get playing and doesn't have much of a learning curve. The visuals of the game are ok but that is not why people play strategy games. Customising your ships is easy and can lend it self to creating different specilisations of your ships.This game is lacking in depth for a real strategy fan. The battle system is similar to XCOM (turn based) however there now real sense of cover. You can use asteroids to bottleneck your opponent into a sort of kill box but then you might end up being shot through the asteroids anyway. The random environment effects that disable certain features of the ships can be annoying but do not really factor into any kind of strategy.Lack of information when mousing over various aspects of the game is very annoying. You have no way of knowing what exactly is happening when you are spending energy upgrading your ships. What does upgrading fighters do? Make them stronger? More fighters? There is no way to tell easily unless you commit to it. Upgrading fighters just gives more fighters to that can be deployed by your starship.The world map portion of the game is another feature lacking any real depth. You can control planets for more resources and wonders but that is all they are good for, you can specialise them for more of a certain resource but that is it.The map sizes are very tiny and are meant for quick games nothing long and drawn out like the Civ games. I was hoping for a massive epic length battle like in civ but sadly, that is not the case.Victory condition restrictions only apply to the player. If you wanted a massive conquest style game that allows you to get your starships to the end game you will not see it. The AI can easily win with a wonder victory or science before you have any real chance to see the full glory of your starships. Would really love those victory conditions to be applied to the AI as well.I cannot recommend this game to any strategy or civ fan.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												Anyone who was thinking of buying this game: wait until at least May 2015.  Hopefully by then the major bugs will have been fixed.  And don't buy it for over $10.It runs for me, but apparently not for many.  One bug I did run into was achievements not unlocking when they should.  (Granted, I fulfilled the requirements for a couple by conquest, when apparently normaly building was the intended way.  But still, these things should be checked for.)It's generic science fiction that tries to be 4x, but really is all about your single steadily growing fleet rolling over the galaxy.  Upgrading your planets is almost inconsequential compared to upgrading your fleet.  Energy constraints heavily favor optimizing for just one form of attack; in particular, lasers 4+ and 0 cannons, torpedoes, et cetera mean you can destroy most targets from a long distance, often times even through asteroids.  (Just make sure you are strong enough before attacking homeworlds: the defense ships that any homeworld starts with will maul a starting fleet, but they don't upgrade over time.)As of this writing, the non-military victory conditions are only feasible if you disable the military victory conditions.  (The UI lets you enable all victory conditions, or only one specific condition, with no option to, say, only disable Population.)  Otherwise, someone's probably going to win a Population victory first.  Even the Domination victory is usually preceeded by a Population victory, unless someone (probably you) launches an early attack on the other empires, to score a Domination victory before enough of the galaxy has been claimed that reducing the galaxy to 2 empires (a necessary prelude to reducing it to 1 for Domination) triggers a Population victory.I do not recommend this game at this time, but if you are reading months or years later - after the bugs have been fixed - and you can get it for under $10, it might be a cheap diversion for a weekend or two.

Posted: March 22, 2015
												Fantastic little Game. Well worth the price tag. Although it has got a lot of negative reviews, I think those reviews were from people who were expecting it to be Civ with starships. It isn't at all. In Civ a game may take 10+ hours depending on what settings it is on, and it takes a lot of thought and tactics. A game on Starships takes around 2 hours, and it's a lot more easy going. It does still require thought though, enough so to keep you engaged with the game. It's a great game with what looks like a lot of replayability. Its perfect for that half hour before going out or that 1 hour in the day that you have spare. Would thoroughly recommend.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												The problem with this game isn't that it's bad. The problem with this game is that it isn't good. The core game is there, but the game lacks the attention to detail that could have made it great. It's as if the developers come up with a great idea, got bored, and just pumped out a really half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥version of the game.The startup options are lackluster consisting of nothing more than map size, number of players, and difficulty which kills replayability. In order to progress in the game you need to gain influence on planets by performing misisons for them. This  is a great idea in theory, but the lack of mission types makes even a single 3 hour playthrough really repetitive. You have kill the enemy fleet, king of the hill, escort the transport, stop the enemy transport, amd wade through a minefield blindfolder (or at least that's what it feels like). 90% of the time it just consists of slaughtering your enemies and waiting until you can clear the objective.The game is just so half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ They really didn't try to add any diversity or options to make the game interesting. It's bare bones, lackluster, and just not fun. TL;DR: Interesting concept, terrible execution.

												 This is one of those games I keep coming back to.  Think of this game more along the lines of a computer based board game in line with Risk and Settlers of Catan.  It is more casual than intense.  I am an avid Civ player and play other 3X games.  If you read any of Sid Meir's notes he did not intend for this game to be an intense massive tech tree brain melting game. This is part turn based strategy part RTS. I can walk away from the game then come back after months of not playing.  I am a pretty big fan of this game.  Is it CIV no, but it is just plain fun to play without all the overlly how did i do that before strategy games. If you want a fun game you can just jump into that has good strategy this is it.  You don't have to spend hours learning a tutorial.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												Bottom-line up front: I'd give this a solid 1.5 out of 10. This is an expensive version of a free Facebook game... read more to find out why. I REALLY wanted to like this game. From the pre-order description, and the fact that Sid Meier does an amazing job with about 95% of the games that they produce, this had a ton of potential.Branded as a 4x game that related to Beyond Earth, I was a bit hopeful to see something that played like Master of Orion 2 and had the space-ground gameplay of Star Commander. Alas, I got my hopes up too high.Also, before you go too much farther with this, just know that I haven't read the other reviews. This is my own take on this game.Everything from the tech, to the resources, (lack of) diplomacy, (generic) space combat, and AI feels flat.TECH: The tech "tree" is just a menu of upgrade. There are no new capabilities to introduce and no real choices that force you to examine tradeoffs and benefits. After playing BE, you'll likely be especially let down because NONE of that innovation exists in this game.RESOURCES: Four resources, and four very narrow things to do with them. Like most campy Facebook games, using your resources requires no more thought than a button click.DIPLOMACY: My main complaint with most Civ games is that you have options that the AI will not accept... in this case, you don't even have those options. Your two basic negotiating stances are a) war, or b) peace. Given the combat, neither has any particular advantages.COMBAT: This is probably the only (slightly) redeeming part of this game. For about the first 20 turns, the combat and the missions are challenging. Once you've pumped enough resources into your ships, you can pretty well steamroll the AI with impunity.Oh yes, the ship customization (and the reason why I was excited about this game)... yawn. Again, like the tech tree, the characteristics of each of your ships can be leveled up to attain greater advantage. There is no researching of new ship hulls, engines, weapons, or shields; just leveling. Facebook flash games have more options than this... such as Battle Pirates.Final thing that I'll say on combat is this: one fleet? If SM was trying a new twist on 4x games to limit player to one fleet and up the challenge, this was a terrible choice. Any potential challenge is wasted because they let you construct warp gates so that you do not use up movement points while moving between your own worlds.AI: Now for the AI. Like the rest of the game, the AI is stale and offers no challenge. In three different play throughs of the game (each at increasing difficulty), I have as yet to have an AI player declare war on me or attack me. I can roam the galaxy with my large armada of heavily armed ships and tear through pretty much every other empire with little effort.What could have been a stellar game (see what I did there?) is really just a black hole for your wallet (even at $13 - as of this writing).Save your money. Save your time. Don't save this galaxy (or SM's bottom line).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												This game may be of the Civilization heritage however it sorely lacks much of the polish and depth that its predecessors have.The game is very easy to pick up and get playing and doesn't have much of a learning curve. The visuals of the game are ok but that is not why people play strategy games. Customising your ships is easy and can lend it self to creating different specilisations of your ships.This game is lacking in depth for a real strategy fan. The battle system is similar to XCOM (turn based) however there now real sense of cover. You can use asteroids to bottleneck your opponent into a sort of kill box but then you might end up being shot through the asteroids anyway. The random environment effects that disable certain features of the ships can be annoying but do not really factor into any kind of strategy.Lack of information when mousing over various aspects of the game is very annoying. You have no way of knowing what exactly is happening when you are spending energy upgrading your ships. What does upgrading fighters do? Make them stronger? More fighters? There is no way to tell easily unless you commit to it. Upgrading fighters just gives more fighters to that can be deployed by your starship.The world map portion of the game is another feature lacking any real depth. You can control planets for more resources and wonders but that is all they are good for, you can specialise them for more of a certain resource but that is it.The map sizes are very tiny and are meant for quick games nothing long and drawn out like the Civ games. I was hoping for a massive epic length battle like in civ but sadly, that is not the case.Victory condition restrictions only apply to the player. If you wanted a massive conquest style game that allows you to get your starships to the end game you will not see it. The AI can easily win with a wonder victory or science before you have any real chance to see the full glory of your starships. Would really love those victory conditions to be applied to the AI as well.I cannot recommend this game to any strategy or civ fan.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												Anyone who was thinking of buying this game: wait until at least May 2015.  Hopefully by then the major bugs will have been fixed.  And don't buy it for over $10.It runs for me, but apparently not for many.  One bug I did run into was achievements not unlocking when they should.  (Granted, I fulfilled the requirements for a couple by conquest, when apparently normaly building was the intended way.  But still, these things should be checked for.)It's generic science fiction that tries to be 4x, but really is all about your single steadily growing fleet rolling over the galaxy.  Upgrading your planets is almost inconsequential compared to upgrading your fleet.  Energy constraints heavily favor optimizing for just one form of attack; in particular, lasers 4+ and 0 cannons, torpedoes, et cetera mean you can destroy most targets from a long distance, often times even through asteroids.  (Just make sure you are strong enough before attacking homeworlds: the defense ships that any homeworld starts with will maul a starting fleet, but they don't upgrade over time.)As of this writing, the non-military victory conditions are only feasible if you disable the military victory conditions.  (The UI lets you enable all victory conditions, or only one specific condition, with no option to, say, only disable Population.)  Otherwise, someone's probably going to win a Population victory first.  Even the Domination victory is usually preceeded by a Population victory, unless someone (probably you) launches an early attack on the other empires, to score a Domination victory before enough of the galaxy has been claimed that reducing the galaxy to 2 empires (a necessary prelude to reducing it to 1 for Domination) triggers a Population victory.I do not recommend this game at this time, but if you are reading months or years later - after the bugs have been fixed - and you can get it for under $10, it might be a cheap diversion for a weekend or two.

												Fantastic little Game. Well worth the price tag. Although it has got a lot of negative reviews, I think those reviews were from people who were expecting it to be Civ with starships. It isn't at all. In Civ a game may take 10+ hours depending on what settings it is on, and it takes a lot of thought and tactics. A game on Starships takes around 2 hours, and it's a lot more easy going. It does still require thought though, enough so to keep you engaged with the game. It's a great game with what looks like a lot of replayability. Its perfect for that half hour before going out or that 1 hour in the day that you have spare. Would thoroughly recommend.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												The problem with this game isn't that it's bad. The problem with this game is that it isn't good. The core game is there, but the game lacks the attention to detail that could have made it great. It's as if the developers come up with a great idea, got bored, and just pumped out a really half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥version of the game.The startup options are lackluster consisting of nothing more than map size, number of players, and difficulty which kills replayability. In order to progress in the game you need to gain influence on planets by performing misisons for them. This  is a great idea in theory, but the lack of mission types makes even a single 3 hour playthrough really repetitive. You have kill the enemy fleet, king of the hill, escort the transport, stop the enemy transport, amd wade through a minefield blindfolder (or at least that's what it feels like). 90% of the time it just consists of slaughtering your enemies and waiting until you can clear the objective.The game is just so half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ They really didn't try to add any diversity or options to make the game interesting. It's bare bones, lackluster, and just not fun. TL;DR: Interesting concept, terrible execution.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												So I really enjoy this game. Yes it does have some issues and is far from perfect but is a great time waster.So good points; The ease of play, there is no real learning curve, you can pick this up and dive right in. The combat. Comabt is interesting and the variety of ships you come across can keep it so. Coming across ships from other factions with very different strenghts and weaknesses can throw what was otherwise an easy roll through space.Ship customisation. Fun but not perfect, it makes a large difference as the game starts and on harder modes, less so in late game easy modes.Negatives.It can get a little old after a while, simeply because there is no real depth to play. The mission variety is low, and can really wear thin after long sessions.In late game it can become a long slog between each faction going back and forth.Very easy to lose on population when two factions join out of the blue. Several times I have gone from 49% population with an easy lead and then been overtaken by two factions, leaving me in the dust.Bugs. You do find many, visual bugs mostly, animations looping, funky camera angles and windowing issues. All normally sort out with a quick save and restart so nothing game braking. Overall I would reccomend if you fancy an every so often time sink.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												Although I'm not a real scifi-fan I really liked Sid Meier's Starships. It's much better than the two Sid Meier's Ace Patrol games but less complex than Civilization. Starships is easy to learn (even though the tutorial isn't that good), has a nice setting and good turn-based gameplay. What makes this game so interesting is the following: A full game only lasts a few hours, you can choose from three playble factions and there are different ways to win the game. This guarantees that replaying the game is still enjoyable. The only negative aspects are, that the game can appear a bit repetitive and that there is sadly no Multiplayer at all. In cotrast to a lot of other reviewers, my game run very stable and never crashed, but like others mentioned there is no real fullscreen mode. If you have Sid Meier's Civilization Beyond Earth you can combine it with Starships and unlock some bonus content in both games, which is really nice if you ask me. All in all I can recommend the game to all turn-based strategey-game-lovers but I suggest you get the game in a discount or in bundle because the fullprice seems a bit too high.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												This is a mini-game. If you expect a big game then you will be disapointed. The depth of the game is redicilously low. There is so little to choose between and almost no options to customize your gaming experience. However as a mini-game for a tablet it would be perfect. On a PC it doesn't do very well and if you have a 4k monitor it's absolutely horrible. The font size doesn't scale up so it's so incredible tiny, the resolution is impossible to change as it runs in windowed mode and can't run full-screen. Heck, you even have to watch the windows taskbar at the bottom of the screen! Of course those things can be fixed manually by changing resolution outside of the game and setting the windows taskbar to auto hide, but those are just simple things that are very annoying and it makes you wonder what the devs was thinking... There's also bugs like trying to shoot a torpedo and then change ship while aiming then the aiming remains on and you can suddenly shoot a torpedo from a ship without torpedos.Diplomacy is a joke, I don't even know why they have the diplomacy screen, it's absolutely pointless. It's more like an intel screen where the enemies comes to you and tells you "these are my planets, these are my forces. I have this much defence, this much armor, this much attack. That's it, bye now". Why would an enemy reveal that?Sure, I could have voted Yes if I played the game on a tablet and only paid $2 for it, but not at this price point. It feels somewhat unfinished due to the above issues and it's absolutely not worth more than $2. Fix the issues and it's worth $4, add some depth and it's worth $8.The only thing I like about this game is the user interface and graphics, it's compelling but then you soon realize it's not much more than that.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												For a sid meier game this is remarkably shallow and simplistic:5 resources : energy (to build/upgrade ships), food (to add cities to planets, these up all resource production), metal (to build planetary improvements and wonders), science (fo buy tech improvements), credits (to buy planetary influence or other resources via the market)5 planet types: normal and then four that each provide 50% increase to one of the first four resource types.4 planet improvements to increase the income of those resources, 1 to improve defence and one to help with ship travel.9 ship modules and 9 techs to improve those modules8 ships in a single fleet, can't have multiple fleets, and a limit of 8 to the number of any specific module on each ship.There's a bit of variation with the selection of wonders to build (1 per planet  and it's random as to which wonder is available on which planet), but it still does not make up for the lack of diversity throughout the rest of the game.I can well believe that this was originally designed for the mobile game market.Also FYI anyone who's not getting the achievements for the game for some stupid reason you only get them if you allow all victory conditions.Basically this will provide a small distraction but is not worth considering a full "game".

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												If you're buying this game for the "Beyond Earth Connectivity"... meh. When I heard Beyond Earth and Starships had connectivity, my mind immediately jumped to what yours probably did..."Hey, I can build up my world in Beyond Earth, with Starships effectively acting as a major expansion pack, and start colonizing other worlds too, and colonizing them beyond-earth style, or maybe while I'm still in my initial world, be invaded by faster-advancing colonies from other worlds.... that's Sooooo coool, basically making the game that much more massive in scope!" Well, I got in... started looking for the connectivity.... and was quickly disappointed. I then looked up online to find out exactly *how* they connect and.... they don't. Sure it "says" they do, but they connect in the same way that TF2 connect to Red Orchestra.... they don't, but you get some cross-promotional content in each one for having the other. Whoop de doo. No massive grand multi-world strategies, no epic level conquests on a scale far beyond just one world.It's a classic situation of something living up to nowhere near it's expectations.You want connectivity? Nope. You get some micro-dlc's back and forth. Whee.

												Essentially this plays like a scaled down and simplified version of Star Wars: Empire at War. The differences are: * Factions. There are a few different factions as apposed to EaW's two* You can chose between three main races and a few different leaders each with different abilities* Only one fleet. Each ship is highly customizable. * The fleet has a few action points which regulates how much it can do in one turn* buying planetary upgrades, research or fleet upgrades can be done anytime in your turn, except when in battle* Turned based. The game is essentially turn based, both in the overview and in the space battles. * There are no ground battles. * A game can be completed in relatively short order. * More control on research In essence, a game can be finished in a few hours. It is interesting enough to keep you playing until the end. it should have a decent replayability value based on choice of starting race and leader.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												Bottom-line up front: I'd give this a solid 1.5 out of 10. This is an expensive version of a free Facebook game... read more to find out why. I REALLY wanted to like this game. From the pre-order description, and the fact that Sid Meier does an amazing job with about 95% of the games that they produce, this had a ton of potential.Branded as a 4x game that related to Beyond Earth, I was a bit hopeful to see something that played like Master of Orion 2 and had the space-ground gameplay of Star Commander. Alas, I got my hopes up too high.Also, before you go too much farther with this, just know that I haven't read the other reviews. This is my own take on this game.Everything from the tech, to the resources, (lack of) diplomacy, (generic) space combat, and AI feels flat.TECH: The tech "tree" is just a menu of upgrade. There are no new capabilities to introduce and no real choices that force you to examine tradeoffs and benefits. After playing BE, you'll likely be especially let down because NONE of that innovation exists in this game.RESOURCES: Four resources, and four very narrow things to do with them. Like most campy Facebook games, using your resources requires no more thought than a button click.DIPLOMACY: My main complaint with most Civ games is that you have options that the AI will not accept... in this case, you don't even have those options. Your two basic negotiating stances are a) war, or b) peace. Given the combat, neither has any particular advantages.COMBAT: This is probably the only (slightly) redeeming part of this game. For about the first 20 turns, the combat and the missions are challenging. Once you've pumped enough resources into your ships, you can pretty well steamroll the AI with impunity.Oh yes, the ship customization (and the reason why I was excited about this game)... yawn. Again, like the tech tree, the characteristics of each of your ships can be leveled up to attain greater advantage. There is no researching of new ship hulls, engines, weapons, or shields; just leveling. Facebook flash games have more options than this... such as Battle Pirates.Final thing that I'll say on combat is this: one fleet? If SM was trying a new twist on 4x games to limit player to one fleet and up the challenge, this was a terrible choice. Any potential challenge is wasted because they let you construct warp gates so that you do not use up movement points while moving between your own worlds.AI: Now for the AI. Like the rest of the game, the AI is stale and offers no challenge. In three different play throughs of the game (each at increasing difficulty), I have as yet to have an AI player declare war on me or attack me. I can roam the galaxy with my large armada of heavily armed ships and tear through pretty much every other empire with little effort.What could have been a stellar game (see what I did there?) is really just a black hole for your wallet (even at $13 - as of this writing).Save your money. Save your time. Don't save this galaxy (or SM's bottom line).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												Starships is a fun game where you play as the admiral of a small fleet. It simplifies the technology and resource managing aspect so that the player may focus on their fleet and the missions that they go on. If you are expecting a 4x game then you will be disappointed because this game was not designed around resources but around space tactical combat and does a good job with it. In the galaxy you do get some resource management but all of those including the techs are strictly focused around building and maintaining the fleet. Then there are the missions the player sends their fleet on, they play out like a good game of chess involving a few varied sets of moves and abilities for each ship. With the longer games taking around 2-3 hours this is far more casual then the Civilization franchise it spawned from which makes it easy to pick up and play on a random day as opposed to a civilization game which takes a little bit of commitment to get through.Now for the ugly. The game does have some balancing issues at the moment of release but nothing game shattering. The only 2 victories that you ever go for are population and wonder victories as science victory takes forever to get and when you go for a domination victory you will inevitably conquer over half the galaxy (population victory) before you wipe out the last player. There is also a very sad lack of multiplayer which could have done very well especially if Firaxis set up a single mission game (kind of like what they did with X-Com Enemy Unknown). I am hoping they eventually give us a multiplayer because that would drastically increase the value of the game but even without multiplayer this is a fun game and for $15 ($10 if you wait for a sale) it is not a bad buy.

												This is a tough one.. really wanted to like the game, but it's got some issues.After playing thru a few games, the biggest problem in my opinion: Regardless of what you select as a victory condition, it apparently does not apply to the AI.  So, the game is going to be a race to get to 7 wonders nearly every time.  You can set the game up to the largest, most epic map that settings will allow,.. and if you don't rush and build 7 wonders, one of the AI will.  This causes the game to be over far too quickly.Some other issues:Lack of customization/variety in your available ships.  You have one type of ship available, and you can alter the appearance a bit based on the loadout you select,.. but they all still look basically the same.  Some of the Wonders are a bit over the top.  Stealth torpedos, permenant stealth ships, and a wonder that gives you two actions instead of one,.....battle over.I don't regret buying this game for the price,.. but it falls painfully short in my opinion.  The game seems over simplified.  Not sure if this was because they wanted to pander to the tablet crowd, but I'm not looking to buy a tablet game to play on my PC.Maybe if there are future updates/addons that add more to the game I will adjust my review,... but for now, the game comes up way short for what I expect from a Sid Meier game.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												There may be a lot of negative reviews for this game, but for the right people, this game really hits it.If you've ever wanted just the turn-based tactical combat without the baggage of empire management, this is the game to get. If you've ever set up a Civ5 game on a huge epic pangaea with only elimination victory type, you might want to try Starships using epic + impossible + domination-only setup. You get the fun battles with much less empire management baggage and with much less possibility for lopsided technological mismatch.And if you want turn-based combat in the form of starships in space, this may well be the only modern take in existence because I haven't managed to find any other. Most other 4X games have gone real-time with combat and they come with massive empire management and ship design overhead.Here are a sample of things I liked compared to other tactical (mostly RPG) games:- You can reconfigure your party instantly with little to no resource loss, promoting build diversity. You can refit your fleet into any spec to suit the next battle and respec it back. In most other tactics game, you're locked into particular builds accompanied by long grinding process which you have to repeat if you switch builds.- The game gets going fast with minimal build-up time. Within 2-3 battles, you're already progressing up to considerable strategic options (e.g. cannons, fighters, new ship). In most other tactics games, you'd have to grind around for dozens of missions to gather resources and gain EXP.- The galactic screen is essentially a very good mission chooser screen. Most other tactics games offer very little choice with regard to choosing missions. (e.g. limited to open sidequests, random battles that interrupt your travel, etc.) In Starships, you can look at your borders and choose a mission based on the other empire's strength and your crew fatigue. Mission types on non-federated planets are quite varied.- Planetary Wonders are a really nice way to differentiate the strengths of each player in the game in a way that's halfway between randomized and controlled, and also in a way that you can't plan for from before the game starts the way you could with Civ5 leader traits or world wonders.- No random chance to miss. (looking at you XCOM) Cover reduces damage instead of chance to hit.The only real complaint I have for this game is the lack of multiplayer, although ultimately its addition would probably be no more than what multiplayer was in XCOM which didn't really do much.Another possible complaint is that the AI is not terribly difficult, but I find that it only really has problems when you start using special tactics (like invisible torpedoes). In an open brawl, I find that the AI is quite competent with finding odd line of sight that I can't fire back to and are pretty good at finding a way to shoot your engines. The Impossible difficulty should be good for the vast majority of average players.I like what the game has to offer in its current (and probably final) state and wholeheartedly recommend it for fans of turn-based tactical space games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												This is a great, streamlined strategy game with a heavy focus on -- surprise, surprise -- building a fleet of starships and improving their stats. You improve the ships by spending resources and you get the resources by exerting "influence" over planets (basically, you conquer them). You can buy influence or gain influence by either completing a mission at the planet or by giving your crew shore leave there. Shore leave basically serves as an "end turn" button on the main strategy map and allows your crew to rest and recover, so you can move again next turn from planet to planet, improving them (by building cities, improvements, or wonders) and gaining influence. Aside from the main strategy map, you'll also be conducting an awful lot of combat missions on a more detailed battle map. You'll fire torpedoes, which you can detonate at will after the first turn when an enemy is nearby (or you think it's nearby), or perform scans, or simply shoot an enemy vessel with your ships' weapons. Asteroids little the 2D battle arena that provide some cover for your vessels as you manoeuvre into an advantageous position. The best thing? These battles, while numerous, move very quickly, so you'll never get bored. You can win the game through a variety of means, though the most common one is the "population" victory, where you control 51% of the galaxy. The end isn't particularly exciting: you'll get a dialogue box that essentially tells you, "You win!", followed by a short and rather nondescript video. But the game is fun! Yes, it's nowhere near as complex and involved like any of the Civilization games, but it isn't supposed to be. This is Sid Meier's Starships, not Sid Meier's Galactic Empires. It's streamlined and simple without being simplistic. You'll be doing all the standard 4X things: exploring, expanding, exploiting, and exterminating, but at such a brisk pace you can easily finish a full game in a couple of hours or less. If you expect this to be the next big Sid Meier game that will devour your life for months if not years on end, you'll be disappointed. (And incidentally, congratulations on having so much spare time on hand!) If instead you're looking for a quick, fun turn-based strategy game with lots of fairly interesting options and brisk combat, then Sid Meier's Starships is worth your time and money. I thoroughly recommend this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												There may be a lot of negative reviews for this game, but for the right people, this game really hits it.If you've ever wanted just the turn-based tactical combat without the baggage of empire management, this is the game to get. If you've ever set up a Civ5 game on a huge epic pangaea with only elimination victory type, you might want to try Starships using epic + impossible + domination-only setup. You get the fun battles with much less empire management baggage and with much less possibility for lopsided technological mismatch.And if you want turn-based combat in the form of starships in space, this may well be the only modern take in existence because I haven't managed to find any other. Most other 4X games have gone real-time with combat and they come with massive empire management and ship design overhead.Here are a sample of things I liked compared to other tactical (mostly RPG) games:- You can reconfigure your party instantly with little to no resource loss, promoting build diversity. You can refit your fleet into any spec to suit the next battle and respec it back. In most other tactics game, you're locked into particular builds accompanied by long grinding process which you have to repeat if you switch builds.- The game gets going fast with minimal build-up time. Within 2-3 battles, you're already progressing up to considerable strategic options (e.g. cannons, fighters, new ship). In most other tactics games, you'd have to grind around for dozens of missions to gather resources and gain EXP.- The galactic screen is essentially a very good mission chooser screen. Most other tactics games offer very little choice with regard to choosing missions. (e.g. limited to open sidequests, random battles that interrupt your travel, etc.) In Starships, you can look at your borders and choose a mission based on the other empire's strength and your crew fatigue. Mission types on non-federated planets are quite varied.- Planetary Wonders are a really nice way to differentiate the strengths of each player in the game in a way that's halfway between randomized and controlled, and also in a way that you can't plan for from before the game starts the way you could with Civ5 leader traits or world wonders.- No random chance to miss. (looking at you XCOM) Cover reduces damage instead of chance to hit.The only real complaint I have for this game is the lack of multiplayer, although ultimately its addition would probably be no more than what multiplayer was in XCOM which didn't really do much.Another possible complaint is that the AI is not terribly difficult, but I find that it only really has problems when you start using special tactics (like invisible torpedoes). In an open brawl, I find that the AI is quite competent with finding odd line of sight that I can't fire back to and are pretty good at finding a way to shoot your engines. The Impossible difficulty should be good for the vast majority of average players.I like what the game has to offer in its current (and probably final) state and wholeheartedly recommend it for fans of turn-based tactical space games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												It's a neat, simple game. Perfect for a few hours when you can't afford the time to play Civ. For me it's perfect, a classic old few-features 4x space strategy. The kind of strategy game you don't have to learn every quirk about because you're busy playing other games (and living) as well. I personally LOVE that simplicity.Take-away: This is a casual game that will still eat a lot of hours, just not as many as the Civ games.The unlocks between C: BE and Starships could be called P2W, irritating, or if you have them both... um, neat. It is a bonus anyway, but rather poorly integrated so you don't really know what unlocks you have unlocked (especially in C:BE).Is it worth the cost? Barely! I picked it up cheap through Humble Bundle in a big civ bundle. It was basically a bonus game. That said, so far I've spent more time on Starships than on C: BE.There are some bad things: It's basically a windowed game/ipad game. To me that's almost a bonus though. If you have a peace treaty, it's not completely obvious or straith forward how to declare war/break the peace. The UI is...not refined... and I'm being polite saying that.The lack of multiplayer and some seriously lost potential is sad too. They could have expanded on this game, a lot, for that price without making the game more complicated. Basically they did a lot of things.. um, not wrong, but poorly, but for what it is, and that's pretty unique nowadays, I still recommend it. It's a blast from the past when things where simpler, but not always easier.(I just *tried* to play Crusader Kings II and my head hurt trying to get into it all again. While those games are amazing - I love them - I just don't have the time to invest.)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 7
												I really want to give a thumbs up. I really do. But I feel as though other space 4X games are much, much more worth your money. The game makes it almost impossible to win other than through war and the interface was a bit counterintuitive at times. Domination victories can catch you off guard because Starships's definition of Domination is just control 50.01% of the population and win. Personally, I hate those types of victories. There are other victory types, but they are almost never achieved because you or the AI will win Domination way earlier than any other victory.ProsThe ship battles were fun and engagingExploration was done wellMarketplace (different than directly trading with other players)ConsHard to use interfaceLack of replayability (especially with city management, wonders, and technologies)Poorly thought out victory conditions and cannot turn on/off certain victory condition typesAlmost non-functional diplomacy system (at least for the AI to AI interaction) and no any tradingFor builder type players, this game is definitely not for you(Edit: In the first paragraph, the victory condition I was referring to is called Population victory, not Domination victory)
